para.tab:
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan)
took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Treasurer's announcement that the government has decided to slug business a further $121 million with an increase in fringe benefits tax on employer provided cars. I ask the minister whether he has noted the comments of the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries that, in its view, people will hold on to their cars longer now which will cost the industry sales. I ask: what studies did the government make of the effect of its tax slug on the Australian automobile industry? Did it examine the likely consequences on sales? I ask this in light of the concerns that are being expressed about local manufacturing in Australia and, in particular, the interests of the Ford Motor Company.

—The changes to the fringe benefits tax arrangements are the product of an extended review of compliance costs through a process which took fully into account not only the revenue implications of various possible options but also, naturally, as one would anticipate, the larger economic consequences. The view that was taken by that review, which the government has accepted, is that there was a very strong case to be made for rebalancing the impact of the FBT and, in particular, to deal more appropriately and sensibly with a whole variety of issues like entertainment, car parking, after hours taxi travel and the treatment of other items that are primarily for business use. Those issues did need to be addressed in a way that was, nonetheless, revenue neutral.

para.tab: The other side of the coin was to change the rate at which cars were taxed, still making it perfectly clear that car benefits will remain significantly concessional under a whole wide range of circumstances. There is never totally going to be three cheers whenever it comes to any kind of tax review exercise of this kind. People will always scream and yell about what they perceive to be the additional impost while, at the same, pocketing very cheerfully—

talk.start.para: —On a point of order: the minister seems to have missed the point of the question. We do not want the argument for putting up a tax; we want to know what consequence—
—That is not a point of order.

—It is a point of order. He is answering a different question. We want to know what studies the government undertook into the effect on the Australian car industry of increasing this particular tax on cars. I hope you can get some good advice, minister. At a time when the Ford Motor Company is talking about perhaps having to pull out of Australia because of a lack of competitiveness in the overall economy, how will this help the Ford Motor Company? What effect will this tax hike have on the car industry?
—Order! There is no point of the order.

—I am not at all surprised that Senator Hill should be carrying on in this fashion. Obviously, it is very much part of the opposition's strategy to divert attention from the mess it has got itself into in terms of its own budgetary proposals and its own macro-economic capacity. This is the alternative, would-be government that would have us believe that you can have a `See, Mum; no hands' budget where you do not have to worry about outlay reductions or do anything that is too difficult in that respect; where you do not do anything about tax increases; and where you do not have any kind of rational monetary policy either. This is the mob of incompetents that have the hide to sit there and lecture us on the ways in which you apply taxation policy and fiscal policy around the edges.

para.tab: The truth of the matter is that all the implications and all the possible impacts of this kind of a review of the compliance costs were fully and sensibly taken into account. It was obviously necessary to address some concerns. Your own alleged business constituencies have been very concerned for a very long period about some aspects of that compliance regime. We fixed that. We are determined to maintain revenue neutrality because we are determined to maintain fiscal responsibility. All you can do, as usual, is to bay about the terrible iniquity of it. You have to realise that in this particular business you cannot just pocket all the benefits every step of the way and whinge to this or that constituency about what you perceive to be the downside. This was a balanced and sensible result of a process that was full and complete in its review of all relevant considerations.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I am sure the answer will be of great interest to people in this chamber and to the Australian community in general.
—Let us be the judge.

—I do not know whether you would be able to judge. Minister, you are clearly concerned about the recent events relating to the proper standards of operation being applied in the meat industry. There is public concern and fear as a result of a recent Haemolytic Uraemic Syndrome case in South Australia. These concerns were further highlighted by media claims, including those of the Meat Inspectors Union, pointing to the lack of integrity in our meat inspection process. Bearing in mind the impact of these events on the Australian public and our international customers, what remedial action have you taken, or are you going to take, to seek to ensure the highest possible standards are observed in this important industry?

—I thank Senator Burns for the question and I acknowledge his strong personal interest in this issue as Chair of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee. There is understandable concern in the community about food safety and meat inspection. Regrettably, that concern has been heightened by a number of inaccurate and very misleading claims that have been made publicly, following the tragic HUS case in South Australia. The combination of both has the potential to undermine public confidence in our domestic and export meat systems.

para.tab: In my view, the Australian public and our international customers need to be reassured as to the veracity and integrity of our meat inspection systems. As all senators in this chamber would be aware, the Commonwealth has no constitutional power to impose a national meat inspection service. However, a number of codes of practice are in place to underpin national standards for inspection in these areas. The compliance of respective states with these codes is now voluntary.

I have written to all state primary industry ministers to seek their agreement at this week's meeting of ARMCANZ, which will be held on Friday, to a thorough review of the relevant codes to ensure that they are complete and current. I will also be seeking the agreement of the states to make these codes mandatory. This would ensure a uniform set of standards applying in the states.

It is essential that our domestic and export systems operate around a common core of standards that satisfy consumer demand and requirements. I will be asking the council to endorse a number of other approaches relevant to this issue, which include the draft strategic plan my department has been preparing over the last six months on minimising E.coli contamination in meat—that intense work was begun halfway through last year as a result of the deaths from HUS infections that occurred in the United States a year ago—the wider introduction of hazard analysis and critical control point based quality assurance systems in the export and domestic meat processing sectors, ultimately as a condition of continued certification; and future arrangements for the delivery of meat inspection systems.

talk.start.para:
—The minister made mention in his answer of a strategy to help deal with E.coli food poisoning. The minister would be aware of a report on
Four Corners
last week which claimed CSIRO research on E.coli 0157:H7 was bad news for Australian meat exporters. Can the minister confirm this to be the case?

—I was extremely disappointed personally in what I thought was a very hastily put together program by
Four Corners
. I can inform the Senate that CSIRO has written a strongly worded letter of protest to the executive producer of
Four Corners
pointing out the total inaccuracy of statements that were made on that program. CSIRO has stated in its letter that during four to five hours of interviews and briefings with the
Four Corners
team, the reverse of what it told
Four Corners
was broadcast. Its survey showed that the quality of Australian meat was at least as good as, and in some respects better than, US meat in terms of contamination with enteric pathogens.

para.tab:
Senators may well recall that the
Four Corners
story was part of a joint investigation with Radio National's health report program. I commend this letter that
Four Corners
has written about the inaccuracies in the
Four Corners
program. I might add that, in terms of the people that should read this letter from CSIRO, Don Ford would certainly be included among them. Mr Ford should have particular regard to the fourth paragraph on page 2 in respect of his outrageous statements about a direct connection between Australian beef and the deaths in the United States. I table the letter from the CSIRO.

question.speaker: Parer Sen W.R.

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is directed to the Leader of the Government in Senate. Minister, on 8 February in response to a question from me, you refused to reject a statement by the Labor member for Lilley, who said:

question.para: New taxes on hotel rooms and restaurants would be consistent with Labor's philosophy of a progressive approach to taxation.

Can you now tell us why in your reply you chose to conceal from the Senate the fact that the government last month commissioned a study on the impact of a bed tax on the tourism industry? Will the government undertake to make the study available to the tourism industry as the basis for discussion before any new taxes, in particular, a bed tax, are imposed on this industry?

talk.start.para: —It is the case, I am advised, that the Department of Tourism did commission ACIL Economics and Policy Pty Ltd to report on the impact on employment in the tourist industry and on the economy generally of a proposal that was obviously initiated not by the government but by ACOSS and put into the public domain by ACOSS some time ago for a five per cent bed tax. It is perfectly understandable that the tourism department should want to be in a position to assess the pros and cons of such a tax, in particular, in the context of any enthusiasm for revenue that might be in the mind of the finance department at the moment.

para.tab: Nothing is to be assumed from that about the status of that particular proposal. It is no more than speculation. We are not responding to speculation on this or any other subject. There is no basis at this stage for the assumption that underlies Senator Parer's question. It is simply a matter of the government doing what governments are supposed to do—that is to say, govern—and, in the course of governing, to carefully review the pros and cons of particular proposals that are put into the public domain and have some credibility.

talk.start.para: —Will the government undertake to make that study available to the Senate and the tourism industry so that informed discussion can take place?
—I will refer the honourable senator's question to the relevant minister and see what his response is on that.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the minister to reports in the
Canberra Times
this morning of a poll reported as being commissioned by the Liberal Party. Under the guise of objective research and with the preamble that all the statements about to be made were true, those people who were contacted for the poll were then asked to react to a number of supposed public positions supported by the Labor candidate for the by-election in the electorate of Canberra, together with supposed details of her record of activity.

para.tab:
Honourable senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Colston has the call.

—Mr President, I will probably go beyond the minute because of the interruptions. Is the minister aware of campaigning techniques developed in the US which use sham polling as a vehicle to spread unsubstantiated and baseless rumours about opposing candidates?
(Time expired)
—Mr President, I take a point of order. That question is entirely out of order and does not relate to the minister's responsibilities in any way whatsoever, and I ask you to rule in that way.

—On the point of order: Mr President, as the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, and therefore responsible for the administration of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, it is absolutely straightforward that this matter is the proper responsibility of the Minister for Administrative Services. He is very concerned about it and wants to take some action about it, which I am very happy to have the opportunity to tell the Senate about.

—On the point of order: I had asked one question. I was further going to ask whether the minister would attend to this matter in relation to his responsibilities for the electoral act. Under those circumstances I would suggest that the question is in order.

—On the point of order: Mr President, what you have just heard from Senator Colston is a very straightforward admission that he did not in the allotted time ask a question that was within the area of responsibility of the minister. What he was really trying to ask you to do was to take account of what he would like to have asked which would have made it relevant. Therefore you have no choice but to rule that he had not got to the point of being relevant and that the question was hypothetical and cannot be answered by the minister.
—I judge the question to be in order as far as it went, without being completed.

answer.speaker: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para:
—The minister and I have had this campaign technique drawn to our attention by concerned citizens who thought that this was the first time—but we have subsequently discovered that it is the second time—in Australia that this technique has ever been used, a technique pioneered by the extreme right wing Republican candidates in the United States. I am very concerned about this technique as it has been employed by the Liberal Party both in the Northern Territory last year, as I now discover, and in the ACT last week. I think it ought to be referred to the Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I think the committee should inquire into it. This is a conscious attempt to deceive intending voters and manipulate them under the guise of objective research. David Broder in the
Washington Post
last year exposed this new technique when it was being developed in the United States. He said:

answer.para: Every time you think that the political campaign operatives have hit rock bottom and can't find anything sneakier and more underhanded to do they prove you wrong.

It is the lowest form of political conduct I have ever heard of in Australia—the worst I have ever heard of. The technique in itself is dubious but its application on this occasion is based on outright lies—and things that must have been known to be lies by the people who sought to ask the questions. In the course of the introduction to the questions that were asked, they said:
All of the statements I'm going to read to you are true—

Then they proceeded to read the most scurrilous list of defamatory allegations about an individual I have ever heard, knowing that they were untrue. This is gutter politics of the worst order. It is no good Andrew Robb this morning getting up and saying, `I thought they were true.' How can he have thought that a quote from a book that does not exist was true? He alleged that Sue Robinson had written a book that does not exist and then delivered a quote that was not from it and sought deliberately to create false impressions in the minds of hundreds of people who were rung in the hope that a rumour they could not state in public could be started under the lap. This is not something that the Federal Liberal Party can dissociate itself from. The architect of this campaign works out of John Howard's office, and we know that it is true.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I take a point of order. This minister does have responsibility for the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Perhaps he should refer to the provisions of that act on which he bases his answer.
—There is no point of order.
—That is why I think it should be investigated—to make sure that the electoral act is adequate to cover these sorts of heinous activities. Mr Textor is the architect of this.
—Mr President, I take a point of order.
—Very sensitive.

—I am not very sensitive at all. The minister has answered the question. He is now clearly debating it. Are we all going to have an opportunity to debate it? Are we going to debate the fact that your government deliberately misled the Australian people at the last election, lied to the Australian people—l-a-w tax cuts?
—Order! Senator Hill, get to your point of order.
—The point of order is that he is debating the issue; he is not answering the question. This is not the time for debating. He has answered the question and he should be told to sit down.
—On the point of order: what I said was that I believe a certain course of action should be taken and these are the reasons it should be taken in response to the question, and I am articulating them.
—What are you going to do?
—Refer it to the committee.
—There is no point of order.
—It is quite clear that, given that Mr Textor has initiated this program out of Mr Howard's office, Mr Howard should sack him and make sure it stops right now.

—Mr President, on a point of order: he is bringing out the names of individuals, saying they work in particular offices. How can that be anything but debating the issue? This is a blatant abuse of the rules of question time and he ought to be sat down.

—Mr President, on the point of order: is this the same minister who last week appeared before a Senate committee and said that it was okay for $1.5 million of taxpayers' funds to be used to fund a political hit squad? It is the same hypocrite.
—Order! There is no point of order there and you know it. That was a statement and nothing else, and that is an abuse of question time and an abuse of points of order.
—Mr President, if you allow him to debate the point, then we are entitled to join in that debate.
—You have made your statement. You have not made any point of order.

—The Leader of the Opposition must dissociate himself from this and the Liberal candidate, who ducked and dived around it on radio this morning, must also dissociate himself from this because the people of Canberra will judge them accordingly. I am not sure if this deceit is a breach of the electoral act. It is not absolutely clear that it is a breach of the electoral act. If it is—and it should be—it should be referred to the joint standing committee and I expect the minister to take that action.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. It also refers to meat, but by way of preamble I say that the Democrats totally reject the minister's earlier assertion that the Commonwealth does not have powers under the trade and commerce powers and the corporations powers. Following the death of a child in South Australia and the hospitalisation of 18 others, does the minister agree that the lack of a uniform system of meat inspection for all meat slaughtered in Australia, whether for domestic or overseas consumption, is unsatisfactory? Is it the case that there is no national notification of food poisoning data nor any national keeping of such information and that the recent outbreak of food poisoning, which has already resulted in one death, will not be recorded in a national register of such events? Will the government seek to implement a uniform national system of meat inspection both for domestic and for exported and imported meat, using its constitutional powers if necessary, and a national system for the central collection of data on food poisoning episodes in all parts of Australia?

—I have already answered that part of Senator Coulter's question to do with my own portfolio. He may not like the answer, but that is the answer I have given. The other question of the notifiable nature of these matters is a matter for the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence. Dr Lawrence has in fact provided me with the following response in relation to the second part of Senator Coulter's question. Food hygiene is the responsibility of the states and territories. Notifiable diseases are also the responsibility of the states under their respective health acts.
—The good old states again.

—If you want to argue the current legal status of this, go for your life. But these are the facts. There is a national notifiable diseases surveillance system which collects information on communicable diseases fortnightly from the states and territories.
—It doesn't work.
—Do you want to listen to the answer, Senator Kernot, or not?
—Order! Senator Collins, direct your remarks through the chair.

—The organism E.coli 0111 associated with the recent outbreak of food-borne disease in South Australia is not notifiable under state and territory health legislation. The surveillance of food-borne disease will be reviewed at a national workshop of the Communicable Disease Network Australia next week. I have already in my answer said that I intend to put a proposition on the table on Friday with the primary industries ministers that the standard codes that do exist be mandatory, not voluntary.

talk.start.para: —That's not a mobile phone, is it?
—What if it is?
—What if it is? It is the technological challenge of the nineties to try to speak for 10 minutes without being interrupted by a mobile telephone, even in the Senate.

Opposition senators interjecting
—

In conclusion, knowing Senator Coulter's academic interest in this—it was his previous field or certainly a field closely related to it—he may be interested in looking at that letter from CSIRO that I tabled today complaining about the inaccuracies that were broadcast about the outbreak of HUS in South Australia. He may be also interested to know the extent of the work that has been done by my department, in cooperation with CSIRO and with state departments of health and primary industry, over the last six months in the formulation of the action plan that will be presented to primary industry ministers on Friday.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Very simply, will the minister use the constitutional powers—namely, trade and commerce and corporation powers—if his attempt to get state cooperation does not work?

—I thank Senator Coulter for the last thing he said. I will certainly try to get the agreement that I can on Friday from state ministers that Senator Coulter referred to in the last part of his question. I will wait to see what the reaction of state ministers is to that proposition on Friday before I contemplate taking the second step that Senator Coulter has raised in his question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the announcement made on 22 February by United Kingdom Prime Minister Major and Irish Prime Minister Bruton on the joint framework agreement for Northern Ireland. I ask the minister: what are the prospects of this latest development bringing a lasting settlement to Northern Ireland?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —The announcement of the joint framework document I think is probably the best news that has come out of Ireland for a very long time and we very warmly welcome it. It builds on the work undertaken for the joint declaration issued in December 1993. The latest proposals provide a balanced and thoughtful basis on which the parties can now proceed towards a comprehensive political settlement in Northern Ireland.

para.tab: The document reaffirms four guiding principles for cooperation between the two governments, the UK and the Irish government, in search of an agreement—that is to say, the right of self-determination, the consent of the governed to the implementation of any new arrangements, the pursuit of a settlement through exclusively democratic and peaceful means, and full respect and protection for the rights and identities of both traditions.

The framework document also addresses the question of constitutional obstacles to a settlement by proposing legislation which could give effect to both the British and the Irish governments' commitment to the principle that the people of Ireland should be able to decide their own future.

answer.para: Despite these guarantees to protect the rights of both communities, the joint document and the British document for accountable government, which was issued at the same time, will certainly require a willingness on the part of all interests to act, to negotiate, in good faith and with the long-term interests of the people of Northern Ireland at heart.

para.tab: The initial response to the framework declaration has been reasonably heartening in that respect. There have been inevitably critical reactions from some members of the unionist parties. The people of Ireland, Britain, the province itself, however, have overwhelmingly welcomed the proposals that are contained in the document and there does seem to be every chance that there will be a continuation of the peace process on this basis.

There has been a considerable measure of goodwill evident since the abandonment of violence by the IRA and loyalist paramilitaries some six months ago. We can all only hope that that will continue. We will continue to lend our support to the process of dialogue and reconciliation in any way that becomes relevant to do so. It will be recalled that Sir Ninian Stephen played a very helpful role in one of the earlier stages of negotiations in which some of the ideas that have now emerged in this document I think were starting to be taken seriously.

Moreover, we have made a very substantial financial contribution to the International Fund for Ireland of $7 million. That I think again is tangible evidence of Australia's commitment to this process—a commitment which I am sure is shared by all Australians, not just those like Senator McKiernan of noisily Irish extraction.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is the minister aware of the frequency with which Labor government legislation is being held to be unconstitutional by the High Court, the most recent being the decision last week in Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, with more decisions almost certain to follow within the minister's own portfolio? Given that the government cannot seem to get it right and it routinely declines to disclose to this chamber the legal advice it relies on in support of such legislation, will the government now reassess the quality of the legal advice that it is relying on to ensure legislation is constitutional? More particularly, what action is the government proposing to take with respect to the Brandy decision? In particular, what action does the government intend to take with respect to moneys paid and received by parties to HREOC proceedings since that time?

—Let me say at the outset that it is the nature of our legal system and constitutional system that cases are taken to court—sometimes you lose, but much more often you win. Senator Vanstone, the reality is that both you and I spent a good four years or so at law school learning about cases of the High Court and other courts, and that is the way law is formulated.
—Your record is appalling.

—If you were to compare the record of this government as opposed to any other, I think you would probably find that ours is not all that much different in terms of the success rate. Going through history, we see that even the great Menzies lost some notable cases in the High Court. He got bowled over time and time again. It is the reality of the constitutional system that we have here. There is no sense in seeking cheap, political point scoring out of this, Senator Vanstone. It does not enhance your credibility outside this place at all, and I must say that it does need enhancement.

para.tab: I will turn now to the question about the HREOC determinations. I am advised by the Attorney-General that, as an immediate but interim solution, the government has decided to reinstate the scheme which existed before the amendments were made in 1992. That scheme, of course, was very expensive for the parties but did not provide for enforceable determinations and placed a heavy onus on complainants to bring Federal Court proceedings to obtain a binding order. Although it is recognised that the scheme has significant drawbacks—that is why it was replaced in 1992—it did provide a valid process for the resolution of complaints.

As well as that, the government anticipates the introduction of legislation to establish a permanent mechanism within six months. With this in mind, a review committee has been asked to report in three months on the most effective means of creating a constitutionally sound scheme for the investigation and resolution of complaints under the Commonwealth anti-discrimination laws—a scheme which meets requirements for accessibility, informality, simplicity and cost-effectiveness. We have been driven in this area by the need to ensure a quick access to ready remedial measures. That has been the driving force in the past, and that will be the driving force now in terms of the government's long-term response to this problem.

The review committee will consist of representatives from the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Finance, HREOC, the Australian Law Reform Commission and the Administrative Review Council and a QC who is a part-time HREOC hearing commissioner, Mr John Basten QC. As to the other incidental part of your question, I will take that on board and get you an answer.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I hate to waste this supplementary question, but I need to ask whether the minister will get that information with respect to the latter part of the question. What is going to happen to parties who have paid over, received and perhaps spent money in good faith and do not have it left? I am amazed: this decision is nearly a week old, and you cannot tell the Senate what is going to happen to the people in the street who are going to be upset by it. You say you will take it on notice. Will you at least give a commitment that you will come back tomorrow with an answer about what is going to happen to those people? That is the most important question.

—I can give you an assurance that we will be faster in our response to you than you have been in presenting that one piece of legislation that we are all waiting for—the racial hatred (Vanstone) bill. We have been waiting for that for months, and we are still waiting for it now. It is an easy thing to do. There are all sorts of precedents around the place, but we are—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Bolkus is now debating the issue. He is not answering the question he was asked. He is being vitriolic and inappropriate. I ask you to direct him to sit down or to speak relevantly to the question.
—You certainly are debating the point, Senator Bolkus. I ask you to wind up.
—On the point of order, Mr President: Senator Vanstone was debating the question. I, in fact, was responding to the points that she was making, so I ask you to rule differently.
—Two wrongs do not make a right. You were debating the issue; wind up your answer.

—As I said at the outset in my response to the supplementary question, we will come back to Senator Vanstone and the Senate with an answer pretty quickly. I think it was Thursday, in fact, that the High Court decision came down. It does take some time to analyse these things, Senator Vanstone. You may not know that because your responses are all in the media but we never get to see the substance of them. Why don't you show up with your legislation? Let us have a look at it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to reports that the Treasurer is considering the imposition of compulsory worker superannuation contributions of 3 per cent to promote national savings. I ask: has the government noted that the FitzGerald report on national savings identified the ageing of the population as a major cause for the need to increase national retirement savings? If so, has the government considered the need not to impose further taxes or imposts on workers raising families if it does not want to exacerbate the problems of an ageing population? Will the government exempt from any compulsory superannuation scheme workers with dependent children who are at a stage in their life cycles when so much of their income is being expended on housing, feeding and educating children? If not, why does the government regard household investment in human capital as inferior to investment in physical or financial capital?

—I have noticed that this proposal, so-called, has seeped into the ether of the debate about the forthcoming budget and is therefore being reported and therefore being bruited around Canberra. But, of course, I am not in a position, as Senator Harradine would know, to comment on what ideas or proposals the government has before it leading to any consideration touching on the budget. So, therefore, I cannot comment, and will not, on the question that is being asked, other than to make these observations.

para.tab: I take the question as indicating what Senator Harradine's position might be on this subject. On the subject of superannuation I point out that it is under this government that the fairest superannuation scheme in the world has been introduced into Australia. Previously, before we came to office, superannuation was the preserve of those in public employment or those in white collar jobs, and the vast majority of Australians working in other industries did not have access to superannuation cover.

This debate is possible, and these speculations about what the budget might contain arise, because of the massive changes made under this government to superannuation—the imposition of a superannuation guarantee charge to industry to ensure that proper superannuation provision is made. It is in that context and in the context of the circumstances around the charge that this proposal comes up. But I do not wish to comment, and cannot, on any matters touching on the budget.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am not asking the minister in two of the questions to comment on what might happen in the budget. What I did ask him was: has the government noted that the FitzGerald report on national savings identified the ageing of the population as a major cause of the need for increasing national retirement savings? If so, has the government considered the need not to impose further taxes or imposts on workers raising families if it does not want to exacerbate problems of an ageing population? Why make an impost on the very people who are expending their savings on future taxpayers? That is what I am asking the minister. That is not asking him to comment on the budget. I am asking him for a general view of the matter.

—I will decline, if I may, to offer a general view on this matter since it has been linked in speculation relating to the budget. But to the specific questions: has the government noted the recommendations of the FitzGerald report? Yes, we have. Further: have we noted this one? Yes, we have. Senator Harradine, you may have heard the Treasurer from time to time make reference to his view about that report. We regard it as a central one and the issue of national savings and the level of national savings in Australia to be of primary concern in framing any measures at all and a concern—
—After 12 years you have finally woken up to it.

—We commissioned the report; you did not. There is a concern about the level of national savings to generate a level of investment from within Australia. The superannuation guarantee charge has generated one of the highest levels of national savings and is the device by which savings can be pushed up much further.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. In 1990, when agreement was reached on the national Aboriginal health strategy, Minister Tickner said that the health, life expectancy and lifestyle prospects of Aborigines would be `dramatically boosted'. —I assume my time starts again. My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. answer.speaker: Faulkner Sen J.P.

talk.start.para: —No matter what the Commonwealth's view is of the Tasmanian government's decision to waste what I believe is a reported $3 million of taxpayers' money for a road that probably will carry no more than 10 cars or 10 four-wheel drive vehicles a day, the Commonwealth has not had and does not have a role in the approval of that road. This is a matter for which the Tasmanian government has to take responsibility. It is its responsibility. It has a responsibility to protect that area, to protect the environmental values and, if world heritage values exist in that area, to protect those values as well. I have certainly indicated to the Tasmanian Premier what those values are. The Australian Heritage Commission has done work in relation to the values of that area. That has been communicated to the Tasmanian government. I have indicated on behalf of the Commonwealth its views on the environmental impact of building that road.

para.tab: The Commonwealth's powers to act in relation to this particular matter are limited. The 1992 intergovernmental agreement on the environment sets out agreed consultative processes to be followed in relation to the identification and nomination of areas for listing as world heritage areas. This Tarkine area has not been nominated by the government for inclusion on the world heritage list. Any nomination of additional areas in Tasmania would in fact be in the context of the agreement that was struck on 28 November 1988 about this issue. Paragraph 12 of that heads of agreement said:

answer.para: The Commonwealth undertakes not to initiate any further inquiries into forestry in Tasmania or to propose any other areas of Tasmania for World Heritage listing without the concurrence of the Tasmanian Government.

That was an agreement reached between the then Prime Minister and the then environment minister and resources minister on the part of the Commonwealth and, on the part of Tasmania, the then Premier and the then minister for forests. In terms of the identification of potential world heritage values in that area, the government's preferred position, as I have indicated on a number of occasions, is that that be done as part of the comprehensive regional assessment process.

talk.start.para: —I thank the minister for informing us that there were several different provisions which would be relevant here—the 1992 intergovernmental agreement, the Cook-Groom heads of agreement and of course the world heritage obligations. What we really need to know is which of those would have primacy. Which will the government pursue as the primary influence on its policy making in this area? It is very interesting to hear that there are three potentially conflicting areas of agreement, obligations or legislation, but which one will the government take as its guidance?

—The government is committed to progressing these issues in accordance with the provisions of the intergovernmental agreement on the environment. I have indicated that any potential world heritage area nomination would be done taking account of and in the context of the 1988 heads of agreement. The responsibility for the building of this road ought to be sheeted home to where it belongs—that is, the Liberal government in Tasmania. It is its decision and its decision alone to build this useless road through this very important wilderness area. I believe, and I have said this in the past, it is nothing more than an act of environmental vandalism and the Tasmanian government will be condemned for doing so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. When this bill was being debated here issues were raised about whether the act would affect state laws on incest, abortion, pornography and prostitution. There is, of course, a broad range of laws across Australia which deals with the private sexual conduct of adults. Most of these laws are reasonable, justified and necessary. They draw an appropriate balance between the needs of the community and the right of the individual. Such laws will not be affected by the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Act 1994.

para.tab: As I said earlier, that was made clear in the explanatory memorandum and during the debate in the parliament. Just because the act has been raised in the context of a challenge to Queensland's prostitution laws does not mean that it will provide the basis for a successful challenge. question.block.title: Partnerships for Development Program and Fixed Term Arrangements Program

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook. I note that a report released by the Bureau of Industry Economics last week found that the partnerships for development and fixed term arrangements programs have delivered a net benefit to Australia. Can the minister advise the Senate of how these benefits have been achieved and whether they are sustainable over the longer term?

—I do believe they are sustainable over the longer term. Last Friday the Bureau of Industry Economics released its evaluation report on the partnerships for development program and the fixed term arrangements program. These are programs that work in the information technology area and essentially they encourage major international information technology companies which wish to bid for government contracts in Australia to set up associations or business arrangements with domestic information technology companies for the purpose of developing new technology or simply working together and achieving a better international as well as domestic output by the Australian part of the partnership and the international part of the partnership.

para.tab: The evaluation of these programs found that the partnerships for development program has been a net positive for the Australian economy and that it has been a key factor in ensuring that the Australian information technology industry has grown dramatically. In 1993 Australia's information technology and telecommunications exports by the partners under this program were valued at $1.2 billion. I might say that is six times more than the level of exports only six years ago—in 1988. So over that six-year period there has been a six-fold increase in exports out of Australia of information technology.

Australia's exports in computer hardware, software and services overall now total in excess of $2 billion annually and the industry has set itself a target of a $10 billion export industry by the year 2000. That is a voluntary target it has imposed on itself after assessing market potential and the strong competitive nature of the Australian information technology industry.

In addition, over the same period investment in research and development conducted in Australia has increased nearly five times to be valued now at $300 million and, of course, that springs off the fact that Australia is the second largest information technology and telecommunications market in the Asia-Pacific region after Japan. After Japan, we are the biggest market.

talk.start.para: —How come we are going backwards?
—We are not going backwards; we are going onwards and upward, and I have just given you the figures for the six-fold development that we have had over the last six years.

para.tab: The partners have worked with over 300 Australian companies and research bodies. They include Aspect Computing; CPG; ERG, a Western Australian company; Intellect, another Western Australian company; Keycorp; Netcom; and QPSX. They have also worked with a number of universities to harness the intellectual powerhouses that these universities have on campus. The universities involved were the University of Wollongong, the Sydney University of Technology and the University of Queensland. Others have participated as well.

talk.start.para: —How is Monash going?

—Monash is included amongst those, Senator Ray. The BIE estimates that if these programs were discontinued that lead to a 20 per cent drop in activity in this area. We do not intend to discontinue these programs. The future, therefore, for this important sector of the Australian information industry is very bright and the enthusiasm of the companies, including the multinational partners, is very high in succeeding to achieve the goals that they have set themselves. The assumption about whether this can continue is a justified one. It can given all of those market settings.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Treasurer (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Harradine this day, relating to superannuation and national savings.

speech.para: Dr Vince FitzGerald, in his report to the government, which is now several years old, very vividly portrayed the need for Australia and Australians to lift their level of savings. At the time of the report, Dr FitzGerald drew attention to the fact that savings at 16 per cent of gross domestic product were lower than at any time, apart from the major recession and the two world wars.

para.tab: What is really needed in this country—we are starting to get there—is an integration between public and private superannuation. This will be necessary to alleviate a lot of pressure on the budget. I remind people that, by the year 2031, we will actually have three people working for one person who is on some form of government assistance, particularly in relation to the aged.

Firstly, the superannuation guarantee charge was introduced in an environment of lifting the level of national savings. That will be a long-term reality. The minister may have misled the parliament a little in indicating that it has already raised the level of saving. I think he is being a little optimistic, but obviously in the very long term it will lift national savings. Secondly, the superannuation guarantee charge was introduced in an environment of alleviating the pressure on the budget.

There has been a fear within certain sections of the community, particularly amongst those people who are disadvantaged, that the superannuation guarantee charge would eliminate the need for social security pensions for people in their twilight years. I am pleased to say that the two major parties have categorically denied the fact that they will remove such safety net assistance. There will always be people in the community who for one reason or another—whether it be lifestyle, health reasons, et cetera—may not accumulate the necessary funds for a satisfactory and a viable retirement incomes policy.

Senator Harradine sought to extract from the minister assurances that the government certainly would not raise taxes. In his question, he drew attention to a number of people who deserve special recognition because of their condition and their family responsibilities. I think Senator Harradine's question was an important parliamentary contribution.

I also use this opportunity to point out that Australia is one of the few countries in the world that actually taxes superannuation at three levels—on entry, which is the contributions tax; on earning the income; and sometimes on exit. Most countries normally tax at two levels. I think it is important that, in order for there to be greater confidence in superannuation, we wipe out the possibility of any suggestion of increased taxes on superannuation contributions, earnings or the like.

Superannuation is already under some scrutiny, and there is a degree of lack of confidence. Some of that lack of confidence is due to what I call `short termism'. I call on everybody, particularly the financial reporters, to look at the longer term. After all, superannuation is a little like buying a house. If you valued your house each quarter and looked at the movements in interest rates, you probably would not get much sleep in terms of paying off your house. This short termism of looking at returns from superannuation on a quarterly basis is not particularly helpful. I call upon everybody to look at the long-term perspective in order to get this situation right.

In the 15th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, which we recently released, we also indicated that the government should examine the feasibility of certain exemptions or tax relief, particularly for contributions during the early stages, so that the beneficiaries can build up an investment where there is going to be a viable, compounding segment. Unfortunately, in the lead-up to a budget situation, a lot of ideas are being floated. Unfortunately, this question of a tax on superannuation or employees being forced to contribute to superannuation was very badly handled by Canberra. I refer to Canberra in its widest sense, because perhaps four or five groups got it hopelessly wrong. Even the trade union movement has accepted the concept that ultimately there will be employee contributions.

The committee has before it a reference to terms of the 9 to 12 component. I think it was always acknowledged that, if there was going to be an employee component, it would always be part of a package. In other words, there would be some sorts of offsets but what sorts of offsets from that package were not spelt out. We must clarify the issue that there should be no further taxes on superannuation.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I think when you decode the speculation that is surrounding the next budget one thing is clear: the employee co-contribution is a serious proposal, and with that in mind the Democrats have done a little bit of preliminary work on this proposal.
—Oh!

—It is more than you have done. The way it is proposed, a three per cent employee co-contribution or tax would raise about $5 billion, and it would reduce the disposable income of an average worker—about $600 per week—by $18 a week. The government is arguing that the employee co-contribution could be a way of dampening demand without increasing taxes or interest rates.

para.tab: I think we need to look at who this co-contribution would affect most. The Democrats believe that the effect of this would be to hit fairly and squarely low income earners. High income earners would be able to switch other savings, but low income earners who have no savings would have to dip into consumption and save more under compulsory saving. There could be some benefit, we think, in forcing high income earners to switch from speculative to long-term savings—like superannuation—but most high and middle income earners are already paying superannuation contributions in excess of three per cent and would not have to pay any more.

In an analysis of Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, we discovered that an employee co-contribution would hit hardest those earning less than $500 to $600 a week, while those earning above $600 a week would be largely unaffected. We further concluded that the SGC employer contribution has provided an overwhelming benefit to low income earners because their superannuation coverage has risen dramatically since 1991. The amount of superannuation payments voluntarily made by employees though, as distinct from employers, has dropped markedly since the introduction of the superannuation guarantee charge. This could be explained by a reduction in the $3,000 tax deduction—although the low level of confidence in superannuation, the likely rearrangement of private schemes by employers following the introduction of the superannuation guarantee charge, and employees reducing their own superannuation payments as their employer contributions rose could all have had an effect on this result.

I think we need to look at the drop-off in voluntary contributions and see that it highlights the need to get the tax concessions right and, as Vince FitzGerald and the Democrats have said, to move away from compulsory contributions towards encouraging voluntary payments. Senator Cook answered the question that was asked today by referring to national savings, and what he said was true: Australia's household savings ratio across all incomes is well below what it should be. Since 1980 it has fallen from 10 per cent of income to four per cent. The harsh reality is that even low income Australians seem to be living beyond their means. So by international standards we are a low wage country, yet we still seem to think we can sustain a high wage standard of living.

Is this the answer to the national savings problem? Both Tony Cole, ex-Treasury, and Vince FitzGerald argue that the primary benefit of the superannuation guarantee charge is to boost national savings and improve the current account in the long term. But at this stage I think we should be asking just what contribution an employee co-contribution will make. I think the extent to which it will reduce demand is probably overstated.

There is that more difficult question of where the national savings is enhanced or reduced by choosing between public sector and private sector savings. But that is something I could come back to. It is early days. It is very important that Senator Harradine too is raising the question of the impact of an employee co-contribution on low income earners in Australia. They are not the only ones who have families but certainly we are right to concentrate on the effect of this co-contribution at this point of time on the disposable income of low income earners in Australia.

talk.start.para: —Having heard what the minister said and to a certain extent what Senator Watson said, I am not satisfied. In fact, I am very fearful. I am prepared to say now: Watch out, you workers. Beware. You are going to have your wages cut by $12 to $15 a week. It is all very well to tell people to trust that there might be some packages and trade-offs. I do not trust packages and trade-offs. If it is said to me, `They are ACTU sponsored packages and trade-offs' I do not trust ACTU sponsored packages as they turn out because many of them are devised by very rich, very well-off, two-income bureaucrats who would not know what it was to work on an ordinary wage. So let us just read what is being said here. The workers are gonna cop it. The middle to lower income workers will cop it with a compulsory impost of superannuation. I remember when somebody sold me—I do not know who it was, CML or whoever—a super scheme when I was single. I will not tell the Senate when that was—
—A few years ago.

—A few years ago. When the children came along and when I had mortgage repayments I found that I could not keep up the payments. I had to blow it. I had to cash it in for much less than it was worth. I found as many families now find—they cannot make ends meet on one income. That is who the government is going to hurt mostly—the families with children. I ask: if all of this is about our ageing population, if we need to have national savings because we have an ageing population, why feed the medicine to the people who are trying to lower the ageing population by having children? Why attack the people who are nurturing, feeding, clothing and training the future taxpayers? I did not get an answer from Senator Cook.

para.tab: I may have misunderstood Senator Watson. He was talking about taxation on superannuation. I agree that there should be no further impost. I agree that it is triple dipping in some cases at present. But I feel very strongly that we should not have a compulsory superannuation impost such as is being canvassed around the traps at present. If we do that, then we are regarding household investment in human capital as inferior to investment in physical or financial capital. Only monopoly capitalists do that. If government members are all monopoly capitalists, I certainly am not. I wonder what the federal government is doing when it adopts the philosophy of a monopoly capitalist, because that is what it would be doing if it regards household investment in human capital as inferior to investment in physical or financial capital.

We will revisit this, no doubt, but I do feel the workers have to realise what is coming down the track. This fast train full of the baggage of compulsion is coming right down the track at them. The result will be that their disposable income will be even less than it is now and they cannot exist on it as it is.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I wish to take note of the tabling by Senator Faulkner of a couple of documents. It is not strictly speaking an answer to a question, but if I do not do this now I do not know when I will get the opportunity to do so. Senator Faulkner has just tabled a series of documents, two of which were of particular interest to me. I will, of course, study them in detail. I wanted to make some brief comments at the very earliest opportunity on two of them. One of them is the report by Professor Stanley into the environmental management charge on the Great Barrier Reef.

para.tab: Senators will recall that for a year now commercial operators have been paying this environmental management charge—just another name for a reef tax. This report by Professor Stanley, which I have been eagerly awaiting for some months, is a recommendation to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and therefore to the government that `the authority should consider a charge on private boat users of the marine park.'

I have almost led the call for better funding for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, but this funding should come from the existing revenue that this government takes from private boat owners, not from a new tax to be charged on recreational boat users of the Great Barrier Reef. Already the federal government gets 33c a litre fuel tax from private boat owners who use outboards and inboards.

This fuel tax was originally supposed to go to fixing the roads. But as I have said time and again, people on the sea do not use roads, so the government gets an absolute skinner for that. Fuel tax of 33c a litre is an absolute rip-off of private boat users. In addition, the Queensland government rips them off with a registration charge and it has just recently snuck in another $12 a year charge which no recreational boat users in the north were aware of. Both the state and federal government think they can keep taxing recreational boat users time and time again.

talk.start.para: —I hope you declare your interest.

—My friend said I should declare an interest. My boat these days is only a four-metre tinny and I would not go out anywhere near the Barrier Reef so I do not have to pay that fee, but I do pay registration fees and I do pay the 33c a litre fuel tax for the outboard I use. I agree that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority needs more funding but it should get it out of existing government taxes, not from some new taxes which this government, desperate to try to balance its budget, wants to impose.

para.tab: In the couple of minutes I have available to me, I want to repeat something for the benefit of all those senators who did not listen to the estimates committee last week, and I am sure there are a couple of those. Senator Faulkner indicated that his government paid $125,000 to environmental groups—

talk.start.para: —To Natalie.

—To Natalie and others to assess these forest coupes, and we asked for some details of where that money went. The contracts with these conservation groups—the assessing agencies—that were tabled in the Senate indicated that the groups would put in acquittals. Those acquittals were supposed to be detailed statements of where the $125,000 was paid because, amongst other things, we wanted to find out whether this $125,000 went to highly qualified assessors or whether it went to Natalie and others. We were really trying to find out how much Natalie and others got and what their qualifications were.

para.tab: The documents that Senator Faulkner tabled today—and he actually tabled these in the Senate estimates committee at my request—showed that the Western Australian group did detail where it went and what it spent the money on. But it showed that, of the $125,000 that went to the Western Australian conservation movement, only $1,200 went to the highly qualified people. The rest of the $125,000 went who knows where—to people without qualifications and on materials, office expenses and rent.

For Victoria, New South Wales and Tasmania, there is no detail at all—just a bland statement saying that some money went to office administration and some went to assessors. When we inquired further, we were told that the conservation group—I think it was from Victoria, but I stand to be corrected—just said that it charged a percentage of the grant as a rent.

talk.start.para: —Environment Victoria.

—My colleague reminds me that it was Environment Victoria. This is not an acquittal. This is not what this chamber expects to see as an acquittal for expenditure of taxpayers' money, so we have asked for more details. Senator Faulkner said that he will try and get those details from the various conservation groups, but it seems to me that we need a lot more accountability when it comes to the huge amounts of money paid by this government for those assessments—assessments which, as it turns out, were completely useless.

petition.para: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

talk.start.para: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

tab.emphasis: Report No. 21 of 1994-95—Project audit—Specific purpose payments to and through the states and territories.

speech.speaker: Calvert Sen P.H.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: I will not speak for too long on this matter because, as the report has only just become available, I have not had a great amount of time to look at it. I think it is important to make the point that specific purpose payments to the states and territories are a very significant component of the Commonwealth's expenditure—something like $16.68 billion, or $16,680 million. So any report by the Auditor-General of efficiencies that can be made, therefore, is quite significant, particularly in the run-up to the budget process. We all know that specific purpose payments are made under section 96 of the constitution. That provides:
. . . the Parliament may grant financial assistance to any State on such terms and conditions as the Parliament thinks fit.

The Auditor-General has been quite critical of some matters relating to the administration of these particular specific purpose payments. This report documents the results of a survey that was carried out jointly by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and the Australian National Audit Office. No doubt we will hear a lot more about that when the Joint Committee of Public Accounts makes its report.

para.tab: The Auditor-General points out that the administration of specific purpose payments has potential for considerable improvement. He lists particular concerns in areas such as the accountability to parliament, the content of the specific permanent agreements and the management of the specific purpose payments. He points out that some of the key findings of the survey are that for many programs the accountability to the Commonwealth is poor. He points out also that some programs do not require statements or certifications of expenditure. He points out that there are deficiencies that have been identified in reporting to the parliament on specific purpose payments and many problems exist in the collection of data on specific purpose programs. So it is a very important report.

He notes that the survey identified a number of specific purpose payments where the authoritative basis of those particular payments consisted only of copies of letters and copies of cabinet decisions. In one case he could not find any authoritative basis at all for these payments being made. We are talking about $16,680 million. When you see these types of queries being raised, it shows you just how inefficient this government has let the Public Service become and how lazy and tired this government has become. We heard earlier Senator Campbell raise some points about the inefficiencies of the government and the things it gets up to. The Audit Office, in its usual precise manner, has targeted some of these areas.

The report has only just been made available, but I remind senators that in 1991 the Auditor-General pointed out that in this particular area of specific purpose payments there had been excessive delays in the provisions of statements of expenditure. He raised complaints and questions about the independent certification of these particular payments. Then in 1993-94 he was again critical when he said that he had noted that there was a potential for improvements in accountability. There was also a need for more accountability, value for money and protection of the Commonwealth's interests. These are quite serious allegations, yet here again we have the same types of criticisms in the Audit report No. 21 of 1994-95.

For instance, the Auditor-General points out that most payments made from the Commonwealth to the states have conditions attached, yet a lot of these conditions have not been adhered to. This is the part that strikes me—and we are talking about a bureaucracy that has been around for so long and with this amount of money to be spent: in conducting the survey the Auditor-General tried to find, through the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and through the Budget Papers No. 3, how many specific purpose payments had been made and a register of those payments was produced. He said, `Difficulties were experienced in attempting to establish the total number from two official sources,' and they are the ones I just quoted, `so we ended up with a best-guess list.'

It is not good enough in this day and age to come up with only a best-guess list when you are talking about the expenditure of over $16 billion and when you want to find out how many specific purpose payments have been made to the states and local government bodies. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts will have plenty of criticism of the government for allowing this situation to arise. We end up with something like 92 as a best-guess list—92 of which 50 are administered by the Department of Human Service and Health and DEET. Seventy-three per cent of the funds are paid through these two particular areas.

We know that a lot of this money obviously is tied up with the one nation and better cities programs and the bandaid approach that this government tried to make to the unemployment situation in this country. No doubt, when the Joint Committee of Public Accounts looks in depth into these problems it will find that a lot of this inefficiency has been brought about by the government decisions made on the run—the bandaid approach to the great problems caused by the recession we had to have in this country.

The other area the Auditor-General is critical of is cash management. He is quite critical of the in-advance payments and states that 28 specific purpose payments, worth $4.2 billion, are paid solely on an in-advance schedule and a further 32, totalling some $9.7 billion, are also paid on a combination of payment schedules which includes an in-advance component. He believes that the Commonwealth should use its powers to make sure that this area is cleaned up. In fact, he recommends that for future specific purpose payments departments negotiating SPP agreements liaise with the Department of Finance to determine appropriate payment schedules so that these matters can be corrected.

I talked earlier about the fact that the survey identified a number of grants for which letters and cabinet decisions were the only things that existed. The Auditor-General pointed out in one case that there was no basis for any authority and I just wonder whether in fact that was one that was wiped off a white board.

The Auditor-General has made a constructive suggestion that greater use could be made of incentives for the states and local governments to cut down the wastage that obviously exists in these programs and says that by sharing the savings it is an incentive for the states, local governments and the Commonwealth to be more efficient. I hope that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has a good look at this and makes sure that these things are brought forward.

As I said, other members of the coalition have not yet had the opportunity to view this report. It concerns me, and I am sure it concerns others, that once again the Auditor-General has been critical of the way this government is handling taxpayers' money and particularly the way in which it is being distributed to the states and local governments through these specific purpose payments. I hope that this survey and inquiry that is being carried out by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts finds out the problems and recommends to the government ways in which it can clean up its act and start saving a bit of money rather than just wasting it. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

speech.para: In tabling the report of the visit to Thailand and Laos by a delegation of six members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I would like to comment on three issues.
The first is the tabling of a separate report on this visit.

Honourable Senators may be aware that the Joint Standing Committee has been, for the last twelve months or so, conducting an inquiry into Australia's relations with Thailand. The delegation's visit to Thailand and Laos was an integral part of that inquiry. The delegation, and then the members of the Committee, took the view that the matters dealt with in this report should be presented to the Parliament before the overall report on the terms of reference was tabled. That will happen later this year.

The delegation was in Thailand from 18 November to 1 December 1994. In that time, it was able to visit Vientiane in Laos for part of a day. Within Thailand, it was able to travel quite extensively, spending much of its time in and around Bangkok, holding discussions with a number of Ministers, officials and other organisations such as UNHCR. The delegation also went to Hua Hin, Chiang Mai, the lignite mine at Lampang, and to Nong Khai in the north east. While in that part of Thailand, members saw the Friendship Bridge over the Mekong River and crossed it to get to and from Laos.

The delegation was able to make visits to Hellfire Pass and the Kanchanaburi War Cemetery. Wreaths were laid at both places on behalf of the Government and People of Australia. Simple ceremonies as these reinforce the links between Australia and Thailand, links forged in terrible circumstances more than 50 years ago.

A breakfast with the Australia-Thai Chamber of Commerce was a valuable way to hear about the experiences of Australian firms working in Thailand. Information from this meeting was supplemented by visits to some factories and building sites run by Australian companies. All these firms left the same messages with the delegation: optimism about the future of the country and also about their company's future there.
The second matter on which I would like to speak today is Thailand's view of its position in its region.

The submission to the inquiry on relations with Thailand from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade drew attention to the primacy that country attaches to its immediate region in the formulation of its foreign policy. This in itself is hardly surprising. Thailand is an influential member of ASEAN and a central country, in more than a geographic sense, in South East Asia.

What did surprise the delegation was the frankness of the exposition of Thailand's views about its place in its region. In particular, members were told of its involvement with the Mekong Corporation, made up of the six riparian states and now increasingly involving Burma and Cambodia. There was mention of the quadrilateral of Thailand with Burma, Laos and southern China, and a growth triangle with Malaysia and Sumatra in the south. In the analysis of these and other possible groupings involving nations in the region, the point was made that the changed definition of security now included economic components. In keeping with this emphasis, likely opportunities for Australia were frequently mentioned.
Thirdly, I would like to comment on the prominence given to Laos in this report.

Since the adoption of a new Constitution in 1991, Laos has gradually liberalised its attitudes and practices. Debate within the National Assembly has been relaxed so that there is more debate about legislation. The 1991 Constitution also formalised the establishment of a market-oriented economy. With its small population, Laos faces many difficulties as it continues its change from its former ways.

While in Vientiane, the delegation held discussions with members of Assembly committees, and with the Chairs of two others. It was clear that Australia is held in high regard in Laos and that there are a number of areas where we might, in consultation with the Laotian authorities, be of assistance. One of the primary reasons this report has been tabled is to ensure the opportunity to assist Laos is made clear to the Australian Government. Even more important is the fact that, without such a separate report as this, Laos could not have been dealt with in the report on relations with Thailand.

As the delegation found out in Vientiane, there are already a surprising number of Australian firms and personnel in Laos. The Friendship Bridge has shown the region what Australian expertise, and development assistance funds, can do. Many opportunities exist in such a climate.

Finally, I would now like to thank the members of the delegation for the work they have put into this report. Their three recommendations, about funding for the National Thai Studies Centre at the Australian national University, about funding for laos and about the Embassy's facilities in Vientiane, all deserve serious consideration.
I commend the report to the Senate.
