speech.para: MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1994

This bill is part of a package of amendments to Immigration and Ethnic Affairs portfolio legislation. This bill amends the Migration Act 1958 and the Immigration (Education) Act 1971. The other bills are the Immigration (Education) Charge Amendment Bill 1994, the Migration Agents Registration (Application) Levy Amendment Bill 1994 and the Migration Agents Registration (Renewal) Levy Amendment Bill 1994.
The purpose of these bills is to:

.implement Government decisions accepting recommendations of the Business Skills Advisory Panel in relation to the cancellation of business skills visas. These amendments are consequential upon the creation of new subclasses of business skills visas and are required to maintain the integrity of the cancellation regime established by the Migration Act 1958;

.give effect to some recommendations of the Committee for the Review of the System for Review of Migration Decisions (CROSROMD) to enhance the non-adversarial nature of the Immigration Review Tribunal (IRT). These are primarily to provide the applicant with additional entitlements in relation to the presentation of, and access to, material before the Tribunal.
.create the positions of a Deputy Principal Member and Senior Members of the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT). These amendments are designed to enhance the effectiveness of the RRT.

.provide for the Remuneration Tribunal to determine the remuneration of members of the IRT and the RRT. This will bring both Tribunals into line with other Tribunals such as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Veterans' Review Board;

.to implement the Government's decision to provide for the increases in portfolio fees, charges and levies in line with the impact of price movements on Commonwealth government running costs outlays without the need to periodically amend primary legislation.
The proposed indexation amendments are contained in separate bills as follows:
.this bill (amendments to the Immigration (Education) Act 1971);
.Immigration (Education) Charge Amendment Bill 1994;
.Migration Agents Registration (Application) Levy Amendment Bill 1994;
.Migration Agents Registration (Renewal) Levy Amendment Bill 1994.
All other amendments are amendments to the Migration Act 1958 made by this bill.
I will now outline the amendments made by this bill.
Firstly, the provisions which relate to Business Skills migration visas in this bill complement improvements approved by the Government in the Business Skills visa class.

The current legislation provides for the mandatory participation by Business Skills migrants in the monitoring of their business activities for three years after their arrival in Australia to ensure individuals comply with their obligations to engage in business and to evaluate the effectiveness of Business Skills migration. The legislation also gives the Minister the power to cancel the visas of Business Skills migrants, within 3 years after their arrival in Australia, if they do not engage in a business or make genuine efforts to do so.

Amendments to the Migration Regulations which are expected to be introduced in April 1995 will create extra opportunities for business people to migrate or remain permanently in Australia, namely those who have substantial business skills and funds to invest or have established businesses in Australia. The Government is introducing these new opportunities for migration following recommendations by the Business Skills Advisory Panel, an expert panel of business people and other key stakeholders in the business migration field.
This bill provides for minor amendments in relation to the power to cancel visas held by some people who are approved under the new Business Skills subclasses.

This bill provides a power to cancel visas held by those people who are approved under the new Investment-linked migration provisions if they withdraw the funds they have invested in designated investments in Australia within 3 years of investment, but not on other business related grounds. The designated investments will be government guaranteed securities with certain features, including maturity three years after purchase, and a commercial rate of interest payable. A notice of the approved designated investments will be gazetted once final details are agreed.

Those people who are approved to remain permanently on the basis that they have an established business in Australia, will not be subject to these cancellation provisions as they will, by definition, have to be engaged in business in Australia to be approved for stay. They will, however, be required to participate in the mandatory monitoring system for 3 years after visa grant. The monitoring system has provided valuable information on the performance of Business Skills migrants in Australia and will continue to be used for policy development, evaluation and planning services to assist migrants to engage in business.

I now turn to the provisions which propose to implement some of the recommendations of the Committee for the Review of the System for Review of Migration Decisions (CROSROMD). It is intended that these provisions will enhance the operation of the Immigration Review Tribunal and further strengthen the non-adversarial nature of the Tribunal.

In December 1989 changes were made to the Migration Act 1958 to establish a two-tier system for the review of certain migration decisions. The review system established the Migration Internal Review Office, a first tier and internal system of review, and the Immigration Review Tribunal, an independent external merits review Tribunal which operated within a non-adversarial framework.

The then Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Minister Senator the Hon. Robert Ray, in establishing the new review system, gave a commitment that the system would be examined after it had operated for two years. CROSROMD, chaired by the Hon. Ian Macphee, was established in 1992 to put that commitment into effect. The Committee examined and reported on the extent to which the system for merits review of migration decisions met the statutory objectives of providing a review mechanism which is fair, just, economical, informal and quick. It reported to the Government in December 1992.

CROSROMD found that the Immigration Review Tribunal had earned a reputation as a credible, fair and independent body for review of migration decisions. Notwithstanding its positive view of the role of the Tribunal, the Committee made recommendations for a range of legislative reforms relating to the operations of the Tribunal, to strengthen its non-adversarial nature. In particular it proposed amendments to the Migration Act to include changes in the gathering of evidence, the conduct of hearings, and the power of the Principal Member of the Tribunal to give directions about the operation of the Tribunal and the conduct of reviews. The proposed amendments will give a review applicant an entitlement to obtain access to information and material relevant to their application before the IRT. An applicant will have the right to submit written material to the Tribunal, to request the Tribunal to obtain written material relating to the matter under review, and to give oral evidence and submissions to the Tribunal. This complements the current legislation which already allows an applicant to appear before the Tribunal to give evidence at their hearing, and to request the Tribunal to call witnesses.

The fairness and effectiveness of the review system will be further enhanced with the extension of an applicant's rights in relation to the information before the Tribunal. Amendments will extend the rights of the review applicant to present arguments in addition to giving evidence at the hearing of their application. The review applicant will also have the right to see any material which is before the Tribunal, unless contrary to the public interest. Together, these amendments will ensure that an applicant has access to all the evidence, other than such evidence excluded on public interest grounds, thus strengthening the thoroughness and fairness of the system.

When the IRT was established it was envisaged that the Tribunal would always operate in a non-adversarial manner, and the legislative provisions passed at that time were meant to require the Tribunal to operate in that manner. Some judicial comments have cast doubt on whether the Tribunal was always required to operate in this manner. To reinforce the non-adversarial role of the Tribunal this bill clarifies the matter of cross-examination; that is, that an applicant, their assistant or a witness is neither entitled nor permitted to cross-examine any other person appearing before the Tribunal. The amendment is consistent with the CROSROMD report which recommended that applicants and their assistants should not be able to cross-examine witnesses, and strengthens the non-adversarial ap proach.

The introduction of a provision for interpreters to be appointed during the oral hearing for any applicant or witness, where the Tribunal deems it necessary, implements a CROSROMD recommendation to this effect and is a positive reinforcement of the current practice of the Tribunal. The use of an interpreter, whenever a person does not have sufficient proficiency in English, ensures equal access to the review process for applicants from non-English speaking backgrounds and strengthens the social justice role of the Tribunal.

The intent of proposed subsection 366A(2) is to strengthen the non-adversarial nature of the Tribunal by ensuring that people are able to assist applicants in limited circumstances before the Tribunal. People assisting applicants are not able to examine or cross-examine witnesses. They are not able to present oral argument to the Tribunal without its consent, to be exercised at its discretion and only in exceptional circumstances (other than where there is a lack of proficiency in English) such as when the applicant has a mental disability.

Proposed subsection 366A(2) is not intended to prevent assistants from commenting on minor and routine matters which could assist the Tribunal, such as providing it with guidance or referring to relevant parts of the documentation. Communication of this kind should obviously occur.

As this is a matter which goes to the operational procedures of the Tribunal, I would expect the Principal Member to develop and promulgate specific rules relating to the conduct of those appearing before the Tribunal.

In its report, CROSROMD recommended that the Principal Member of the Tribunal be empowered to give directions about the operations of the Tribunal and the conduct of reviews. This bill proposes that the Principal Member have the statutory power to give such directions. This will enhance clarity and consistency in the conduct of reviews and operations of the Tribunal and is consistent with general powers held by other review tribunal heads such as the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

In considering information before the Tribunal, CROSROMD recommended that an additional level relating to the disclosure of information be introduced. This bill empowers the Minister to certify that the disclosure of information or documents, otherwise than to the Tribunal, would be contrary to the public interest and cannot therefore be disclosed to any person other than a member of the Tribunal. This complements the two levels restricting or qualifying disclosure of information already contained in the Migration Act for the purpose of review. The Minister can currently certify that certain information must not be disclosed to the Tribunal, or can provide a certificate alerting the Tribunal to the sensitivity of certain information, which has either been provided in confidence, or which if disclosed would be contrary to the public interest. In the latter event the Tribunal must then decide how to use the information provided, which can be released at their discretion. This additional level on restriction of disclosure, where the Tribunal must not disclose the information, ensures that the interests of third parties and witnesses are protected.

This bill also proposes amendments which are designed to enhance the role of the Refugee Review Tribunal by providing for the creation of the positions of a Deputy Principal Member and a number (as prescribed) of Senior members.

The RRT was established as a independent statutory body under the provisions of the Migration Act following a review of the processes for dealing with the review rights of persons seeking refugee status within Australia. The Tribunal commenced operation on 1 July 1993.
The Tribunal currently consists of a Principal Member and a number of other members. Provision was made for the maximum number of such members to be prescribed by regulation.

It has been found that this structure of just one Principal Member who is the "Chief Executive Officer" with sole responsibility for the operation of the RRT does not provide an effective management structure.

This bill proposes to create the position of Deputy Principal Member who will work with the Principal Member in providing the necessary management and leadership for the Tribunal. Provision is also made to create positions of Senior Members who will take an enhanced role within the structure of the Tribunal.

The amendments proposed in this bill are part of a package of measures designed to improve the productivity of the RRT. These amendments will provide the flexibility to create a management structure better suited to the achievement of the desired levels of productivity.

The provisions of this bill will not result in an increase in the total number of permissible members. This will continue to be prescribed by regulation (currently 100). It does however represent a redeployment of existing resources in a way which should result in improved productivity on the part of the RRT.

This bill also proposes amendments to transfer responsibility for setting remuneration of members to the Remuneration Tribunal. To date the remuneration of IRT/RRT members, other than the Principal Member, has been determined by the Government. To enhance the perception, as well as the reality, of the Tribunal's independence, and after receiving the views of the Administrative Review Council on the matter, the Government has decided that it is more appropriate for remuneration issues to be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. This bill effects the legislative amendments necessary for a Member's remuneration to be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal, subject to some transitional provisions.

Lastly, Mr President, this bill together with the other bills being concurrently considered, implements the Government's decision to index most fees, charges and levies charged under Immigration and Ethnic Affairs portfolio legislation from the date they were last set or varied by introducing a formula for automatic annual indexation.

The bill proposes to amend the Immigration (Education) Act 1971 to provide for the automatic indexation of these fees and charges. This will ensure that the relative share of the costs of providing English language tuition services borne by the taxpayer, and the relative share of these costs borne by the consumers of those services, will remain constant in real terms.
This will maintain the balance between ensuring social justice for migrants entering our community while responsibly controlling the budgetary impact of maintaining these high quality services.

Refugee, humanitarian and preferential family entrants will not be affected by the amendments being introduced. The Government is committed to ensuring that they continue to receive the best level of service possible without incurring any financial burden.

The changes only affect charges levied on migrants in economic categories; migrants who have been selected for their ability to benefit Australia. It is reasonable to expect them to contribute towards measures that will improve the chances of their individual success in this country.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

PARLIAMENTARY CONTRIBUTORY SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995
This bill amends the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948 and the Superannuation Laws Amendment Act 1994.

The main purpose of the amendments is to improve the operation of provisions which allow certain former members and senators who re-enter Parliament to repay lump sums paid under the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Scheme and receive recognition of prior parliamentary service for future benefit purposes.

The existing provisions of the scheme allow former members of the scheme who have not qualified for pension benefits, and who received lump sum benefits instead, to enter a contract with the Parliamentary Retiring Allowances Trust to repay those lump sums.
In return for this repayment, the scheme recognises the actual period of prior parliamentary service towards future benefits, including pensions.
Currently, affected members may enter contracts with the Trust within three months of re-entering Parliament, with the Trust having discretion to extend this period to six months.

Mr President, this bill will extend the period during which the trust has discretion to enter a contract from six to twelve months. In a number of past cases, and in one current one, this contract has not been signed within the six month period. The extended discretionary period should allow the trust and any affected future members sufficient time to enter contracts.
The bill contains transitional provisions to allow current members who have not been able to enter repayment contracts with the trust to do so within three months of this bill receiving Royal Assent.

The extended discretionary period is to be subject to a cut-off date in the event that the former member's parliamentary term expires before the end of any other period contained in the provisions. This is to ensure that the affected members' decisions are made while they are still members of the scheme.

The bill also proposes to replace the existing provision for repayment of the actual sum received with a repayment amount which is updated in line with movements in basic parliamentary salary from the time the original lump sum was paid until the time the affected member enters a contract with the trust. This would remove a possible windfall to the affected member which arises from the current provisions, where he or she may have received interest on, or otherwise made use of, the lump sum amount. The level of basic parliamentary salary, applying from time to time, is used to calculate pension benefits and is therefore an appropriate index to be applied.
The bill contains a minor amendment to the Superannuation Laws Amendment Act 1994 to remedy a numbering error.
In the context of the whole parliamentary contributory superannuation scheme, these amendments will have negligible financial impact.

TAX LAW IMPROVEMENT (SUBSTANTIATION) BILL 1994
Background
Mr President, for many years the income tax law has been criticised for being too difficult to read and understand.
This difficulty has led to:
unnecessarily high compliance costs for taxpayers;
increased administration costs for Government; and

para.tab: inaccurate compliance by taxpayers.

speech.para: In November 1993, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts recommended the setting up of a broadly-based Task Force to rewrite the income tax law. The following month, the former Treasurer, Mr. Dawkins, announced the Tax Law Improvement Project.

The project's goals are to reduce compliance costs and to improve compliance by restructuring and rewriting Australia's income tax law so that it is more easily understood. The project is not a policy review, but it will provide opportunities to remove unnecessary complexity and cost from the administrative requirements of the law.

The project team includes personnel from the Australian Taxation Office, the Treasury and the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. In addition, the Assistant Treasurer appointed 2 private sector representatives to the project's leadership, and has set up a 14 person Consultative Committee drawn exclusively from outside the Government sector.
The project will run for 3 years from 1 July 1994.
Substantiation
The Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill 1994 is the first new law to be brought forward by the project team.

Early in the life of the project, the team identified the need to rewrite part of the existing law as a possible legislative model that could be publicly tested and assessed through processes of consultation. The substantiation provisions were chosen because they affect 7 out of 10 taxpayers. These provisions set out the rules to be followed in claiming deductions for work-related expenses.

The Assistant Treasurer released an exposure draft bill in August of last year, and over 3,500 copies were distributed. As well, the members of the project held well-attended seminars around Australia to discuss the bill.

Overall, feedback from the consultation process was very positive. It indicated that the redraft was much easier to understand and could be expected to lead to a significantly greater use of the tax law itself as a source of information for tax practitioners and others who need to understand the law. More importantly, most people who took part thought the proposed changes would reduce their compliance costs.
What the bill does
Mr President, this bill makes improvements to the substantiation provisions of the law that may be considered in 3 parts. They are:
a clear, helpful structure and lay-out;
plain language in a personable style;
cutting back administrative requirements that are unnecessarily complex or out of touch with current commercial reality or normal behaviour.
Changes to structure

The bill significantly changes the structure and order in which the substantiation law is presented, so that the important requirements of the law are more easily found. One of the innovations of the bill is the use of highlighted key principles at the start of each major segment of the bill. These give readers a simple entry point. As well the bill makes extensive use of navigational aids to identify, and guide readers to, those provisions relevant to them.
Changes to language
The existing law has been completely rewritten in clear, everyday language that tries to anticipate the needs of its readers.

To make readers more comfortable in following the law, the bill introduces another innovation by addressing the reader personally throughout as `you', using a tone that is essentially friendly and not bureaucratic.
Greater use is made within the text of examples and notes to provisions.
The bill is shorter, clearer, simpler and more readable than the present law. Overall, the legislation has been reduced by about half.
Changes to administrative requirements
In order to make the procedural rules less cumbersome, the main changes proposed by this bill are as follows.

The existing log book rules for calculating car expenses are so complicated that few taxpayers fully understand them. The greatest complexity is in working out what percentage of your car expenses you can deduct. The bill will greatly simplify this calculation and reduce the occasions when a new log book must be kept. This is one area of the bill where the approach taken in the exposure draft bill has been further improved as a result of the extensive consultation process.

Access to the "cents per kilometre" method of calculating car deductions will be extended, so that more taxpayers can use it. The cents per kilometre method is the most often used of the 4 methods available for calculating car expense deductions. Currently, it can't be used at all if business travel is more than the 5,000 kilometres in a year. That restriction will be eased so that claims up to 5,000 kilometres can be based on this method even if business kilometres are more than this. The maximum claim remains unchanged at 5,000 kilometres.
Record keeping requirements will be eased in several ways. For example:

para.tab: taxpayers will be able to claim up to $150 worth of deductible home laundry expenses without needing to keep receipts. This commonsense change has been particularly well received in the community;
taxpayers will no longer be required to go to the trouble of signing every entry in a log book or travel diary;
in recognition of practical realities, taxpayers will be able to annotate receipts from suppliers if they contain insufficient information to identify the goods or services supplied.

speech.para: The exception from substantiation for taxpayers who claim no more than $300 of work and car expenses will be effectively widened by excluding car expenses from the limit. Most taxpayers with car expenses usually have such large claims that they are unable to benefit from the exception, even though their other work expenses may total less than $300. By excluding car expenses, these taxpayers will not have to substantiate their other work expenses within the $300 limit.
Date of effect

So that the benefit of improvements, including simpler administrative requirements, can be available to taxpayers in the current income year, the changes will apply to expenses incurred from 1 July 1994. A special saving provision will apply for the 1994-95 income year to ensure that nobody can be detrimentally affected by any of the changes.
Revenue Impact
None of the proposed changes result in a gain to the revenue. Overall, the changes may result in a cost to revenue of around $2m-$5m per annum.
Full details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1995

The bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It will give effect to announcements which have been made by the Government including some of the decisions made in response to the Report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into the administration of the tax system.
The bill will establish a Taxation Ombudsman within the office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman.
This measure and the allocation of additional resources to the Ombudsman for review of ATO action will improve equity in the taxation system.
The measure will not involve any cost to the revenue.

The bill will change the rules for making a public taxation ruling by the Commissioner of Taxation so that a ruling is made when it is published and notice of the ruling is published in the Commonwealth Gazette. This measure removes any uncertainty about when a public ruling is made.
The measure will not involve any cost to the revenue.

The third measure in the bill arising out of the JCPA Report will remove the power of the Commissioner to impose or reimpose an administrative penalty where a prosecution for the same act or omission is withdrawn.
The bill also makes related amendments to ensure taxpayers are not exposed to administrative penalties for an act or omission for which the taxpayer is being prosecuted.
There is an unquantifiable impact on the revenue for these measures.
In the 1993-94 Budget the Government announced details of a disability wage supplement which began on 1 July 1994.

The wage supplement seeks to promote workforce participation by people with a disability. The wage supplement is subject to essentially the same eligibility criteria as the disability support pension.

This bill proposes to exempt the wage supplement from income tax for those recipients under age pension age. The wage supplement for recipients who are above age pension age will be taxable but they will be eligible for a beneficiary rebate. The rebate will negate the tax on the wage supplement for a full-rate recipient.
Measures in the bill will also ensure that bereavement payments related to the wage supplement are given similar tax treatment to bereavement payments related to the disability support pension.
The bill also makes some minor technical amendments to the tax treatment of other social security payments.
The financial impact of these measures is not significant for 1994-95 and estimated to be less than $1 million for 1995-96.
Two measures contained in this bill relating to life insurance companies give effect to an announcement made by me on 30 June 1994.

The first measure relates to dividends payable to life insurance companies satisfied through the issue of bonus shares which form part of the assets of the insurance funds of a life insurance company. The normal situation with dividends paid to companies is that they are subject to the inter-corporate dividend rebate. Because of this, where bonus shares are issued in satisfaction of a dividend, the amount of the dividend is not treated as constituting part of the cost of the shares when calculating any profit or loss on their disposal.

With a life insurance company, however, no inter-corporate dividend rebate is available for dividends paid to its insurance funds. This results in an element of double taxation. The bill will correct this unintended result in respect of bonus shares disposed of from 1 July 1994.

The second measure concerns the rate of the inter-corporate dividend rebate allowable to a life insurance company in respect of non-insurance fund dividends included in its taxable income. These dividends are eligible for the inter-corporate dividend rebate, but the rate of rebate currently allowable is the average rate of tax paid on the total income of a life insurance company. The average rate is lower than the rate paid on non-fund dividends. The bill will ensure that, from the 1994-95 year of income, the rate of rebate equals the rate of tax actually paid.
Neither measure is expected to result in significant costs to revenue.

para.emphasis: Eligible investment income of registered organisations

speech.para: This bill will include in the assessable income of friendly societies and certain other registered organisations income derived from certain assets of the organisation. The purpose of the amendment is to ensure that the provisions of Division 8A of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 are not circumvented by the holding of assets separate from the eligible insurance business of the organisation. The amendments will apply to income derived from eligible investment assets derived or purchased on or after 1 July 1994 by a registered organisation.
It is not possible to reliably estimate the revenue impact of this measure; however, the measure has the potential to prevent a significant future loss to revenue.
The bill will also deal with three transitional tax issues that will be faced by the State Bank of NSW after it is sold to private interests and loses its tax exempt status as a public authority.

First, the bill will ensure that any gains or losses accrued in assets or liabilities of the bank at the time when it is sold, will not be taken into account in determining the bank's taxable income after it is sold. This will be achieved by treating the assets as having been sold and the liabilities met at the time of the sale and then having been bought or assumed again immediately after the sale.
Another measure will ensure that superannuation deductions are not tax deductible after the sale if they are made to satisfy a liability that accrued when the bank was exempt from tax.
The final measure will deny deductions for bad debts written off after the bank's sale to the extent that they were already considered by the bank to be doubtful debts before the sale occurred.
These measures will simply clarify the tax treatment of the State Bank of NSW in respect of the three transitional issues. They will not have any direct financial impact of their own.

para.emphasis: Cost price of natural increase of live stock

speech.para: This bill will make amendments to the income tax law to ensure that natural increase of live stock for which no minimum value is prescribed is valued at its actual cost, where taxpayers elect to value such stock at cost. I announced the proposed amendments on 30 June 1994.

The effect of the amendments is to eliminate an inappropriate deferral of tax. For classes of live stock for which no minimum value is prescribed, the existing law allows some producers to use historical costs that have become negligible compared to actual costs. This substantially defers tax, and gives these producers a corresponding advantage over competitors who must use costs at, or close to, actual costs.
The amendments will apply to natural increase occurring after 30 June 1994.
As this measure is designed to eliminate the deferral of taxation revenue, there will be an increase in revenue in the first year of income. The amount of the increase cannot be quantified.

The bill proposes an amendment to the capital gains provisions to ensure that there will be liability to capital gains tax where an asset is created and held by its creator as the trustee of a discretionary trust. An example of the created assets to which the amendment will apply is a future interest in a professional partnership.
The financial impact of this proposal is unquantifiable.

The bill will also amend the gift provisions of the income tax law to allow deductions for gifts of $2 or more made to five organisations or funds. The amendment gives effect to announcements made by the Treasurer during 1994.
The impact of the amendments on revenue is not expected to be significant.

The bill proposes to extend the present annual superannuation guarantee contribution requirement for the superannuation guarantee regime to the 1994-95 year and later years until the regime is more established. This extension was announced in the Treasurer's Superannuation Policy Statement of 28 June 1994.
There is no cost to the revenue from the change.

A further measure in the bill will ensure that panel vans and utility trucks that carry one tonne or more are treated in the same manner throughout the tax law irrespective of whether or not they are derived from passenger motor vehicles.

The bill proposes to amend the depreciation, capital gains and related miscellaneous `rollover' provisions. As a result, all of the above class of vehicles (`one tonners') will qualify for accelerated depreciation rates rather than general rates. The amendment will also achieve better consistency of language between capital gains and related `rollover' provisions.
The cost to the revenue is estimated to be $1 million in 1994-95, $2 million in 1995-96 and $3 million in 1996-97.

The bill will make a number of small amendments to the new company tax instalment arrangements contained in the income tax law. These new instalment arrangements commence for small and medium taxpayers from the 1994-95 year of income and for large taxpayers from the 1995-96 year of income.
The existing anti-avoidance provision in the law is to be replaced with three separate measures which more effectively target avoidance arrangements.
The bill also inserts a provision to allow the tax amount on which instalments are based to be varied by regulation where tax rates have changed.

The bill will also make consequential amendments to the provisions which impose penalty for late payment and interest on underpayments so that the penalty and interest calculations are made from the due date of the final instalment.
These amendments will not change the original revenue estimates for the new company tax instalment arrangements.

The bill will amend the income tax law to allow an assessment to be deemed to have been made by the Commissioner of Taxation at the time when returns are lodged by companies and by trustees of certain funds. This amendment, which applies to taxpayers under both the existing and new company tax instalment regimes, will allow those taxpayers to obtain any refund due on assessment without delay. Under present provisions, refunds can be delayed when returns are lodged early.
This amendment has a minimal effect on revenue.

para.emphasis: Passive income of controlled foreign companies

speech.para: Special rules are contained in the controlled foreign company (CFC) measures of the income tax law to provide concessional treatment to Australian taxpayers who are shareholders of offshore general insurance companies and life insurance companies which are CFCs.

The bill will amend the CFC provisions relating to general insurance companies to replace the definitions of `tainted calculated liabilities' and `calculated liabilities' with definitions that reflect the concept of `outstanding claims'—a concept used in the general insurance industry as opposed to the life insurance industry.
This measure will not involve any cost to the revenue.

Finally, the bill will amend the Taxation Administration Act 1953 to give the Commissioner of Taxation the authority to round down to the nearest multiple of five cents the final amount of a taxation liability due and payable under any act or Regulation which the Commissioner administers.
Full details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

debate.title: CORPORATIONS LAW (SECURITIES AND FUTURES) AMENDMENT BILL 1994 [1995]

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 5 December 1994, on motion by
Senator Crowley
:
That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Vanstone Sen A.E.

talk.start.para: —The Corporations Law (Securities and Futures) Amendment Bill 1994 is no doubt a bill that the government would hope is not taken as characteristic of its capacity to get a legislative program through to achieve a goal that it wants to achieve. The history of this bill is somewhat sad, to say the least.

para.tab: The bill is a result of a desire on the part of the Australian Stock Exchange to trade a new product share ratio. The ratio allows an investor to trade on the degree to which individual shares move relative to the market. A share ratio does not currently fall within the definition of a security under the Corporations Law and cannot be traded on a stock exchange.

The regulatory regimes for the trading of securities and futures have developed separately—securities under chapter 7 and futures under chapter 8 of the Corporations Law. The separation reflects the different risk profiles and investment uses of securities and futures contracts. Each chapter contains a stringent regulatory regime, including provisions relating to market operators, clearing houses, licensing of dealers and fidelity funds.

Derivatives straddle the definitional borders between securities and futures. They raise difficult questions about the appropriateness of the current regulatory regime. A share ratio may in one sense be described as a derivative; however, it clearly falls squarely within the definition of a futures contract. While the definitional distinctions mean that futures markets have greater ability to trade derivative products, the Stock Exchange argues that it should be permitted to trade the share ratio because the contracts require specialised knowledge of individual shares.

The government has accepted that the legislative framework ought to be amended to facilitate trading of the Stock Exchange's share ratio. We are in this instance not talking about the over-the-counter derivatives that are specifically structured for particular needs and negotiated privately. The government has commissioned CASAC, the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, to undertake a general review of derivative regulation. Given the size and scope of that task, it is going to take some time. Hence, we have this particular legislation trying to deal with one particular instance.

The history of this bill, as I alluded to earlier, is something of saga which began in early 1994 when the government introduced a draft omnibus Corporations Law amendment bill. When the final bill was introduced, slipped in was a provision that effectively allowed the government, by regulation, to alter the division between securities and futures contracts under the Corporations Law. Those amendments were introduced to allow the Stock Exchange to trade unnamed product.

Those changes obviously had serious implications for the wholesale regulation of futures, securities and derivative markets and were subject to industry, investor and academic criticism. This point was well made by my colleague the then shadow Attorney-General, Daryl Williams. As a result of that, the portion of the legislation dealing with share ratios was withdrawn. Subsequent to that, the Stock Exchange has provided details of its share ratio product.

An exposure package was distributed by the Attorney-General's Department. This provided a draft bill and more details of the underpinning regulatory framework. The exposure package attracted, as I understand it, a number of submissions, including a detailed and voluminous one from the Sydney Futures Exchange. The Sydney Futures Exchange was particularly concerned that, if the Stock Exchange was to be allowed to trade instruments having the risk profile of futures contracts, it was imperative that there at least be a level playing field.

What we have ended up with is a mix and match approach. Following discussions between the government and the Futures Exchange, a new version of the bill that addressed at least some of the concerns of the Sydney Futures Exchange was agreed upon. However, as a result of an administrative error—let us put it that way—the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 which was introduced was the wrong version. This is the second time the government has introduced this bill. The first time it was introduced, it was withdrawn. There was much consultation and discussion with everybody. A new bill was introduced, but all of a sudden it was the wrong bill. It is going to sit at the bottom of the
Notice Paper
until it lapses after this parliament is prorogued.

There has not been much explanation for this mistake. Frankly, there is very little difference between the bill that will sit at the bottom of the
Notice Paper
and this one, which is now the third in effect. That just highlights the difficulty in this area. The differences are so fine that someone in the minister's office apparently did not know what was going on and the wrong bill was introduced. It is not an area in which you can talk about broad-brush policy making. Quite fine, detailed work has to be undertaken in order to satisfy all parties. Some people have been so unkind, and perhaps realistic, to describe this as a fight over a patch between the Stock Exchange and the Futures Exchange. Of course, the patch is becoming varied and, understandably, we now have the problem of sorting out how to regulate it.

The bill essentially allows an agreement to be prescribed by regulation as a security or a futures contract. The regulations might apply, disapply or modify the application of the Corporations Law or relevant regulations to a prescribed agreement. The purpose is to allow the standard regime to be tinkered with to take into account special characteristics of particular instruments. That is what is planned in relation to share ratios. The proposed regulations have been drafted. They prescribe a share ratio as a security and modify the Corporations Law as it applies to such agreements.

While the intention is that the product be regulated as a security, there is this degree of mixing and matching between the securities and futures contract requirements to take into account the specific nature of this product. In addition to that, the Stock Exchange has now developed detailed business rules which are designed to supplement the regulations, and those business rules are subject to disallowance by the Attorney-General.

In short, some of our concerns have now been allayed. We now know the product that the Stock Exchange wishes to trade. This government initially slipped in some amendments at the last minute to allow this unidentified product to be traded, but we now know what that is. We now have much better details of the underpinning regulatory regime, draft regulations and the business rules. It has been made clear that these proposals do not effect the over-the-counter derivative markets.

There is some existing concern. It is strongly arguable that the changes should have been made in a fuller legislative sense until we had an overall system that everyone agreed with for handling those things that fall between the two chapters. By not waiting until that time, we end up taking this piecemeal approach by regulation. I understand that parliament still has the capacity to disallow regulations. One of the basic reasons we are supporting this is that we understand the difficulties of holding up the private sector—in this case, the Stock Exchange—from marketing a new product because we have not got our act together. But that does not detract from the fact that the way we are doing this is not ideal. It is workable and suitable, but it is not ideal. We wish to highlight that point.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny Bills stated that the predecessors to this bill really amounted to an inappropriate delegation of legislative power. That is probably still an appropriate conclusion for this bill. It is a concern expressed by a number of people. As I said, this is not an irretrievably bad way to go, but it is not the ideal way to go. Therefore, we point out that we are really only going this way because, if we do not, the government's incapacity to design a proper regulatory regime will hold up the Stock Exchange from marketing a new and innovative product.

The government has made the point that this was a one-off. But, in other speeches, we have seen that this regime could be used for other products. We just want to flag the caution that the government should take in adopting the attitude that this system could be used on a permanent basis to allow the Attorney-General to yea or nay by regulation to other products as they come up. For example, the Futures Exchange might have a product that it feels falls between the two and that it wants to have treated in this fashion in one way or another.

We emphasise that we are really looking at this as a one-off. I suppose that means that in the end the answer is no to any future ones. But it would be with huge reluctance that we would even consider looking at future changes until we hear what the CASAC inquiry has to say.

I have probably made the points that I wanted to make. No doubt it is of some embarrassment to the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) to come in here after a year of fiddling around with this bill and introducing the wrong one in the lower house. I cannot imagine what occasioned that to happen. He does not seem to indicate in the second reading speech of this bill what was wrong with the earlier one and how that mistake happened.

I have indicated in my comments that, while we do not think this is ideal, we think it is workable. We, the parliament, should not be holding up the Stock Exchange from proceeding with its product. On that basis, we do not want to prevent the bill from passing the second reading stage or, for that matter, the third reading stage, but we do wish to move a second reading amendment. I move:
At end of motion, add:

speech.para: "but the Senate criticises the Government and the Attorney-General for their handling of this bill, and in particular condemns:

para.tab: (a)the inappropriate manner of facilitating the ASX's desire to trade share ratios;
(b)the initial attempt to pass the amendments without consultation;
(c)the Government's clear inability to come to grips with the regulation of derivatives in Australia; and
(d)the Attorney-General's administrative bungling of the proposed legislation".

speech.para: We do not move that amendment just as a means of sour grapes. They are serious points that need to be made. It is a matter of some note that, when the opposition provided the Attorney-General with a series of questions on notice requesting the government's response in writing, this side of the chamber received a call from the Chairman of the Stock Exchange, who was then in Hong Kong, who was inquiring as to what we were doing. He said that we could have asked the Stock Exchange any questions that we wanted. Of course we could, but we wanted the Attorney-General's answers.

para.tab: One wonders how the Stock Exchange knew we had provided questions. I will tell you how it knew: the Attorney-General's Department, as we are advised, gave it the questions to answer. The department gave the Stock Exchange the questions either right at the beginning or to be cleared. The department is going off to the Stock Exchange to check whether it is happy with what the department is putting before parliament. Quite frankly, that does not seem an appropriate mechanism to me. I wonder whether the Sydney Futures Exchange was asked whether it would like to comment on what the answers to be put before parliament ought to be.

It is as a consequence of the government's failure to consult on the first bill, its mixing around with the second one, its inability to answer questions promptly and efficiently, its passing the questions off to the Stock Exchange and its doing this as a one-off piecemeal approach that we have moved that second reading amendment.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is debating the Corporations Law (Securities and Futures) Amendment Bill. In general, the Australian Democrats welcome this particular bill but not without some concerns which largely mirror the points of concern enunciated by Senator Vanstone on behalf of the coalition. I might say at this stage that the Democrats will be supporting the second reading amendment that Senator Vanstone has moved.

para.tab: The bill will provide a much needed regulatory framework for a rapidly developing market in hybrid financial products. Currently, the Corporations Law provides little flexibility with respect to financial products that fall outside the existing definition of securities and shares. This problem has been highlighted in particular by the Australian Stock Exchange's wish to market a new product known as share ratio contracts. Such products allow an investor to trade on the degree to which individual shares move relative to the market.

Without the amendments contained in this bill, the product would not be available to the Stock Exchange for marketing to the public. It appears more appropriate for share ratio contracts to be traded on the Australian Stock Exchange, given that they require specialised knowledge of individual shares and such expertise is more likely to be found in share broking firms rather than in their future trading counterparts. Therefore clauses 4 and 6 of the bill introduce new sections 72A and 92A into the Corporations Law to allow the addition by regulation of the type and variety of tradeable futures contracts and securities.

As I mentioned, the Democrats recognise the need for legislative change in this area but we do have a number of concerns about the amendments that are placed before the Senate. First of all, we share the concerns raised by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills that clauses 4 and 6 of the bill—those that provide for the definition of new products by regulation—may well be an inappropriate delegation of legislative power. The Attorney-General's view is that, because of the rapid development of financial products, a definition of derivatives may outlive its usefulness in a very short time and it would be impractical to introduce a legislative amendment every time a new product is about to be released. As a result, the bill is permitting prescribed agreements to be regulated as if they were securities of futures contracts. The bill, therefore, will not have the effect of altering the general understanding of what is a security or a futures contract, which was one of the concerns raised by the industry when the first bill was introduced. As I have said before, the Democrats will be supporting the bill. However, we will be monitoring this regulation making power after it becomes operational to see whether it fulfils the task that is set for it and the extent to which, if at all, it is exceeded.

Our second concern is that the bill does not attempt to regulate over-the-counter transactions. These are principally contracts concluded through private negotiations and typically involve large commercial institutions. By definition, they are not traded through the securities or futures exchanges. These, it is argued, are difficult to regulate and, in any event, do not appropriately fall within the government's regulatory sphere proposed by this bill.

The Democrats accept that it is difficult to regulate these forms of investment. However, we impress upon the government the need for the utmost vigilance in this area. Transactions of this variety are not typically conducted by small investors but by large commercial operators such as banks and merchant banks. We should take the recent collapse of Tricontinental, Rothwells and the Pyramid Building Society as proof of the fact that not all financial institutions are as careful with other people's money as they should be. Indeed, only today we have learned about the derivative induced collapse of one of England's oldest financial institutions, Barings Plc.

Finally, we impress upon the government the need to ensure that the licensing system for those dealers selling hybrid products is reviewed. The need for trustworthiness and a high level of professional competence in the brokers of financial products increases proportionately with the complexity of the product sold. The government should not wait for problems to develop before ensuring that the existing regulatory mechanisms are sufficient to deal with what would appear to be a major new investment market. Having noted these reservations, the Democrats welcome the Corporations Law (Securities and Futures) Amendment Bill 1994 and will be supporting the second reading amendment moved by Senator Vanstone.

talker.name: Senator SCHACHT
talker.role: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

talk.start.para: —I was supposed to be off duty by the time this came in.
—Give us the benefit of your listening.
—Do not encourage me, Senator O'Chee. You being a lawyer, I might make a few comments.
—Your government hates lawyers. That is the only reason you were on the committee.

—Someone had to be a voice of sanity seeing the opposition was represented only by lawyers. I would like to thank senators for their contributions. The viability and integrity of our public securities and futures markets merit the close examination by the parliament of proposals affecting these markets. I would like to recount the major criticisms of this bill and indicate the response of the government to each of them. There has been open public consultation with affected parties about the proposals, and the comments received on the bill have been carefully considered.

para.tab: The government believes that each of the criticisms of the bill has been addressed comprehensively and adequately in one way or another in the overall package implementing this proposal. The proposals will enhance, not diminish, the effectiveness of the regulatory arrangements for our securities and futures markets. A major criticism of the bill has been that it delegates to the executive too broad a power to prescribe products. It has been alleged that the bill is a backdoor way of regulating the over-the-counter derivatives market.

The power to prescribe products is quite restricted. The arrangements proposed are for the regulation of exchange traded products only and have nothing to say about the trading of over-the-counter derivatives. The amendments are not intended to anticipate or pre-empt in any way the outcome of the present inquiry by the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee into the regulation of over-the-counter derivative products. The power will only be used on those occasions when it can be demonstrated that the ordinary operation of the Corporations Law is not appropriate. For most purposes, the regulatory regimes in chapters 7 and 8 will be quite adequate.

The regulation making power will, of necessity, be limited to a narrow range of products. There are already similar powers to those proposed in the Corporations Law. Provisions such as these are needed to enable the law to be adapted to new financial products and market innovations. The exercise of the power of prescription will be subject to the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994, which is due to commence on 1 July 1995. That bill mandates consultation with persons affected by legislative instruments proposed to be made on or after 1 January 1996. Consultation is also a current prerequisite under the corporations agreement with the states.

A further criticism of the bill is that it undermines investor protection and market stability. There will be adequate and comprehensive provisions in the package implementing this proposal, the bill, the supporting regulations and the business rules of the Stock Exchange to ensure that investors are adequately protected in dealings in share ratio contracts. The bill allows the regulations to modify the law as applying to prescribed products. Specific rules to govern the trading of share ratio contracts will be set out in amendments to the corporations regulations and the ASX business rules. The regulations will ensure that all features of a strict and comprehensive regulatory framework for exchange traded products will be applicable to share ratio contracts or to any prescribed products.

There are many aspects to this, including: licensing, disclosure, the conduct of brokers, relations with clients, the operation of a national guarantee fund, clearing arrangements, insider trading, market manipulation and fraud, and auditing of brokers' accounts. The overall package for the trading of share ratio contracts addresses each of these matters in detail. The national guarantee fund will guarantee share ratio contracts traded on the Australian Stock Exchange. The business rules of the exchange will incorporate many of the detailed features that are essential for the maintenance of a fair and orderly market and for investor protection. The rules have been subjected to careful scrutiny by the Australian Securities Commission to ensure they are both comprehensive and appropriate for the products to be regulated. They are subject to review and possible disallowance by the Attorney-General.

Another criticism of this bill is that the national guarantee fund will be exposed to significant additional risks as a result of exposure to speculative futures contracts. Careful attention has been paid to this matter. The NGF will not be exposed to any undue risk as a result of its coverage of trading and share ratio contracts. An independent actuarial analysis of the potential exposure of the NGF to trading and share ratio contracts has been undertaken. The analysis concluded that `the introduction of share ratio contracts would not lead to a serious undermining of the financial resources of the NGF.' The risk posed to the NGF will be no greater than that posed by other derivative products traded by the Stock Exchange as those traded on the Stock Exchange options market. Before prescribing any other product under the proposed provisions, the government would seek the advice of the ASC and the Securities Exchange Guarantee Corporation which administers the NGF on issues such as adequacy and coverage of the NGF.

The distinction between the securities and the future contracts is another point that has been raised. It is alleged that these amendments will blur the distinction between securities and futures products. The distinction between futures or risk management products and securities will remain a basic feature of the law. However, market changes and product developments are blurring the distinction between securities and futures. The critical point is to ensure that, whatever products are traded on public exchanges in Australia, the most appropriate regulatory arrangements apply to them.

In conclusion, I reiterate that the amendments are necessary because they add an essential element of flexibility to the regulatory framework. Governments must be able to respond to requests by public exchanges to trade new products. The regulatory regime should not hinder market development and product innovation. The content of any regulatory regime that will apply to any prescribed products will be determined by the primary regulatory consideration of ensuring the conduct of fair, orderly and efficient markets and investor protection. The government does not support the second reading amendment moved by Senator Vanstone. It seems to me from my brief knowledge of her description that this was a matter of pro forma on her part, that the opposition has to go through the process of moving a second reading amendment that criticises the government because, if it did not, it might be reported that it was not doing its job as an opposition. I note that the Democrats are supporting the amendment. I suspect that the Democrats are building up a statistical count from time to time on how many times they vote with us and how many times they vote with the opposition. I am not cynical about these matters; it is a statement of fact. Anyway, I can assure Senator Vanstone that we do not support the second reading amendment.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

debate.sub1.title: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

para.tab: Consideration resumed from 1 February of House of Representatives message.

interject.speaker: The CHAIRMAN

talk.start.para: —The committee is considering message No. 350 from the House of Representatives, relating to the International War Crimes Tribunal Bill 1994, and message No. 351 from the House of Representatives, relating to the International War Crimes Tribunal (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1994. When the committee last met, it was considering message No. 350 from the House of Representatives, relating to the International War Crimes Tribunal Bill 1994, and the following motion moved by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs:

para.tab: That the committee—

interject.para: (1)agrees to the amendments 1-23 and 25-27 made by the House of Representatives
(2)disagrees to amendment 24 and makes an amendment in place thereof
The first two questions having been agreed to, the question now is that the further amendments moved by the government be agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I do not want to take up the time of the Senate this afternoon with respect to this matter. We support the bill and the subsequent amendments the government wants to make, but it is worth putting a couple of things on the record. The principal bill was introduced in the Senate. Upon introduction in the House it was referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. That committee is slowly but surely developing some skills at reviewing legislation, taking on a job for which it is elected. The committee made a number of recommendations, most of which were accepted by the government. Amendments were moved and passed in the House. The House amendments were due to be considered by the Senate the last time this matter came forward. The day before, the government advised that it intended to introduce further amendments to extend the application of the bill to the Rwanda Tribunal. Given the short notice and the desire to have the extended application of the bill considered by, for example, on this side the shadow ministry and party room, a motion was moved that consideration be postponed. That motion was passed—not, I might say, with the government's support. As I recall, we had to have a division in order to agree that we be given time to consider amendments of which we had been notified the day before.

para.tab: It is interesting to note that, in order to move the new raft of amendments, the government was required to move to suspend the standing order that prohibits amendments to a bill returned to the Senate and considered by the House unless the amendments relate to the House amendments. The procedure to suspend the standing order was used probably for the first time in the history of Senate. So it was quite exceptional. I do not think this side of the chamber feels they were given adequate notice of that exceptional procedure being undertaken—perhaps that standing orders would be suspended to do something, but inadequate notice of the historical nature of what was happening.

I have since had time to consult with my party, and we support the changes that the government seeks to make. However many people there might be in detention in Rwanda charged effectively with war crimes, as I understand it there is no proper judicial system under which they can be tried. To release the accused would then subject them to revenge attacks. The establishment of an international tribunal was seen as an appropriate solution. The amendment is very unlikely to have any practical impact for Australia. While there is the possibility that war criminals from the former Yugoslavia will have made their way to Australia, that is much less likely in relation to Rwanda. The amendment, by applying the procedures of the principal bill to the Rwandan situation, provides a simple means by which Australia's international obligations are fulfilled and provides a gesture of support to the tribunal. The coalition does not oppose the amendments.

speech.speaker: Spindler Sen S.E.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats put on record our support for this bill when it was last before the Senate. Senator Vanstone drew attention to the amendments which the government moved in the chamber after the bill had been dealt with by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I think it is worth noting that the House of Representatives standing committee recommendations in large measure accepted amendments which I had previously moved in the Senate and which had been rejected by both the government and the coalition at that time. When I gave them as recommendations to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, that committee saw fit to adopt a significant number of those recommendations which ultimately found their way into government amendments which the Senate is now accepting.

para.tab: As far as the government amendments are concerned, which were sprung on the Senate during the last session, the Democrats at that time were prepared to proceed because we saw the wisdom of including Rwanda in these particular provisions. That has not changed and the Democrats will be supporting the bill, including the amendments.

speech.speaker: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

talk.start.para: —We are addressing the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994. This is an important piece of legislation where basically all parties have agreed. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) in his second reading speech makes the commitment that this is a piece of legislation to recognise those rights that relate to the Hodgson Downs land claim in the Northern Territory and that agreement has basically been reached between the Commonwealth government, the Northern Territory government, the Northern Land Council and the claimants in the land claim, and that they have entered into an agreement which settles that claim. This is an important piece of legislation for what it sets out to do.

para.tab: I would like to take the time and the opportunity in the Senate today to refer to this piece of legislation. Hodgson Downs is a pastoral property some 40 kilometres south of the Roper Highway and approximately 200 kilometres south-east of Katherine in the Northern Territory. There is a population resident there of about 200 people, Aboriginal people primarily from the Alawa tribe, but also some Ngalakan people. Recently, the purchase of Hodgson Downs station by ATSIC was made on behalf of the Miniyeri community in the Northern Territory. This piece of legislation will recognise those important aspects.

The other issue I have raised with regard to Hodgson Downs that I think is important is that it is a community where there is a CDEP program administered by ATSIC. In fact, the only criticism I have heard in recent times is that it is an area where ATSIC needs to carefully review that aspect of the administration and the importance of the CDEP program to ensure its ongoing area is free of other problems in the financial administration, and that the administrator look very carefully at those issues as to how the CDEP program is being properly administered in that area.

This debate gives me the opportunity to also look very carefully at the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. That act, instituted in 1976, is a complex piece of federal legislation which relates to only the Northern Territory, as its title would have us know. With nearly two decades of the operation of that act behind us, the legislation continues to have considerable impact on the people and the land of the Northern Territory. Given this impact, the complexity of the act and the many contentious legal interpretations, there have been justified calls for regular, formal reviews of the operation of this particular legislation.

That is what I want to concentrate on today. Whilst this particular bill sets out to put in place a particular provision for a particular property and particular people, it is important to recognise that there have been many requests for reviews and alterations to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act itself. For example, I know that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Marshall Perron, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 1 February 1994.

In that particular correspondence to the Prime Minister he canvassed a whole range of issues relating to the administration of the land rights act. The issues that Mr Perron raised with Mr Keating were that there should be an indication of matters that should be discussed further. They included the application of territory laws on Aboriginal inalienable freehold; the continuing conversion of pastoral leases to Aboriginal land and the implications of provisions of the Native Title Act; the need for the territory government to have compulsory acquisition power to acquire land for essential public purposes; confirmation of the crown's ownership of minerals and resources and the right of access to those resources; just terms compensation for the acquisition of crown land from the territory by the Commonwealth and for the loss of rents otherwise payable to the territory; and compensation for the loss of revenue to the territory resulting from the exercise of the veto.

Each and every one of these issues are complex and certainly demand the attention of government; and it disappoints me that, given the length of time that the Commonwealth government has had notice of these particular areas and provisions—and some of them were addressed several years ago by the Industry Commission in a major report that particularly highlighted the areas that would impact on mining provision and the provision of benefits that would flow through to Aboriginal people—the government has not addressed any of these issues which have been on notice for some time.

In more recent times we have seen the relevance of commercial activities, home ownership by and for Aboriginal people, and fishing issues such as commercial fishing which allows continuing and existing licences but restricts the issue of new licences and also commercial fishing operations that have to notify the Northern Land Council of their impending interests. These issues, coupled with those where coastal licensees are severely restricted in where they can sell fishing catches et cetera, are further issues that do need to be addressed. Unfortunately, these have been ignored by the federal government. And here we have a piece of legislation that the government should have looked at and ought to have added those specific provisions to.

By contrast, the relatively new Native Title Act 1993, which impacts on the Northern Territory and the rest of Australia, is already under fire, sparking calls for review. Earlier in February and following rejection of the Waanyi claim in north-west Queensland, one of the architects of the native title legislation said it was time to revisit the act. Let me quote the director of the Northern Land Council, Mr Darryl Pearce, who told ABC radio only several weeks ago on 16 February:

speech.para: I think that there will always be an unforseen consequence in any piece of legislation that has been both beneficial and detrimental and part of that process is to have a look at it and find out where it's been working and leave that bit alone, and where it hasn't been working, (and) to revisit that.

Mr Pearce's words are intriguing in light of the legal battles under way between the traditional owners and the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council. Under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, the land councils are supposed to represent traditional owners but we now have two cases where the owners allege that their rights have been usurped. One is at Jabiru and involves the Gagadju Association and the other is the Central Land Council administration of Alcoota Station in central Australia. In the case of the Northern Land Council, the Gagadju Association, which represents the traditional owners of the uranium rich Ranger area, has taken its concerns all the way to the Federal Court. I believe it was last week that there was media comment with regard to that particular action.

para.tab:
The Gagadju Association alleges that, firstly, the Northern Land Council did not have the consent of the traditional owners to negotiate a royalty agreement with Energy Resources of Australia Ltd, known as ERA, over the Ranger uranium mine and, secondly, the NLC refuses to pay Gagadju proper royalty entitlements. Lawyers representing the Gagadju Association recently wrote to me outlining their case against the Northern Land Council and expressed concern about the operation and the adequacy of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate in
Hansard
the letter from the lawyers acting for the Gagadju Association.
Leave granted.

The provision of community vehicles and vehicles for members of the Association, provision of helicopters for use during the wet season when outstations are inaccessible by road;

(4)
Employment:
The provision of employment opportunities for all members of the Association and training of such members for the development of their skills in such areas as the hospitality industry and trades;

speech.para: In addition to the foregoing, Gagudju has purchased and conducts a Mobil service station, the profits of which are used for the benefit of its members, and a screen printing business, which is conducted for the same purpose. Gagudju also conducts the Crocodile Hotel Resort as well as other tourist facilities.

On our instructions Gagudju is heavily reliant upon the receipt of the royalty payments arising out of mining on the Ranger land. Without those funds the operations of Gagudju will be severely prejudiced.

Furthermore, unless Gagudju receives from the NLC the royalty moneys due to have been paid for the 6 months ending February 1995 (approximately $600,000.00) then all services currently provided may have to be suspended indefinitely. Put simply, this will have catastrophic effects.

Our client has serious concerns and reservations about the representative capacity of the NLC in dealing with the affairs, concerns and welfare of Aboriginal people. In particular, the NLC's behaviour, the subject of the current litigation has the accumulated effect of:-

para.tab: (a)Promoting and enlarging social disharmony and instability amongst key traditional owners and decision makers in the Kakadu region;
(b)Escalating the economic depression and substandard of living of the members of Gagudju;
(c)Derogating the process of consultation with Aboriginal persons (concerning issues relevant to their lands);
(d)Quashing the autonomy of the Gagudju Association in dealing with matters of traditional concern in the Kakadu region;
(e)Restricting the successful and controlled progression of self awareness and self determination of the Gagudju members.

speech.para: On our understanding, the Aboriginal Land Rights Act (Northern Territory) 1976, was intended to be sufficiently flexible to allow for the changing ideas and changing needs amongst Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory.

His Honour Mr Justice Woodward (2nd report 1974) suggested a formal review of the legislation by the Government after 3 years and thereafter at seven year intervals from the commencement of operation of the Act. To our knowledge the last formal review of the legislation and its practicality/effectiveness took place in 1983 ("7 Years On") by Mr Justice Toohey.

It is our client's opinion that the dispute which exists between Gagudju and the NLC is indicative of the general dissatisfaction of Aboriginal persons in the Northern Territory towards the management, representative capacity and perception of the NLC. The dispute also highlights the various inadequacies of the Act to accommodate the self determinative attitudes of the members of Gagudju (and other Aboriginal persons) generally.

Accordingly we are instructed to request and urge you to raise before the Senate, the neglect or absence of any formal review of the operation and adequacy of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 having been undertaken since 1983 and the imminent concern and needs of the persons mentioned earlier in this correspondence.
Your urgent actions and response will be most appreciated.
Your faithfully
BARWICKS
