talk.start.para:
—I thank the Senate. I would like to quote from the latest edition of
Australian Business Monthly
. The cover story this month—and I am sure members and senators may well have seen this—headed `Black Money' involves a very comprehensive study by
Australia Business Monthly
and by the author, Trevor Sykes, and results in a 25-page article. I think that is almost unprecedented in any consideration by
Australian Business Monthly
which looks very much at this area where very obviously Minister Tickner has totally failed Aboriginal people and, in turn, the Labor government in the last decade has not properly addressed this issue. That cover story describes land councils as `political and financial power centres which can dispense or withhold patronage'. Further, in a comparison with ATSIC, the article states:

speech.para: The land councils do not have the same democratic basis and show signs, particularly in NSW and the NT, that they are developing political agendas of their own which do not necessarily represent the wishes of traditional Aboriginal owners.

Over the past two decades, Aboriginal people have become much more sophisticated in their dealings with politicians and the bureaucracy. Unfortunately, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act has failed to keep pace with this growing sophistication, not to mention the changing needs and aspirations of Aboriginal people. That is why I specifically mentioned the issues that need to be properly addressed and properly amended by this parliament. Mr Perron, in that letter to the Prime Minister dated 1 February 1994, certainly set out a series of major points that need to be addressed. They are the self same issues that many Aboriginal leaders and Aboriginal people are also asking to be reconsidered and revisited by this parliament.

para.tab: For what reason does the Labor Party withhold? Certainly we support the legislation that is before us today. It is one small technical matter that has been resolved. But, unfortunately, the issues on the hard agenda—the more difficult and specific areas that Aboriginal people, Northern Territorians and the wider Australian community are asking to be addressed—are not being properly attended to.

Surely, if it is now time to review the Native Title Act—and we are all well aware that the national pressures are building on that: whether it is Mr Justice French making a statement, whether it is AMIC representing the mining interests, whether it is the various interested Aboriginal organisations that have made submissions to committees of this Senate in the last two months with regard to the indigenous land fund legislation or whether it is with regard to other issues impacting on the Native Title Act—it is going to be a very strange and severe test of this Labor government as to whether it is also going to be prepared to put on the table a right and proper way of addressing those very specific issues that are coming out of 20 years of operation of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act specifically in the Northern Territory.

I said it would be a strange matter for the Labor government to look at. If it is not prepared to address those issues which have been specifically raised by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Perron, the director of the Northern Land Council, Mr Pearce, or other people in the last five, six or seven years that I have been in this Senate, we will only get a piece of legislation like this, not one that goes to the basis and the very fundamentals. Unless we make it more relevant for Aboriginal territorians, we will have some complications that we will have to look at as Australia approaches the next century.

It will also be a test of the bona fides of the Labor Party that it will look at these areas. We are well aware that the issues that need focused and concentrated attack and attention by government are to do with Aboriginal programs that particularly affect areas such as housing—the appropriateness of housing design, which is so fundamental to Aboriginal health and hygiene and, in fact, the survival of Aboriginal people in many areas. Many Aboriginal leaders are not happy with the administrative system that exists within their relationship with the Labor government, within ATSIC or within the various other areas, and we really have to revisit many of these issues.

It is important that we pass the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2) today. I acknowledge that. It is also important that we look at the complexity of the issues that must be addressed. For too long, the Left faction within the Labor Party has been focused on Aboriginal issues. It has been a matter of the ALP Left, with its historic socialism agenda, driving the issue in Aboriginal affairs of control, power and, in some areas, what I would describe as greed and nepotism. The shandying of funding and the way in which it has been manipulated in many Aboriginal areas is not in the best interests of Aboriginal people.

The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act gives us the opportunity to focus on the funding that comes from the taxpayer through Commonwealth and state administration. This act also enables us to look at the administration of royalties and how they flow through the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account and the land councils, all of which have been subjected to severe audits in the last few years. It also gives us a right to look at the commercial activities.

Very often when we get corporate networks that are complex—and we now have this funding from government departments and local government, from ATSIC and land councils, from Aboriginal corporations and associations incorporated nationally, from companies that are properly recognised under the Australian Securities Commission and from a more complex area in the area of trusts—we need to focus on the issues of conflicts of interest and purpose, the lack of accountability and disclosure and, very often, the poor prudential care and understanding of fiduciary duty by the management of trustees. People acting for Aboriginal people and Aboriginal people themselves need to look at those areas of responsibility and the principles of preserving the property and asset base of Aboriginal people and not go on being subjected to such high risk and hazards.

The implications of this bill and what is not being done to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act have severe consequences for native title and the indigenous land fund legislation. We must concentrate on audit and accountability. We must, in all instances, also highlight—as did Mr Sykes in the
Australian Business Monthly
—the success stories in Aboriginal communities. I sincerely trust that this legislation will enable Hodgson Downs to be a success story in Aboriginal affairs.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen C.V.

talk.start.para: —I wish to address a few short remarks to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994. In doing so, I do not intend to address the issues raised by the previous speaker—perhaps we will save that for another day. This bill seeks to grant to an Aboriginal land trust freehold title to Hodgson Downs cattle station, a pastoral lease owned by Aboriginal interests. This amending bill—which has had the support of the Northern Territory government, for which it is to be commended—will make possible that purchase and so pass the ownership of the freehold title to the Aboriginal community who have lived on this property for many years, who have sacred sites there and who have close links to that land.

para.tab: It is interesting to note that the land was purchased by ATSIC in 1991. In many ways, the current bill and this purchase have interesting ramifications for the debate we have been having about the land fund bill, because the land was purchased in 1991 on behalf of the community using current ATSIC funds but will now become freehold. It is, in a sense, a model of how the government envisages the land fund operating.

I am pleased to see that we have support for that model, which it places the ownership of the land in a land trust on behalf of the Aboriginal people and will allow them to strengthen their legal ties to the land for which they have had traditional and longstanding ties. I think all members of parliament will be pleased to see this legislation passed. It is consistent with the overall approach of the government, which is to try to help Aboriginal people re-establish their link with the land, wherever that is possible.

Some senators opposite have today drawn attention to the recent Australian Bureau of Statistics survey which highlighted some of the very serious problems confronting Aboriginal people in our society. One of the things that survey highlighted was the continuing identification with the land held by Aboriginal people. The national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander survey found that 75 per cent of those surveyed continued to identify with their home land, while only 30 per cent of those surveyed still lived there. So there was a continuing identification with traditional land, an ongoing affinity with the land and a desire by many Aboriginal people to strengthen their links with that traditional land.

The response by the government in this instance is part of that response to the need and desire in Aboriginal people. I think it has been recognised by a range of inquiries—such as the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody—that dispossession of land has made an enormous contribution to the degradation of the Aboriginal population and that their association with the land and the link to their culture and way of life is very important to the health, dignity and self-respect of the Aboriginal people.

This bill is one element in the overall strategy that the government has adopted. Another element of that, of course, is the native title legislation, which the previous speaker referred to. It is obviously too early to make any assessment of that legislation, but I think it is clear that that legislation will not result in large amounts of land being transferred, through the granting of native title, to Aboriginal ownership. I think there will be significant successes, but this can only be seen as part of the policy response.

Another aspect of the government's approach is, of course, the Land Fund Bill. It is a shame that that bill has met with such resistance and opposition in this place, but I am hopeful that it will be able to be put in place very shortly. That legislation will contribute to a strategy of helping to assist Aboriginal people build and rebuild their connection with the land. In addition to native title legislation and the Land Fund Bill, we will have to look at other innovative ways of ensuring that Aboriginal people gain access and connection to their land. This bill represents one way that can be achieved, but it is a situation peculiar to the Northern Territory.

In speaking today, I want to deal with an issue that continually crops up in this debate; it continually crops up in my own state in relation to Aboriginal persons buying cattle stations. We get an economic argument from certain groups who oppose Aboriginal communities buying cattle stations. In speeches made in the debate on the Land Fund Bill we have heard the opposition that there is to such measures which allow Aboriginal people to buy land and run commercial enterprises.

I think it reflects a difficulty we have that, whenever we confront other economic interests in debating the provision of facilities and land for Aboriginal people, the debate changes. We really have to come to grips with that: people cannot mouth rhetoric and platitudes if, whenever it comes to the question of conflict of economic interest, they want to walk away from the argument. That is something we are facing in Western Australia, in particular. Some of the opposition coming from the Pastoralists and Graziers Association in that state has, I think, been quite unhelpful. On a wider front, obviously the whole attitude of the Western Australian state government in its attempt to abolish native title in that state has been a demonstration of the WA Liberal Party's position in representing economic interests, at least in relation to these issues.

I wish to tackle, briefly, the issue that is raised constantly in relation to the granting of land to Aboriginal people; that is, that it somehow discourages mining, will result in a lack of investment in Australia and is to the detriment of other Australian people because of the economic impact of such decisions. Recently, material was distributed by the Australian Mining Industry Council regarding its recent surveying of investor attitudes. While that material was interesting, I was more interested to see a world risk survey, published in
Australia's Mining Monthly
in February 1995; this surveys risk which is associated with the international mining industry and compares the world's 15 major mining countries.

The important thing to note is that that survey revealed that Australia was the least riskiest place in the world to undertake business in relation to mining investment. This annual world risk survey is not some left wing survey but is, in fact, a survey commissioned by
Australia's Mining Monthly
. It makes the point very clearly that, in terms of the mining industry, Australia is the least riskiest country in the world in which to invest.

As to our rating, on a scale which gives marks for various risk categories, Australia has a weighted average of 11.6—and the lower the figure, the less the risk. That compares with Canada at 12.7, South Africa at 16.4 and Papua New Guinea at the top of the scale at 20.4. But Australia is by far the least riskiest country in which to invest. Quoting briefly from the article in
Australia's Mining Monthly
, it states:

speech.para: This latest survey does pour some cold water on the negative views expressed by a number of outspoken critics of Australian government policy. When measured as an overall ranking and not based solely on geological prospectivity, Australia is shown to be an excellent place in which to do business.
Later, the article continues:
. . . the results from this latest World Risk Survey show that Australia might be talking itself down.

That is a real danger we run in this debate about making land available to Aboriginal people. It suits some people to talk up the risks to the mining industry, and it suits some people to put that sort of argument into the bargaining process to try to resist measures that go to empowering Aboriginal people and giving them access to the land from which they have been dispossessed. I think this world risk survey is very useful in putting paid to the sorts of arguments that are run about those issues.

para.tab: I hasten to add that, obviously, it will be an ongoing battle. I notice, Senator Panizza, that the President of the Liberal Party's Kalgoorlie South Division, when appearing before the Land Fund Bill committee, claimed that dispossession of Aboriginal people in Australia was not a problem because, unless any of them were over 200 years of age, none of them had been dispossessed, and so really there was not an issue about Aboriginal dispossession in Australia. Those are the sorts of attitudes that are rife in the Australian community and which have to be countered. Surveys such as this world risk survey help to put paid to some of the arguments about the economic risks of doing the right thing by attempting to allow Aboriginal people to reclaim their connection with as much land as is possible. I commend this bill to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —I was leading up to talking about what is politically correct or incorrect in terms of support for Aboriginal people. This government has focused so exclusively on land rights that it has denied that other issues are basic to the wellbeing of Aboriginal people. Senator Collins may not like my focusing on where the government has failed in those areas, but I intend to do so. Aboriginal land rights are not granting people good health. For example, they are not doing something about the problem of grog and drug abuse and the domestic violence that flows from it.

para.tab: I have been to communities where a shelter was not enough, where a fence around the shelter was not enough and where barbed wire on the top of the fence around the shelter was not enough. They still needed older women present all night in those communities in order to try to do something about the domestic violence flowing from grog. The government continues to fail to acknowledge that problem. It is politically incorrect to do so.

Former Senator Richardson made a much publicised visit to the Northern Territory. The people from Karpoo in Alice Springs established an alcohol and drug rehabilitation service based on the Canadian Indian program. They got their fares to Canada by holding a chook raffle. They really proved their determination to do something for their people by the sweat of their brow. When they came to Canberra, Senator Richardson, the then minister for health, was not able to spend five minutes of his time seeing them. So much for this government's concern about Aboriginal health.

Alcohol and drug abuse is a critically important issue in Aboriginal health as it leads to many other problems such as diabetes, domestic violence, the failure of babies to thrive and maternal death in very young mothers. All these things can flow from that one subject, which seems to be taboo for this government to talk about. It seems to me to be politically incorrect to talk about drug abuse being a priority. It also seems to be politically incorrect to acknowledge the fact that over the last few years government action has made many Aboriginal people in these communities totally dependent upon government. Grog is again involved in this. If people do not stay in their community, they cannot get the dole. If they cannot get the dole, they cannot get grog. The men do not take their boys out bush to teach them bushcraft.

talk.start.para: —What rubbish!
—Senator Collins should tell that to the women in the communities I have talked to. Perhaps he does not do much women's talk.
—What is your solution?
—I am telling Senator Collins that there is no focus by this government on the basic issue that is affecting their health and the survival of their culture.
—Tell me what you would do about grog abuse; I am open to suggestions.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)
—Order! Senator Collins, continuous interjection is disorderly if it is, in particular, distracting a senator from the structure of their speech to a bill. Whilst from time to time senators welcome interjection, continuous interjections are disorderly. I ask you to not continue interjecting. I call Senator Newman to continue her speech.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will tell the minister what I would do. I would have supported the first conference of indigenous people on alcohol and drug abuse and rehabilitation that was held in Cairns last year. This government could not even spare anybody to represent it. It could not help the funding of that conference; it was prepared to ignore it altogether. Once again, it is an indication that the government seems to want to put this on the backburner.

para.tab: With the combination, which I just tried to describe, of the presence of the dole, too many people who cannot get employment and grog abuse, we have a system where adults living in communities around Australia have become dependent upon government. They want the government to do things that they could do for themselves.

It is desperately sad to see Aboriginal mothers and fathers watching their children play in sewage. I have been to Soweto. I have seen people living in abject poverty keep their homes swept and clean, and focus on the health and hygiene of their children. It is a natural instinct in any parent in any country in the world to do so. Yet grog has so debilitated some Aboriginal families that the parents sit by and watch their children play in this way. Their mothers do not retrain them and their fathers do not get out a spade. I am not being critical of Aboriginal people; I am being critical of the lack of focus on the canker that is ruining the Aboriginal race. I am sure that if Fred Hollow were here today he would be telling the government the same thing. The government did not like to hear what he had to say.

talk.start.para: —Don't be provocative, Senator, or I will interject.

—So much for his interjections. I wish that we could acknowledge the real facts so that we can set what we really have to do. Until we acknowledge the truth of these facts, we will not get on top of the issues that we as a nation need to get on top of if we are going to help Aboriginal people.

para.tab: I would like to air one more matter. I recently read of a health worker who was speaking about mothers giving Sunshine milk to their babies. It is an adult formula that is totally unsatisfactory for babies. She wanted the government to provide baby milk formula. There are health departments in the territories, states and the Commonwealth. How can it possibly be that in this day and age we are not focusing on the health needs of those babies by encouraging mothers to breastfeed? We know much about the good quality of breast milk and the protection of babies from a hygiene point of view by breastfeeding. To not encourage these women who are living in difficult, dusty and remote areas to breastfeed their babies seems to be a dereliction of duty. To be talking about formula as an alternative to Sunshine milk seems to me to have missed the plot.
These babies are not thriving. Any paediatrician working in this area will say that we

speech.para: should be ashamed of the health status of the Aboriginal babies of our land. One critical building block is good nutrition for their mothers in pregnancy. That is not happening, again frequently because of the intake of grog and because they are not feeding their babies properly in their infancy.

para.tab: Although Senator Collins wanted to be argumentative about this issue, I plead with the government to put some of these basic things in place. These are priority issues. That does not mean to say that the issue of land rights is not important but, by focusing entirely on land rights, we are destining the current generation and at least the next generation to ill health and early death. Aboriginal women in this country I think have a particularly difficult life. I want to see that life improved for them and for their children. I am disappointed that Senator Collins could not see how vitally important some of these things are that I have talked about today in trying to improve the lot of our people.

talk.start.para: —I do not think I need to do much more at this stage than note that there is support for the legislation and thank the Senate for that support.
