debate.title: WEAPONS OF MASS DESTRUCTION (PREVENTION OF PROLIFERATION) BILL 1994 [1995]

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 9 November 1994, on motion by
Senator Faulkner
:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I speak on behalf of the coalition with regard to the Weapons of Mass Destruction (Prevention of Proliferation) Bill 1994, which is now before us and which the government introduced. `Weapons of mass destruction' is a term used to describe nuclear, biological and chemical weapons which are capable of resulting in mass destruction of the population. Not one member of the Australian parliament or, I believe, any responsible member of the whole population of Australia would be irresponsible about such matters.

para.tab: Accordingly, it is appropriate for the government of the day to enter into international treaties in order to prevent the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Successive Australian governments, both Liberal and Labor, have entered into international treaties and, in a record that is bipartisan, have gone from there to passing appropriate legislation in the parliament that has the full consent of the Senate and House of Representatives to back up the treaties and to ensure that we have followed up with action our commitment in words.

Australia is party to three international treaties concerned with the control and reduction of weapons of mass destruction. The first is the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, ratified by Australia on 23 January 1973, which is substantially implemented by the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987. The second is the Convention on the Prohibition of the Development, Production and Stockpiling of Bacteriological (Biological) and Toxin Weapons and on their Destruction, ratified by Australia on 5 October 1977, which is substantially implemented by the Crimes (Biological Weapons) Act 1976.

The third is the Convention on the Prohibition of the Development, Production, Stockpiling and use of Chemical Weapons and on their Destruction. I observe that Australia was at the forefront of international measures that were taken to achieve that convention and that the government had the full support of the opposition in that endeavour. It was ratified by Australia on 6 May last year but has not yet come into force internationally. Action will need to be taken by a number of other nations before that is the case. With regard to Australia, it will be substantially implemented by the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994, which will come into force on a date to be proclaimed—that is, upon the convention coming into force internationally.

In addition to these three international treaties and their associated Commonwealth legislation, which place limits on the use and transfer of chemical, nuclear and bacteriological material, Australia has been involved in four international groups which aim to control the international transfer of such materials. Many senators will be aware of these four important international groups in which Australia plays a very responsible and sometimes leading role. The first is the Zangger Committee, which was formed in the early 1970s by countries who are suppliers of nuclear materials with the aim of developing controls on the export of equipment for use in the production of special fissionable material. It has developed a list of equipment, the export of which should be subject to safeguards.

Secondly, there is the Nuclear Suppliers Group, formed in 1974, which has developed guidelines for the export of nuclear-related equipment and technology which is aimed at preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons. Thirdly, there is the missile technology control regime, established in 1987, whereby a group of countries have agreed to a basic set of guidelines on the export of missile technology to be incorporated in national export regulations. Fourthly, there is the so-called `Australia Group', which was established in 1987 to facilitate the establishment of the chemical weapons treaty and to deal with the export of material for the making of chemical weapons until such a treaty comes into force. The group has developed a list of chemicals which require export controls.

In order to meet our own international obligations imposed by the treaties to which I have referred and the undertakings of international groups, Australia has enacted legislation. In addition, there are export controls through the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations under the Customs Act 1901.

With this range of legislation in place, it is the case, however, that not all common commercial exports are fully covered by the legislative measures that I have outlined. It is practical to therefore consider legislation of the kind that we now have in front of us. It fills a gap. It means that common commercial exports which have legitimate usage in other countries—that is, they can be properly exported to those other countries but may also assist in the construction of weapons of mass destruction—can be identified either by the supplier or by the minister responsible and, with such a self-awareness on behalf of the exporter or a government publicised awareness, become subject to this legislation and so prevented from export from this country.

This would cover not only goods to be exported but also services and contracts. It covers not only the Australian states but also all of the territories. It not only applies to acts or omissions by persons in Australia but also applies to acts or omissions done outside of Australia by Australian citizens, by people who ordinarily reside in Australia and by bodies incorporated in Australia. Wherever there is a reasonable reach of Australian responsibility, this legislation reaches to prevent any proliferation of weapons of mass destruction by any action of an Australian who would supply substances, services or contracts that would have any such misuse.

The legislation sets out in clause 7 a constitutional basis for the bill. I refer senators to look that up in the legislation that is circulated. I go on to talk about clause 9, which sets out the prohibition on the provision or export of goods or services. It requires a person to believe or suspect on reasonable grounds that the goods may be used in a program for the development, production, acquisition or stockpiling of weapons of mass destruction. A person knowing that that is the outcome of the export would be, by this legislation, liable to an offence punishable by imprisonment for a maximum of eight years.

The person is not guilty of an offence if the supply of goods is authorised by a permit granted under clause 13 or the minister has issued a person with a written notice under clause 12 stating that the minister does not believe or suspect that the goods may be used in a weapons of mass destruction program. As I have said, clause 10 relates to the export of goods. Clause 11 relates to the provision of services. Clause 4 also includes contracts for the performance of work.

I notice that the structure of this bill, in closing this gap and living up to Australia's responsibilities to ensure that we have a comprehensive enactment of laws to back up the international treaties that we have entered into, is placing a responsibility upon commercial exporters. On behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I must note that this is a new responsibility punishable by a very major sentence—indeed, for companies, it is five times the fine that would be imposed upon an individual—and that this extra responsibility upon individuals to inform themselves in the commercial world is one which we ought not to take lightly. The coalition, however, believes it to be reasonable that we have such a requirement upon those who will enter into the export of substances, services or contracts to so inform themselves. In any event, where there is a doubt there is the ability to seek a permit from the minister or to be fully informed by the minister—that is, the minister's department acting under instructions from the minister.

We notice that there is a reasonable provision for people who come under the ambit of this legislation in or out of Australia to inform themselves of the likely end use of certain exports. It has been very much the case, even in the years before the Gulf War, that exporters of chemicals in Australia have been very aware that certain chemicals exported to Iraq could well have been diverted from a commercial purpose—even a stated Iraqi commercial purpose—to use in the making of a weapon of mass destruction.

We know that chemical weapons were used in the Iraq-Iran war; that chemical weapons were used by the Iraq government even against Iraqi citizens, especially in the south, and amongst the Kurds in the north; and that it would have been highly irresponsible, even without this legislation in place and without the international treaty that it implements, for an Australian to have exported chemicals that could have been used by the Iraqi government in those programs. This legislation makes the example that I have just outlined actual, explicit and prohibited with regard to any Australian action.

Not only are we in Australia seeking to put ourselves in good order to credibly back up treaties that we have entered into as a nation but to some extent, without putting ourselves forward as a major exemplar, we are also putting ourselves in line as another example of good practice that other countries can reasonably be asked to follow. If all countries had legislation of this kind, it would be a safer world.

I anticipate that some senators will want to strengthen this legislation and will say that the Liberal and National parties, in agreeing with the principles of the government's legislation, have left even now a loophole for the exporting of goods, services or contracts that could be used for such programs. I am not convinced of that position, but I will listen most carefully to Independent and Democrat senators to hear the case that they may put. I ask that it not be mere alarm that is put forward but, as we would expect, reasonable, argued and specific arguments put if there are inadequacies in the legislation in front of us. I would think that all senators from all parts of this chamber would accept the principle, if not the legislation, that we would now put in place by adopting this bill and that we would want other countries to go at least as far as Australia has in this matter.

I conclude by reiterating that the coalition notes that this legislation will impose an additional burden on companies to become aware of the ultimate use of goods or services that they might provide or export. Although the criminal provisions require a level of intent of belief or suspicion, a jury could attribute suspicion to a company if it held or had access to information which indicated that the goods or services might be used for a weapons of mass destruction program, even if no-one in the company had actually turned their mind to it. The company then must also take care that one of its directors, employees or agents does not hold such suspicions without alerting the responsible person in the company, otherwise the knowledge of the director, employee or agent could be attributed to the company, resulting in conviction, a fine and confiscation of the goods.

The coalition does not step back from requiring reasonable, responsible action of any company or person in Australia, but we are very mindful of this additional burden placed upon commercial operators in Australia and Australians abroad. This burden on companies should be balanced against the importance of limiting the capacity of countries to construct weapons of mass destruction. As I have intimated from the outset, the coalition does not oppose the legislation. We are mindful of some tightening or rewording amendments that the government will move that have been circulated and for which there is an explanation. We will support this legislation and listen to the contributions of other senators.

speech.speaker: Bourne Sen V.W.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats give a qualified welcome to the Weapons of Mass Destruction (Prevention of Proliferation) Bill 1994. This legislation is designed to be a backup to existing non-proliferation controls and, as such, it represents a step forward.

para.tab: The bill contains a number of sensible provisions that we are happy to support, specifically: the minister may prohibit the supply or export of goods or services which could contribute to a weapons of mass destruction program; a person may seek the minister's advice as to whether a proposed supply or export could assist such a program; gaol terms can be imposed for breaches; goods may be seized and destroyed where attempts are made to export them in contravention of the act; and companies and directors are liable for the actions of their employees or their delegates.

So far so good, but the bill contains what we regard as a major weakness. It actually allows permits to be issued to supply goods or services to a weapons of mass destruction program provided this would not conflict with our international obligations or the national interest. To make matters worse, the power to issue permits can be delegated by the minister to someone in his department and there is absolutely no accountability built into that process. Permits do not need to be tabled or otherwise made public and they are not subject to any disallowance.

The Democrats cannot see how it would ever be in the national interest for Australians to help develop or build weapons of mass destruction. Indeed, there is a strong body of legal opinion that weapons of that kind violate international humanitarian law. In our view, the power to issue permits should be removed from this bill and I will be moving amendments to that effect.

I would be very interested to hear the minister explain the circumstances under which he would authorise Australians to play a role in the production of weapons of mass destruction. I would be particularly interested to hear him respond to advice that I have received that this bill could even allow the export of nuclear weapon components to a nuclear weapon state, such as the United States or the UK.

This possibility arises because the nuclear non-proliferation treaty does not prevent nuclear weapon related exports to the five acknowledged nuclear weapon states—the US, Russia, the UK, France and China. In discussions with my office departmental officials have claimed that our bilateral safeguards agreements would prevent the export of nuclear weapon components or the supply of relevant services but as far as we can see this is simply not the case. Those agreements regulate the export of nuclear reactor parts not nuclear weapon parts.

It would be alarmist to suggest that this bill is going to unleash a flood of Australian assistance to nuclear weapons programs; it is not. We simply believe that the possibility of any such assistance, even in the future, should be categorically ruled out right now. The significance of this proposed permit system, which somewhat fittingly is provided for in clause 13, lies not just in the apparent risk of highly undesirable exports. Just as important—perhaps more important—is what it says about the government's policy on nuclear non-proliferation. If this government had a clear and unambiguous policy favouring the abolition of all weapons of mass destruction it would not have provided for a permit system in this bill. It would have realised that any sort of assistance to a weapons of mass destruction program is automatically contrary to our national interest.
Unfortunately, this self-evident realisation has not yet found its way into government policy, and that is a fact which was illustrated by two votes taken in the United Nations General Assembly on 15 December last year. The first vote was on a resolution which proposed a step by step reduction in the nuclear threat. This was a balanced and sensible proposal. It sought to move the world closer to the ultimate goal of general nuclear disarmament, as called for in the NPT. Article 6 of the NPT calls for negotiations for:

speech.para: . . . cessation of the nuclear arms race at an early date and . . . nuclear disarmament, and . . . a treaty on general and complete disarmament . . .
In other words, the resolution was completely consistent with the NPT and with the general climate of world opinion that nuclear weapons should be abolished.

para.tab:
With the end of the Cold War that view has infiltrated the very bastions of the nuclear establishment itself. On 16 July last year the
Boston Globe
newspaper reported that General Charles Horner, head of the US Space Command, told journalists, `The nuclear weapon is obsolete. I want to get rid of them all.' Honourable senators should bear in mind that General Horner is one of the most senior officers in the US military. He was on active duty when he made that statement, and he still is. It was an extraordinary statement and he left no doubt as to its meaning when he went on to say:

speech.para: I want to go to zero, and I'll tell you why: if we and the Russians can go to zero nuclear weapons, then think what that does for us in our efforts to counter the new war. Think of the high moral ground we secure by having none. It's kind of hard for us to say to North Korea, `You are terrible people, you're developing nuclear weapon', when the United States has thousands of them.

Across the Atlantic British Field Marshal Lord Carver reportedly sees no need for Britain to maintain an independent nuclear force. Senior Conservative MP Sir Peter Emery has called on the nuclear powers to give up their nuclear arsenals in favour of a small internationally controlled nuclear reserve. UK Defence Secretary Malcolm Rifkind went some way towards General Horner's thinking when he admitted, `It is difficult to see deterrence operating securely against proliferators.'

para.tab: In keeping with world opinion, the resolution for a step by step reduction in the nuclear threat won a resounding majority: 111 states voted in favour, 24 voted against and 33 abstained. Australia was one of those abstentions. The second vote—which, incidentally, took place some 17 minutes later—proposed to ask the International Court of Justice for an advisory opinion on a question which is crucial to world security, that is: is the threat or use of nuclear weapons in any circumstance permitted under international law?

Senators may be aware that international law is quite clear in its opposition in principle to methods of warfare which are inhumane, indiscriminate and disproportionately destructive. There can be little doubt that the use of nuclear weapons, with the possible exception of some peripheral low yield types, would be inhumane, indiscriminate and disproportionately destructive.

You do not need a degree in international law to realise that there is something wrong with a legal system which explicitly bans chemical weapons, biological weapons and dumdum bullets but is silent on nuclear weapons despite their far greater potential to kill, destroy and maim. There are few better things the international court could do than to consider whether weapons which could destroy the planet several times over should be stripped of their veneer of legitimacy.

This goes to the heart of one of the burning issues of international relations: should the privileges enjoyed by the nuclear states, as temporarily enshrined in the NPT, be allowed to continue? If the International Court of Justice were to say no, the existing world order would become a lot more fluid than it is now. The standing enjoyed by the nuclear powers as permanent members of the Security Council would be increasingly called into question.

With all that was at stake the nuclear powers worked very hard to neutralise the World Court project, which was established in the mid-1980s to get a resolution of this kind through the General Assembly. Fortunately, and amazingly, they failed in that. The resolution passed with 78 states in favour, 43 against and 38 abstentions. How did Australia vote? Did we stand up for humanitarian principles? Did we build on our self-proclaimed track record on arms control or did we abstain again? We abstained. Twice in 17 minutes we did nothing while the United Nations took concrete positions in favour of nuclear disarmament.

It is not hard to work out why our government took that position. For all our great work on chemical disarmament—and it was great work; it still is—our approach to nuclear disarmament is conservative, outdated and heavily constrained by alliance sensitivities. The government has put up a number of arguments to justify its opposition to the World Court project, and I will deal briefly with those.

The minister has argued that the court should not involve itself in a security matter, especially one as sensitive as this one. It is not at all clear why this should be so, particularly when weighty humanitarian principles and the integrity of international law are at stake here. He has also claimed that the standing of the court will be undermined because the nuclear weapon states will not cooperate with an adverse ruling. In fact, the contrary is more likely to be the case. The court's standing would be raised immeasurably by an opinion against nuclear weapons given the favourable climate of world sentiment.

The pressure will be on the nuclear powers to comply with the court's findings. Any failure to do so would do far more damage to their own standing. We have also been told that an adverse finding would complicate and hinder arms control negotiations. To the contrary, it would give those negotiations a much clearer end focus by clarifying that the end point is general and complete nuclear disarmament.

Finally, it has been suggested that the court might find that some categories of nuclear weapons are not illegal, setting back the impetus for disarmament. A finding in favour of high yield weapons, the most controversial and threatening kind, is extremely unlikely for the reasons I have already given. It may be that some classes of tactical weapons would be found legal, but this would be peripheral. The government's objections to the World Court project have quite deliberately erred on the side of unjustified pessimism and have ducked the real issue—the illegality of nuclear weapons and the need to get serious about nuclear disarmament.

It is most unfortunate to see one of Australia's most progressive foreign ministers so far behind the cutting edge on this issue. The government has positioned itself as a spectator rather than as a player and it has offered excuses instead of addressing the principles. It is also out of step with almost every government in South-East Asia and the South Pacific. The countries which voted in favour of both resolutions were Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, the Philippines, Vietnam, Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands and Fiji. New Zealand voted for the World Court reference and Laos voted for the threat reduction motion.

That is not to suggest that we should automatically side with a regional majority. We most certainly should not. It is just that we have taken an unjustifiable position which also happens to be at odds with our push for better regional relations. The point I am making is that the same thinking which underpins clause 13 of this bill has led us to take some extremely poor positions on the world stage.

We do, however, have an opportunity to redeem ourselves in the near future. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty will be the subject of a review conference in April of this year. At issue is whether the treaty should be extended indefinitely or for a temporary period, amended in some way or abandoned entirely. A key focus will be whether the nuclear powers have honoured their article 6 obligation to move towards nuclear disarmament and whether that process should be given a kick along.

My view is that indefinite extension without amendment would encourage complacency amongst the nuclear powers. A timetable for disarmament or at least some more ambitious steps towards that goal would be much more in keeping with the spirit of the treaty itself. After 25 years of the NPT, it is not good enough to propose an indefinite continuation of the status quo.

Unfortunately, the signs are not good. Australia's statement on the review conference suggest a continuation of the depressingly cautious policies I have already spoken of. Our representatives are arguing for an indefinite extension of the NPT and negotiations for a nuclear test ban and that is about it. The result will be to undermine our disarmament credentials and to increase our regional isolation on this critical security issue. A policy rethink is long overdue. We need to be serious about nuclear disarmament. We urge the Senate to make that point by accepting our amendment.

talk.start.para: —The Weapons of Mass Destruction (Prevention of Proliferation) Bill has an essential place in the international arms control agreements. This bill prohibits the supply or export of goods or services that will or may be used to produce, acquire or stockpile weapons of mass destruction and their missile delivery systems. I will take a moment to talk about the missile delivery systems because previous speakers have placed little importance on that. It is a very essential part of the bill.

para.tab: Ballistic missiles can be classified in a number of ways. There are very short range missiles, the tactical ballistic missiles that are used on the battlefields. Beyond that are the theatre type weapons such as the short range ballistic missile that go to about 450 nautical miles, the medium range ballistic missiles that go to 1,500 nautical miles, the intermediate range ballistic missiles that go up to 3,500 nautical miles and then beyond that again are the very large missiles, the intercontinental ballistic missiles.

I have had a concern about the control of missiles and missile availability for a number of years. My main concern is with the intermediate and short and medium range ballistic missiles because the reliability and capability of those missiles has increased out of sight. They are very accurate and readily available on the world market and they will be increasingly available through the next decade. They are very potent delivery systems.

They are in quite a different league to the intercontinental ballistic missiles, which are hugely expensive. They will always be the province of only the major powers. The smaller nations will never possess missiles to rival the Russian or American ICBMs. In relation to the shorter range missiles, the world is awash with them—that may sound like hyperbole—and they are certainly increasingly available. There is an urgent need for us to develop a counter to those weapons. That is one of the military imperatives before us.

Saying that, I recognise that there is no successful counter in place today. The Patriot missile that was used in the Gulf War was one of the systems used against them and there are several lesser systems available in the Western nations. An anti-ballistic missile system is a very system, but these weapons are real terror weapons. One of the great dangers is that they can be used against civilian targets, either in a mass area attack or for precise attacks on civilian targets.

We only have to talk to those citizens who were living in the United Kingdom in 1944 and 1945 when the V2, the first of these short range ballistic missiles, was used to know the terror that they conferred on the community. They dropped out of the sky and flattened whole blocks of houses or buildings and no-one had any warning. No-one could escape them. In the 50 years since the V2 was used, we are now seeing weapons available with pinpoint accuracy and affordability.

I have been talking about the need to have both control of these weapons and military counters for them for at least four or five years. Typically, the Labor government has done nothing in the national interest to make this a priority and, of course, the Australian defence forces have done nothing. It is a priority for Australia as it is for all other nations with a concern about their own integrity from a defence point of view. That part of the bill which deals with the control of the delivery platforms is very important.

I will now turn to the main part of the bill. What the government is proposing is a bill to restrict the availability of weapons of mass destruction and the materials they are made from. That implies that we are going to have some rules in place. It may seem strange to some people that we do have rules for the conduct of a matter which is so violent as armed conflict. There have been many moves to regulate the use of weapons of war, not just nuclear weapons, in the last 50 years.

If we look at modern history, we find that in 1868 we had the St Petersburg conference which ultimately led to the Hague convention of 1907 which banned a number of weapons. Interestingly enough, the St Petersburg convention banned the use of poison gas as a military weapon. Somewhat strangely the development of poison gas was carried out by a Nobel Prize winning German-Jewish scientist Fritz Haber. He developed chlorine so that it could be used in the battlefield. He took it beyond a laboratory exercise, mass produced it and developed the technologies for using it. It was used firstly at Ypres in April 1915 and with devastating effect for the rest of the First World War. We saw gas widely used by both sides of the conflict in the First World War and we saw it used by the Italians at Abyssinia and most recently by Saddam Hussein, the friend of the Democrats, against his own Kurdish citizens in Iraq.

I said that it is part of the series of international arms control agreements that we have. One of the principal agreements that comes to mind is the nuclear non-proliferation treaty which, despite the criticism we have heard from the Democrats, has been a great success. There is no question in my mind, having lived through the era that this treaty has been in place, that it has acted as a positive restraint on the proliferation of nuclear weapons. No-one who can take a detached view of history could come to any other conclusion. Sure, it is not perfect but, if we had not had the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, we would have seen many more nations possessing nuclear weapons today and the world would be a very much more dangerous place than it is today.

I listened with great interest to the ramblings of Senator Bourne. It struck me that she and her party simply have no ability to stand back and look at the world with any sense of perspective at all. To make the claims she did that somehow or other we are in a parlous state because we still have nuclear weapons is to not recognise the enormous changes that have taken place since the end of the Cold War. For many years, from the detonation of the hydrogen bomb by the Soviets, we lived under the doctrine of mutually assured destruction. It was the most difficult period for the nations of the world since civilisation began.

We managed that situation on both sides with extreme care but, as I have said in many speeches, I never thought this could last forever. I did not think we could live under a doctrine of mutually assured destruction forever. It came to pass that the Soviet economy collapsed and the Cold War passed. Since then, the risk of nuclear confrontation between the superpowers has gone forever.

Certainly, we would all like to live in a world free of nuclear weapons, but no-one can destroy the technological and scientific base that gives us those weapons. No-one can control governments that have a mind to build these weapons if they are not signatories to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and that go ahead. What we have seen since the ending of the Cold War is not only the absence of the risk of a war between the East and the West, or between the Soviets and the Western democracies, but also the rapid run-down of the nuclear arsenals of both powers. It is very unlikely that we will see any new nuclear weapons developed by them at all because there is no need to do that.

It is important, since the world is not a perfect place, that you retain some nuclear weapons. I have never wanted them to be retained by Australia or developed by Australia. I am sure there is a good argument for the United Kingdom and France not possessing them. But I do think that some country has to maintain some sort of a nuclear capability, otherwise they will be held to ransom by some tin-pot dictator like Saddam Hussein or Colonel Gaddafi in Libya. It is just a fact of adult life that, while these weapons are around, somebody has to be around on the side of the good guys with the force to take them on in case they are challenged. It as simple as that.

That is really what General Horner was saying. I saw the interviews that he made and I read his comments on that. It is certainly the belief of my very old and very good friend Sir Peter Emery, who has been the Chairman of the Atlantic Alliance for many years and who is a leading thinker. He has been in the House of Commons for 30 or more years now. He is one of the very longstanding members of the British parliament. He is certainly one of the best thinkers in defence that Britain has produced in the postwar years. When he talks about some sort of supranational power with nuclear weapons as a deterrent, he is going down the path that you cannot be held to ransom.

I want to take a point of difference with the Democrats. It is not my reading of the bill that it will permit the wholesale export of chemical weapons or weapons of mass destruction. My understanding of it is that the permit does not allow any export for the use overseas of any weapon system for the purposes of mass destruction. The permits are designed to allow the legitimate exports that will not be used in the weapons of mass destruction. I will leave that for the minister to clear up.

Let me continue with the current arms control measures that we have had after the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. We have had the biological weapons convention and the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Bill 1993.

This bill attempts to ensure that Australian citizens will not aid in the possession, manufacture or the use of weapons of mass destruction. I accept that this is a very difficult legislative field. As the history of gas being banned at St Petersburg in the last century illustrates, where you have a wilful government, conventions can be broken and overridden. But that is not an argument against legislating in the first place.

We have seen under the nuclear non-proliferation treaty a considerable degree of control of the materials that go into the precursors of nuclear weapons. I accept that is a lot easier to control than measures in relation to biological and chemical weapons. One of the characteristics of biological and chemical weapons of mass destruction is that their precursors are common, everyday chemicals and supplies that you can almost buy on the grocery shelves. They are used in such volume that they are very hard to monitor and control. It is the moral authority of this legislation that really is more important than the physical way it can be implemented.

As I said before, it may seem strange to have rules for war, but there have always been rules in mankind since the first tribes or groups went to war or had conflicts with others. There is an old saying, a rather glib cliche, that `all is fair in love and war'. That is simply not true. It is not true in either case, but it is certainly not true with respect to war. There have always been rules and conventions for the conduct of armed conflict. It is true that those rules have changed over the centuries, and we have not had the codification that we had under the Geneva conventions that we have at the present time. But there has always been some acceptance that there are limits to the use of force.

One of the great differentiations that has been made is between armed force in regular military units and civilians. The general assumption has been that civilians are separate and that armed forces have certain rules that they conform to when they are using the force and the violence necessary in a time of war. Once upon a time, it was quite simple to differentiate between the two. In general, members of an armed force wore a uniform or badges. They were identifiable visibly and they always carried their arms openly. Nowadays, with the freedom fighters and the sorts of liberation struggles that take place within some regimes, it is very hard to identify a civilian faction from an armed faction. That leads to a blurring of the rules of war. Nevertheless, there are conventions.

It is interesting that the great writer on warfare, von Clausewitz, derided laws in relation to armed conflict as being `self-imposed restraints hardly worth mentioning'. But I do not agree with that point of view. I would agree with Professor Martin Van Crevald, who is one of the most informed modern writers on the conduct of war and armed conflict. He once said that `war without law is not merely a monstrosity but an impossibility'. Those laws in the past have applied to the personnel who were involved, the weapons that were used and the circumstances of treaties and conventions for truces, the neutral states and the citizenship.

Once upon a time, prisoners of war were enslaved and made to work. Now we have the Geneva convention, which provides that you have to give only your name, rank and serial number, and that is the end of it. Prisoners are required under the convention to be treated in a humane way. They are required to be fed, to be not turned into slave labourers or anything like that. But I can give another example of how conventions change. Back in Napoleonic times, if officers who were captured gave their word that they would not escape, they lived the life of luxury and ease that the officers in the army that captured them did. It is now accepted that, when both officers and other ranks are captured, they have an obligation to escape if they can.

Some weapons have been favoured more than others. From Greek mythology right up to the Middle Ages the sword and the spear were always preferred to the bow. That, of course, was breached when King Harald got an arrow through his eye at the Battle of Hastings. As you would remember very well, the English had their revenge at Crecy and at Agincourt with the longbow against the French. There are also rules and conventions relating to what invading armies must do when they conquer a country. Most of that is inscribed under the Geneva conventions, to which most countries are signatory at the present time.

We have a long history of rules or conventions relating to activities in a warlike sense, and they go back right to the dawn of history when the first groups or tribes were in conflict, right up to the nation states that we have today. It is against that historical background that the weapons of mass destruction bill must be judged. We recognise that all legislation is imperfect and it will not stop a wilful government breaking the conventions. If you look at the effect of treaties, like the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, you must come to the conclusion that it is better to do these legislative acts and work to support them and to get acceptance of them amongst the nations of the world than not do them. On that basis the opposition supports this legislation.

speech.speaker: Margetts Sen D.

talk.start.para: —Before making some brief comments on the Weapons of Mass Destruction (Prevention of Proliferation) Bill, I would like to say a couple of things about some of the statements that have been made already by other senators. Senator MacGibbon says that war without law would be a monstrosity. I would like to see war without profits. If it became illegal to make profits out of such things as weapons of mass destruction, perhaps we would not be in this situation of trying to work out how we can stop people from continuing to try to make profits out of producing components or parts of weapons of mass destruction.

para.tab: It still seems to be the dollar that is driving in a negative way a lot of what happens in the world—increasing gaps between rich and poor and increasing gaps between various countries in relation to trade arrangements and scapegoating, which tends to occur between and within countries. The dollar is responsible for a lot of that and from what I have seen so far, today's debate has not indicated that the members of the opposition recognise in any way that that is the case.

Senator MacGibbon also said that the nuclear non-proliferation treaty is one of the great successes. I am concerned that he misses the point that the conditions for the nuclear non-proliferation treaty actually guarantee proliferation of nuclear materials. Supposedly, that guarantees the supply of nuclear materials for non-aggressive uses. The only trouble is that there is very little way of controlling what happens to nuclear materials once a country has gained access to them. The reality is that the international body for controlling the spread of nuclear weapons, the International Atomic Energy Agency, is the same body whose role it is to promote the use of nuclear technology. Therefore, there is obviously a conflict of interest. It is a body that is very underresourced in the area of checking proliferation, so there is no way that this body has the ability to police what happens.

Senator MacGibbon mentioned that we can breathe a sigh of relief that the Cold War is over, but we are not just talking about the existing superpowers that we recognised under the Cold War. As we speak, a cargo of plutonium is travelling to Japan. The problem with that is that Australia and other countries like the United States have jumped up and down about North Korea's gaining of materials that could be used in a nuclear weapons program. What has been said about the proliferation of materials that could be used in Japan's nuclear program? Senator MacGibbon says that no nuclear weapon is being developed. That is an extremely naive stance—and Australia has taken that stance.

I point out that the Greens (WA) strongly endorse the words in Senator Bourne's deliberations. The reality is that Australia's stance is far from acceptable to people who are concerned about what place we will take in the future and what role we might have in the future proliferation of nuclear weapons. Senator MacGibbon said, `Somebody has got to be around on the side of the good guys.' I have to tell you that during the inquiry into defence exports, it was extremely difficult for anyone to get any idea of who we classified as good guys and who we classified as bad guys. In fact, the new Uruguay Round of GATT does not allow us to make distinctions between good guys and bad guys, because they consider it is a barrier to free trade for us to make plans for the future of our exports, like uranium, or whether or not it might be making a situation worse in a particular part of the world. The reason for that is that the Uruguay Round of GATT specifies that we can only make decisions in that way if it is in our own security interests.

It is hard for us to argue that something in the Middle East or in a part of South-East Asia that is not directly threatening Australia is going to directly impact on Australia's security. Therefore, the kinds of sayings that we hear in here do not in practice apply if we are talking about an individual company wanting to make money—the big dollar again—by selling either weapons or components of weapons of mass destruction.

I was extremely perplexed that Senator MacGibbon could say that his reading of the legislation indicated that there is no way that the permits mentioned under section 13 could be used for weapons of mass destruction. I would like to point Senator MacGibbon to the word `and' in clause 13, which states:

speech.para: (a) a person wishes to supply goods to a particular person, to export non-regulated goods to a particular place or to provide services to a particular person; and
(b) the Minister has reason to believe or suspect that the goods will or may be used in, or the provision of the services will or may assist, a WMD program; and

Each of the paragraphs in clause 13 is joined by `and'. I am not a lawyer, but I know enough to say that that means it is a precondition of that section. Therefore, if the minister suspects that goods may be used in a weapons of mass destruction program, he may give a permit for them to be exported. That is clear.

para.tab: The Greens (WA) welcome any legislation designed to reduce the threat of proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. I would like to point out that in very recent times, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) has been involved in a trip to Indonesia to actually ask them to support the nuclear weapons states' push for an open-ended treaty. As Senator Bourne mentioned, the reality is that there has not been enough movement towards the clauses that are required by the nuclear weapons states to go towards a position of disarmament. That is the preferred position. It surely must be that Australia works to strengthen those clauses. Why, oh, why is Australia siding with the nuclear weapons states?

I am noticing in the media that some people are depicting the position as Australia going into bat for the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. That is garbage. It is not an all or nothing situation. It is a matter of strengthening the position that a number of countries in the world are wanting. It is not just a matter of privilege. The nuclear weapons states can continue to do what they like for as long as they like with nuclear weapons. We do acknowledge that the government has done and continues to do good work on the chemical weapons ban. Why doesn't it move in the same direction for weapons of mass destruction in general?

In the case of nuclear weapons it is hypocritical for the government to express concern about exporting goods and services that could be used in weapons of mass destruction while exporting uranium and allowing plutonium, the key element for nuclear weapons, to be separated from it.

We are also concerned about clauses 10 and 13. I have mentioned this before. It reads that goods may not be exported if it is suspected that they will be used in a weapons of mass destruction program except `where it is authorised by virtue of a ministerial permanent or written notice.' We are at a loss to understand why the government would authorise the export of goods it suspects may be used in a weapons of mass destruction program. We suspect that this may be used to ensure that this bill does not interfere unduly with the profit of Australian companies. It will also be used, we assume, to allow exports of sensitive goods to the nuclear weapons states, despite their possession of massive nuclear arsenals. This is consistent with the double standard inherent in treaties such as the nuclear non-proliferation treaty.

I know the Democrats are putting forward an amendment to clause 13. I also flag that I will be moving an amendment to clause 13 to allow for parliamentary scrutiny of permits issued by the minister. There is absolutely no excuse for a minister or a representative of the minister to be able to override this legislation without the scrutiny of parliament.

Whilst we welcome any bill designed to deter proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, we believe the government could be doing much more on the international scene with regard to nuclear weapons. In 1985 Senator Gareth Evans was asked:

speech.para: Does the Government consider that the [Nuclear Weapons State] signatories to the nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty have adequately complied with their obligations under Article VI of the Treaty?

His answer was that they had not `met the expectations of the non-nuclear weapons states.' Given that, why is Australia not doing more to support attempts to strengthen article vi at the April 1995 nuclear non-proliferation review conference, in particular supporting attempts to introduce a timetable for the elimination of nuclear weapons?

para.tab: Senator Evans cannot claim that things have changed in this sense since 1985. The United Kingdom has just commissioned the Trident nuclear submarine, which represents a fourfold increase in strike power over the previous Polaris. France and China have made no moves towards disarmament. Despite START II, the United States continues to develop its nuclear arsenal. The commitment to disarmament contained in article vi is still not being met. I agree that some nuclear weapons are being decommissioned but mostly it is because they have reached their use-by date, so it makes a very convenient gesture on the part of those states.

In the 1994 defence white paper, the government stated that it was committed to `supporting the maintenance by the United States of a nuclear capability to deter nuclear threats against allies like Australia.' This flies in the face of moves towards disarmament. It reinforces the role of nuclear weapons as one of the major determinants of global power and makes the acquisition of nuclear weapons by non-weapons states more attractive. In that, it directly undermines non-proliferation efforts. Non-proliferation efforts will always be more difficult if nuclear weapons are given such a critical role in determining who is powerful and who is not.

Australia has been an opponent of the attempt to have the International Court of Justice rule on the legality of using nuclear weapons. This position has seen us running the line of the nuclear weapons states, whose agenda predictably is to maintain their nuclear arsenals. We should then encourage Australia to support moves being made in the context of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty review conference to accelerate nuclear disarmament, in particular moves to introduce a definite timetable for the elimination of nuclear weapons. Countries such as Indonesia and Mexico are proposing such moves, as are groupings such as Parliamentarians for Global Action, PGA. Australia, however, is pushing for indefinite extension with no timetable, which would set in stone the possession of nuclear weapons by the nuclear weapons states.

Finally, I give notice that I will be moving an amendment after clause 20 to incorporate a clause that requires the government to commit itself to implementing a program to eliminate the risk of nuclear weapons developed from nuclear energy resources. I will elaborate further on this issue at the committee stage of the bill. It is hypocritical of Australia not to include such clauses. Otherwise there is no way in the world we could indicate that we are anything but naive. To consider supplying the elements of weapons of mass destruction on the basis that we accept countries' assurances that they will not be used in a weapons of mass destruction program is naive in the extreme. So we watch with interest and with support from the various sides on these issues. In reality I cannot see any justification for supporting the ability of the minister to override without parliamentary scrutiny any ability to make the sale by Australia of parts of weapons of mass destruction illegal, full stop.

talk.start.para: —I will do my best to cope with the points that have been raised and the information provided me to assist the Senate. The government cannot agree with the suggestion made by some opposition senators that there are deficiencies in the government's approach to disarmament and non-proliferation issues, including in relation to the current bill. Australia's record under this government of being one of the most active countries internationally in promoting these objectives and of practical achievement in areas such as the conclusion of the chemical weapons convention and progress towards the comprehensive test ban treaty underlines this government's commitment and constructive approach. It is also an approach that is practical and realistic. That point must be stressed. Not only is it committed; it is also practical and realistic. It is a very significant area of foreign and security policy. This government can be very proud of its record and its commitment.

para.tab: Indeed, the government's record stands in strong contrast to some of the impractical posturing or proposals that have come out in comments made earlier in this debate. The bill under consideration is an example of practical measures being taken to further reinforce Australia's approach to non-proliferation and it is in step with similar measures in place or under consideration by many of our non-proliferation partners.

To comment on a few points that have been raised in this debate, turning to nuclear disarmament and the non-proliferation treaty review and extension conference, the NPTREC: the Australian government is committed to nuclear non-proliferation and disarmament. It is working actively to strengthen and extend indefinitely the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Indeed, we have taken a leading role in urging the early completion of the CTBT. Australia, together with New Zealand, has for many years co-sponsored a resolution in the General Assembly calling for the comprehensive test ban treaty and we have also been successful in maximising support for this resolution.

In 1993 Australia took a leading role in gaining consensus support for the comprehensive test ban treaty resolution for the first time, an achievement which allowed the negotiations on this treaty finally to commence. Since then we have committed substantial resources towards the negotiation, including the provision of a draft treaty text. Australia continues to urge the five nuclear weapons states to reach a common agreement on assurances against the use or threat of use of nuclear weapons to non-nuclear weapons states which have fulfilled their non-proliferation obligations, known as negative security assurances. We are also working for agreement on establishing a mandate at the conference of disarmament for the negotiation of a convention providing for the cut-off of the production of fissionable material for weapons purposes.

In the General Assembly, Australia supports the overwhelming majority of resolutions on nuclear matters, including negative security assurances, nuclear free zones, bilateral nuclear disarmament and the cut-off of production of fissionable materials for weapons purposes. Last year, and this is in contrast with some of the nuclear weapons states, Australia voted in favour of a new resolution sponsored by Japan which called upon `the nuclear weapons states to pursue their efforts for nuclear disarmament with the ultimate objectives of elimination of nuclear weapons in the framework of general and complete disarmament.'

Australia's abstention on a resolution requesting an advisory opinion on the legality of the threat or use of nuclear weapons was based on our strong doubts about whether consideration by the court of questions of legality would in fact assist nuclear disarmament and non-proliferation efforts.

The opinion of the court could have a negative effect on the import arms control and disarmament negotiations, referred to above, being conducted in other relevant forums. In particular, a finding that the use of nuclear weapons could be legal in some circumstances would have serious negative implications for global nuclear non-proliferation norms. Alternatively, a finding that any use of nuclear weapons would be illegal would be in contradiction of the stated doctrines of all nuclear weapons states and as such would be unlikely to have any effect on their approaches to nuclear disarmament and could seriously undermine the authority of the court.

Australia abstained on a resolution promoting a step-by-step approach to nuclear threat reduction because the resolution was largely impractical. It is widely understood that the nuclear weapons states would not be prepared to negotiate a timetable for nuclear disarmament in a multilateral forum. Some of the steps prescribed in the resolution can only be negotiated bilaterally and those which can be considered multilaterally, such as the comprehensive test ban treaty and the cut-off, are already on the agenda of the CD. We were also concerned that the process of negotiating a timetable for nuclear disarmament could completely paralyse the CD. These abstentions in no way detract from our record as a country which persistently and actively pursues a range of practical and meaningful nuclear non-proliferation and disarmament objectives.

Looking at the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, the government believes the treaty makes a vital contribution to international peace and security, including peace and security in our own region, and strongly supports the indefinite extension of the NPT at the treaty's review and extension conference to be held in April-May 1995. The government believes that indefinite extension of the treaty can best guarantee the continuation of the international and regional security benefits provided to date by the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. The government wants to see a thorough review of the operation of the treaty at the NPTREC.

talk.start.para: —What's that?

—The non-proliferation treaty review and extension conference. I have explained, and I hope the Senate will appreciate, that it would be beneficial for us all if we were understanding of these issues. Certainly I am trying to assist the Senate as best I can. What I am arguing is that an indefinite extension of the non-proliferation treaty is the best way of maintaining the benefits of the non-proliferation treaty.

para.tab: We also want to encourage non-proliferation treaty members to see the conference as an opportunity to shape the environment for the next century so that, if we can, we move to a nuclear-free world. That, I presume, is the intention of other governments besides Australia, but it certainly is the intention of this government. Getting that indefinite extension would be a major factor in locking in the significant achievement of disarmament since the end of the Cold War and it would provide the most propitious environment for continuing nuclear reductions.

I turn now to clause 13, which relates to the permit system. The suggestion that the permit system under clause 13 would allow a wide area of discretion to the government to supply goods or services to weapons of mass destruction programs is based on a misreading of this provision in the legislation. The example given in Senator Bourne's media release of 8 February of nuclear weapons triggers—that is, electronic switches—is particularly inappropriate as any export of the item in question is already regulated under Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulation 13(e).

The definition of `non-regulated goods' in clause 3, in combination with the prohibition on exports under clause 10, which is limited to cover only exports of non-regulated goods, means that the export of such items would not be governed by the weapons of mass destruction bill, irrespective of the existence or not of the permit system. The question is theoretical in any case as Australia does not produce nuclear weapons triggers.

As required by paragraph 13(1)(d), the minister would only be able to issue a permit where the minister is satisfied that the planned activity would not be contrary to Australia's international or treaty obligations or the national interest. This requirement greatly restricts the circumstances in which a minister could issue a permit.

Chemical weapons convention and biological weapons convention obligations would prevent any assistance to chemical or biological weapons programs. Further, our obligations under the nuclear non-proliferation treaty would provide for all transfers of fissile material and related equipment to non-nuclear weapons states to be for peaceful purposes only and subject to IAEA safeguards. Transfer of Australian uranium would occur only under treaty level bilateral safeguard agreements with recipient states.

Therefore, in the case of those nuclear weapons states with whom Australia has bilateral safeguard agreements, transfers of Australian uranium for non-peaceful purposes would be prohibited under the terms of these binding international treaty undertakings. These state that Australian uranium will not be diverted to military or nuclear explosive purposes, nor used for research thereon.

In any case, the nuclear weapons states have their own sources of nuclear material. Exports of uranium and all other nuclear or nuclear-related dual use items are controlled by Australian Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations, in keeping with our international treaty obligations and existing domestic non-proliferation legislation.

In the event that a nuclear weapons state wished to purchase such items from Australia for use in a weapons program, export of these items would be denied unless the Australian government were satisfied that the export would be used only for peaceful purposes. It is most unlikely, however, that such a request would be made, given the capacity of the nuclear weapons states to develop such items themselves.

Our obligations as a member of the missile technology control regime require us to exercise restraint in the export of dual use missile technology. The purpose of the regime is to limit the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction by controlling transfers that could make a contribution to ballistic and cruise missile delivery systems. In the case of complete missiles within the missile technology control regime parameters—that is, capable of delivering a payload of 500 kilograms over a distance of 300 kilometres—there is a strong presumption to deny any transfer. That means that the minister could only issue a permit to allow the supply or export of goods or the provisions of services in the narrow circumstances of cooperation on a missile program, consistent with our international or treaty obligations or the national interests, including defence interests. In practice, we believe such permits would only be issued in relation to missile programs relevant to the development of Australia's defence capabilities.

The government accordingly cannot agree to the separate proposals for amendments relating to clause 13 proposed by the Australian Democrats and by the Greens, believing strongly that such amendments are unnecessary in view of the stringent restrictions already contained in the bill on the issue of permits under clause 13.

I turn to the reasons for government amendments. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills questioned the inclusion of subclause 14(7), due to a possible reversal of the onus of proof. Subclause 14(7) was added late in the drafting of the bill with the aim of precluding prosecution being mounted against a person who has acted in compliance with the conditions specified by the minister in a notice issued under paragraph 14(2)(a). The government believes such protection should be included in the legislation but agrees that the Senate committee has a point in its suggestion that subclause 14(7) could be read as reversing the onus of proof in this one possible element in a prosecution. The government, accordingly, is moving amendments to ensure this reversal onus of proof does not occur.

The amendments delete subclause 14(7) and add provisions to clauses 9, 10 and 11 to make clear that an offence is not committed if the person is acting in compliance with conditions stated in a ministerial notice issued under subclause 14(2).

The government is also using the opportunity to clarify an ambiguity in the current language for clauses 9, 10 and 11. Provisions 9(1)(d), 10(1)(d) and 11(1)(d) all refer to the absence of a written notice by the minister. The amendments make clear that these references refer only to notices issued under clause 12 of the bill. I hope that helps senators with the proposed government amendments.

I am provided with some comments that particularly go to the foreshadowed amendment of Senator Margetts after clause 13 concerning a program of international cooperation in energy resources. The government does not see that the development and use of non-nuclear resources is an effective way of dealing with the potential military use of nuclear science. The great virtue of the non-proliferation treaty is that, despite their inherent scientific and technological competence or capacities, countries consciously forswear the acquisition or development of nuclear armaments. This undertaking is bound in international law and verified by the international safeguard system. It has been shown to be effective in the case of the North Korean nuclear program.

Thus there already exists a comprehensive international regime constraining nuclear weapons proliferation whilst providing a basis for legitimate nuclear trade and cooperation. This entails arrangements by which countries control the supply and export of nuclear related items consistent with their obligations under the non-proliferation treaty to ensure that such trade does not contribute to proliferation. As to the international cooperation in non-nuclear energy, there is already an abundant level of such cooperation at both the intergovernmental and non-governmental level. I hope that assists Senator Margetts in understanding why we do not accept that amendment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

talk.start.para: —I cannot let this go by without mentioning one small issue of relevance here. Senator Crowley has mentioned that the reason the government is changing clause 14(7) of the bill is the principle of the reversal of the onus of proof. Both the government and the opposition sat in this chamber—they did not sit in the chamber very much—during the debate on the Uruguay Round of GATT. The government moved and the opposition voted for the reversal of the onus of proof in relation to intellectual property. It seems to be a principle that is only put forward on occasions when it suits the government and when the opposition is listening. During that debate you did exactly the opposite. I would like to find out why it is applicable in some instances and not in others.

—As I explained in the comments provided to me to assist the chamber, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee alerted the government to the possible reversal of onus of proof and the government has redrafted the bill to make sure that that onus of proof reversal is removed. Floating examples from other areas may be an interesting point to score, even a point to raise, but if you are concerned about the issues of the bill at hand and want to see that reversal of onus removed, then that is what the government is doing with these amendments.

para.tab: Amendments agreed to.
Clause 13.

talk.start.para: —As I said during my speech on the second reading, the Democrats cannot see how it would ever be in the national interest for Australians to help develop or build weapons of mass destruction. The permit system seems to cut right across the basic purpose of this whole legislation. I have raised the issue of the export of nuclear weapon components to nuclear weapon states as an example of an export which should be prohibited unconditionally, and the minister has mentioned that in her second reading speech.

para.tab: The department initially told me that these are caught by our bilateral safeguard agreements and that turned out not to be the case. The minister now tells me that the prohibitions are in the customs regulations. I must confess that I have a certain unease about the way the story keeps changing, but I hope the minister is right in this. Even if she is, though, we still see no justification for any permit system, particularly one which is secret, which is unaccountable, which can be delegated to the department.

We have no such weapons ourselves. We do not produce them for our own or anyone else's use. We do not import them for our own use and we do not want to. We see absolutely no reason why Australia should have any part in helping anyone to produce weapons of mass destruction and therefore why the minister should have the power to issue such a permit under any circumstances. We oppose clause 13 of the bill.

talk.start.para: —As mentioned before, the Greens (WA) have grave concerns with clause 13. We do not see any reason whatsoever why it can be justified that the minister, without reference to the parliament, could overrule the legislation for weapons of mass destruction. Therefore, we would wholeheartedly support the Democrats and feel there should not be any reason why other parties in this chamber do not do the same.

—Senator Bourne has said that it appears to her—and I like her guardedness—that the permit system is established in order to allow a minister to see a person export a substance or a service or a contract for the purpose of a weapons of mass destruction program. The minister has made it abundantly clear that that is fallacious; that is wrong. That is not the purpose of the permit. If you read clause 13—that is the matter before us, to exclude clause 13 from this bill—it talks about exporting certain goods. It does not say in any way that there is an intention or indeed even a possibility that the goods will be provided for another country's weapons of mass destruction program.

para.tab: We are obliged by treaty and we are obliged by the minister's responsibilities under this act—let alone the individual exporter's responsibilities—not to see Australians exporting any matter for a weapons of mass destruction program. Therefore, the guarded way that Senator Bourne expressed the point that it seems to her that that is the case is answered by the clear statement of the minister that that seeming is so subjective it is, in fact, wrong. I am not at all convinced by the contributions made by Senator Bourne or Senator Margetts that we should support any motion to have the permit system taken away from this bill. On behalf of the coalition, I indicate that we will not support the removal of clause 13. We support the bill.

speech.speaker: Bourne Sen V.W.

talk.start.para: —I would just like to read clause 13 of the bill for Senator Teague's information. It seems to me to be extraordinarily clear that what he is saying it does not mean is what it means. Under the heading `Permits', clause 13(1) states:

speech.para: If:
(a)a person wishes to supply goods to a particular person, to export non-regulated goods to a particular place or to provide services to a particular person; and
(b)the Minister has reason to believe or suspect that the goods will or may be used in, or the provision of the services will or may assist, a WMD program—

That sounds very clear to me. That is what this clause says. The minister can issue a permit if he believes or suspects that that is the way those goods or services will be used. We see absolutely no reason whatsoever why he should be able to do that. If it is going to be used in a weapons of mass destruction program, we can see no good reason why that should be allowed.

talk.start.para: —I would like to endorse that statement. What the clause says very clearly—there cannot be any other legal interpretation—is that the minister reserves the right to supply goods or services for the production of weapons of mass destruction. Because the word `and' is used to separate the paragraphs, there is no other legal interpretation that you can make, except that it says, `believe or suspect the goods will or may be used in'. There is not any other way you can read this, except that the minister reserves the right to grant that permit.

para.tab: So I am not sure what on earth the opposition is arguing for. I cannot think of any other way that that can be used, except that it reserves the right to overrule this legislation and provide that Australia can be knowingly complicit in the provision of services or goods for the production of weapons of mass destruction.

speech.speaker: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

talk.start.para: —I think I said most of what needs to be said by the government in closing the second reading debate, and Senator Teague has very comprehensively trawled across the points that need to be made. In the light of those recent contributions, I think it is important that, if you are reading 13(1), you read not (a) or (b) or (c) or (d) by themselves, but you note that between (a), (b), (c) and (d) is the word `and'. All four of those paragraphs must be taken into account together. The best way to counter the concern raised is by reading 13(1)(d). Yes, there are those other points, and:

speech.para: (d)the Minister is satisfied that the supply or export of the goods or the provision of the services in accordance with the application would not be contrary to Australia's international or treaty obligations or the national interest—
I have already made the point that they are very significant restrictions. That, I believe, is the point that needs to be added to the comments that you have both just made.

talk.start.para: —With all due respect, Senator Crowley is perhaps not as aware as some of us of the fact that the Minister for Defence has actually overlooked a number of Australia's treaty obligations with regard to human rights on a number of occasions in efforts to make Australian Defence Industries and other defence related exports more profitable in Australia. So, when it comes to the dollar, it seems that some of our treaty obligations are not as important as others. The fact that it does say `and' gives me no confidence whatsoever, because it means that none of us get to check the decisions made by the minister or the first mentioned person acting on his behalf. What on earth are we doing? To whom are we surrendering this power of overriding this legislation?

para.tab: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of bill.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: 1.After clause 13, page 7, insert the following clause:

13A.(1)
A permit is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the
Acts Interpretation Act 1901
.

"
(2)
