This amendment to the Weapons of Mass Destruction (Prevention of Proliferation) Bill 1994 is designed to provide the parliament with the opportunity to scrutinise permits issued by the minister under the terms of clause 13 of this bill. We agreed with the Democrats that it would be preferable if this clause did not exist, but it is the wish of the chamber to allow the minister to issue permits to allow export of goods or services that may assist with the weapons of mass destruction program. The Greens feel that it is absolutely essential that, in the interests of absolute, proper parliamentary scrutiny, permits issued under ministerial discretion be able to be disallowed by the parliament.

para.tab: Given the opposition's commitment to parliamentary scrutiny of issues in relation to international treaties, I trust that it will be consistent with that belief and allow this parliament to carry out its duties and ensure that the minister's discretion is not contrary to Australia's international or treaty obligations or the national interest, as stated in clause 13. Given the government's often stated commitment to openness and accountability, I trust that it too will support this very reasonable amendment.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats also support Senator Margetts's amendment. We would really rather, as I have mentioned, see that there was no permit system, but we are about to have a permit system. So, in the interests of the transparency of the system—knowing exactly what we are doing in assistance with weapons of mass destruction anywhere—we believe that this is a very good amendment and should go through.

—The position that I outlined on behalf of the coalition with regard to permits and the debate we just had about clause 13 stands with regard to this matter as well. Senator Margetts's proposition to allow permits to be disallowable by a chamber of the parliament is a halfway house or is some way along the track to Senator Bourne's attempted amendment. I give the same substantial answer to this amendment as I did to the former.

para.tab: I ask further that this be understood: the Liberal and National parties believe that we will be in government soon, and that, in government, we will be accountable to parliament. We require this government now to be accountable to parliament. But accountability to parliament does not mean that the parliament has an immediate veto upon powers exercised responsibly by a minister of the government. There is an appropriate executive power, legislative power and parliamentary power.

With regard to accountability in a matter like this, any concern about an action of the minister can be raised by way of a question of the minister in parliament, by way of a speech, by way of a substantive motion or by a variety of ways that we are all familiar with. But it is not the policy of the Liberal and National parties to require that every act of the executive be able to be vetoed by one chamber of the parliament.

With Senator Margetts having referred to treaties, for the record let it be understood that the Liberal and National parties are, indeed, very concerned that the treaty making powers which are rightly in the constitution are being used as a loophole to bring upon the Commonwealth areas of legislative capacity which would not have been allowed by the constitution had there not been the exercise by the Australian government of a treaty. What we are calling for is that at an early stage in the contemplation of a treaty there be proper review and input by the parliament—indeed, I say, even by responsible bodies like state governments and state parliaments, so that there is full knowledge of the implications of any treaty.

However, let me make it clear also that the Liberal and National parties do not have a policy that the parliament has an automatic veto on any treaty. The Liberal and National parties when in government have never agreed that the parliament has a veto upon a treaty that a Liberal-National Party government enters into. Rather, in coming to government—and I hope it is later this year or as soon as is possible—we want to take upon us a new discipline that we will, in government, give such forewarning of any treaty that would be contemplated to be entered into; that the full views of representatives in the parliament, representatives of the states and any other interested parties are fully able to be heard; and that there is consultation that is real and meaningful before the executive government exercises its real power to enter into such a treaty.
I can only say that, for all of the reasons I have referred to, we are not convinced by the motion moved by Senator Margetts. We will allow the bill to stand as it is.

talk.start.para: —Just on a short point of clarification, the Greens (WA) do not stand up on every clause of every bill to ask for disallowance. But on this occasion the asking for disallowance is a symbol of how important we think it is that Australia may well, under this legislation, leave itself open—by corporations, sometimes—to be used to supply services and goods for weapons of mass destruction.

para.tab: We think it is important enough for there to be parliamentary scrutiny because of the amount of secrecy that is generally associated with defence agreements. I would like to think that other people in this chamber realise that it is important enough for us to have scrutiny of it and the power to disallow, if the minister, in all his wisdom, gets it wrong.

talk.start.para: —Just to add briefly to the subject of the importance of parliamentary scrutiny and to the remarks of my colleague Senator Teague, I think there is a growing consensus in this chamber—at least amongst the minor parties and the Liberal Party—that there must be far greater scrutiny of treaties. There is no question that that is the case, and the appropriate step is to work out what is the best way to achieve it.

para.tab: I have had discussions in the past with Senator Bourne to see whether we can achieve the establishment of a Senate committee to which whereby all controversial treaties can be referred. For example, Senator Margetts raised the issue, by interjection, of the need perhaps to have the GATT referred to a Senate committee. Of course, if such a Senate committee had been established, that obviously would be the sort of treaty—if senators felt it were controversial—which would be referred to a Senate committee for discussion and analysis. Equally, a very large number of other treaties being proposed by the government which are controversial would have also been referred to such a Senate committee. I think it is a pity that, despite the earlier assurances we received from Senator Bourne, we have not been able to advance further on this basis, but I hope that in the coming weeks we can have constructive discussions.

I hear exactly what Senator Margetts is saying on the issue of the need to have greater parliamentary scrutiny of treaties. I think it is a sentiment which all of us share—apart from the Labor Party, apparently. I hope that we can make some progress on this important initiative to attempt to establish a Senate committee to properly scrutinise controversial treaties.

talk.start.para: —I have already given the reasons why the government is not accepting this amendment. I would also simply say that Senator Kemp's contribution is probably a brilliant example of the irrelevant contribution.

—I find the assertions—I will not use the term `arguments'—put by the two senators of the opposition who spoke previously absolutely remarkable and almost unbelievable. We have already on the books many, many international agreements which have not passed the scrutiny of this parlia ment.

para.tab: The opposition is assuming that it will win the next election. It may well be that Labor wins the next election; it may stay in power for the next 10 years. Earlier today we heard cries from the opposition that the government had lied about certain things. The opposition clearly does not trust the government. The government will probably enter into another 25, 50, or 100 international treaties during its next term in office—if it gets there. The opposition cannot assume that it will win office, yet here it is giving to the government not only the power to enter into those treaties but also the power under those treaties to do things which, as Senator Margetts has indicated, could presage the massive destruction of life over large areas, including the destruction of cities. We are talking about weapons of mass destruction.

The opposition cannot assume that it will win government. It might well be stuck with the entering into of many, many other treaties by the government. The opposition then will have to live with having given the minister this sort of power, without there being any recourse available to it. It seems to me that the amendment we are considering here is a very reasonable stopgap, if the opposition is genuinely concerned about proper parliamentary scrutiny.
Amendment negatived.

20A.(1)

speech.para: This amendment is, in fact, a redraft of sections 501, 502 and 503 of the United States Nuclear Non-Proliferation Act 1978. The philosophy behind those sections is very sound: they are designed to ensure that the worldwide reliance on nuclear technology, including that for nuclear power, is reduced to minimise the risk that nations developing so-called peaceful nuclear technology do not use that technology for developing weapons of mass destruction.

para.tab:
I wish to remind the committee that I outlined concerns in this regard during debate on a matter of urgency on uranium mining on 24 August 1994. At that time I quoted from an article by Elizabeth Clegg from the Centre for Defence Studies at the University of Aberdeen. In that article, which was published in
Contemporary Review
, she stated:

speech.para: In conclusion, then, it can be seen that the infrastructure required for the development of a nuclear weapons potential is best created under cover of a well established civilian nuclear industry; in all of the above cases the military option was made possible by the existence of a civilian programme.

These concerns have been echoed in recent times with press reports that the United States Secretary of State, Mr Warren Christopher, has been fighting to prevent a deal under which the Russian government will provide specialists, equipment and technology to help Iran finish a 1,300-megawatt light-water nuclear reactor. Apparently, one of the concerns outlined by the United States has been the fear that Iran was, in fact, involved in a crash effort to develop nuclear weapons.

para.tab: There is no doubt that, apart from the very real concerns about the environment associated with the operation of nuclear reactors and the disposal of nuclear waste from those facilities, there is also a great concern that so-called `peaceful' nuclear technology is very easily diverted into programs to manufacture weapons of mass destruction. I trust that the committee will support this amendment as a means of demonstrating to the world community that Australia is truly committed to reducing the possibility of proliferating weapons of mass destruction.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment. We understand from the minister in this debate that Australia is serious about the reduction of nuclear weapons. That is very good to hear. This amendment is an easy way to demonstrate that. It just asks the minister to prepare and implement a program of international cooperation. That is something that this minister is very good at in some circumstances. We will be supporting this. We look forward to everybody else supporting it as well.

talk.start.para: —Under sessional orders, I put the question:

para.tab: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I wish to bid farewell from our parliament to a man who will go down in history as an enigma in the realm of Australian politics. I refer to Dr John Hewson. John Hewson entered this parliament as the member for the Sydney harbourside electorate of Wentworth in 1987 at the age of just 40. He had a background of achievement in business and finance and had considerable experience in political life as a policy adviser to successive federal treasurers between 1976 and 1983.

para.tab: John Hewson is a man of great intelligence. In many ways, he is a good example of a self-made man. Coming from a solid working class background, he rose through hard work and a beneficial exploitation of his own abilities to become professor of economics at the University of New South Wales at the tender age of just 31. By the time he entered federal parliament in 1987, John had amassed a striking background in economic life, the type of which is rarely made available to this place. No-one ever thought that John entered parliament for the kicks or the money; he had plenty of both in his previous occupations. He came here because he was a man of vision. He was a man who could see what this country could become, given the inspired leadership in economic matters which this country lacked in the late 1980s and which it still lacks at a governmental level.

I note that John Hewson's speech in the House today gave expression to some of the frustrations which he felt after seven years of struggling to put his vision into practice. It is not difficult to empathise with his feelings. He readily admitted all along that he was no politician. He readily admitted that he lacked some of the guile which long-term politicians acquire and which helps us to survive some of the more testing times of political battle, public and media criticism and the rough and tumble of political life. After all, John was an academic. He was also a man of the business world who came to Canberra with a vision, but not necessarily with the craft to bring about the results that he sought.

He never saw politics as anything but a means to itself. Unfortunately, he has now come to the conclusion that his ability to seriously influence the ends he sought is not in proportion to the influence he can have on affairs outside this parliament.

This is not meant to be a tribute to a great statesman or politician. It is a tribute to a great and rare parliamentarian. I think there can be nothing but good in having more people of vision in this parliament from all walks of life.

Many would say that John's greatest mistake was to produce a policy document at the 1993 election that was too detailed. It permitted a decline into petty nit-picking to the exclusion of the greater picture. Others would claim that the detailed policy was his greatest success. Certainly the election was the first to see a policy document which allowed close scrutiny but also the ability for our political opponents to sow confusion and misconceptions by scare tactics and untruths. To spend too much time expressing regrets over the outcome of the 1993 election is of no value. John Hewson gave his best effort. He told the truth about his policies. He gave the full details and, regrettably, he lost at the polls.

It would be indeed unfortunate if this experience prevented oppositions or governments of the future from presenting the electorate with a comprehensive set of detailed policies for fear of the type of criticism and the campaign of misrepresentation which occurred in 1993. The action of John Hewson on that occasion took courage. It failed to pay off where it should have mattered, which was at the polls. To try to say that it was therefore the wrong tack to take belittles the exercise and the right of Australians to have access to in-depth policies at election time.

I believe that John Hewson took not only a courageous road but the right one, and one that will set an example for the expectation of voters in the future. An educated and aware electorate will no longer be satisfied with motherhood policies and broad generalisations when it is seeking meaningful direction from political parties.

From my personal point of view, I thank John for the opportunity he gave me to participate in the preparation and examination of policies in the areas of income tax and superannuation as a parliamentary secretary as part of a shadow ministry team. It was an experience that I relished. I appreciate it and thank him. Finally, as I say goodbye to John and wish him and his family all the very best for their future life, I believe that the parliamentary and economic debate will be the poorer for his leaving. However, I sincerely believe that Australian politics has certainly been the richer for John Hewson's time with us. I thank the Senate.

talk.start.para:
—I regret that I have to stand tonight in defence of something that I spent two months of my life with last year and which I thought would have been accepted without question by the Australian public and the Australian media. I am uniquely qualified to speak about this as I am the only parliamentarian who served as a volunteer in Rwanda last year. I was saddened to see the attack on CARE Australia, for whom I worked, on Channel Nine's
Sunday
program yesterday.

para.tab:
I was amazed to learn today that some of that footage and the people who were used in that program had been employed as long as four years ago and were venting their spleen for some imagined misdemeanours that had occurred. I went into that program unaware of CARE Australia's activities. I ask Channel Nine and the
Sunday
program whether they can imagine the damage they have done to the reputation of CARE Australia and the other non-government organisations. Regretfully, when you throw mud, inevitably some of it sticks. I have certainly regarded the
Sunday
program as a high-grade program. Having seen the program yesterday—I have the transcript of it in front of me; I have re-read it—I am amazed at the lack of depth in what it did. I think it has damned itself by what it did yesterday.

Interestingly enough, one of the people who appeared on that program I had not met but he followed on my service in Rwanda. He complained that he was a pharmacist but was not used as a pharmacist. I was senior surgeon of a teaching hospital in Brisbane, and I was acting as pharmacist at the hospital that he was at. I organised the pharmacy in Kitale because it was not organised when I got there. Only somebody who has been in that situation can really understand the utter chaos and the overwhelming demands made on organisations such as CARE Australia.

This `poor' chap came in and, in the comfort of the studios where the program was produced, talked about the lack of organisation, lack of facilities and his not being promoted to his level of competence. I feel sorry for him, because the one characteristic that I noted with all the CARE Australia workers who were involved in this situation was that they put their hands or their shoulders to anything that was available because of the terrible death and destruction that was going on around them. We did not care whether we were pharmacists. We did not care whether we were the surgeons, the doctors or the nurses. We were there to work on the ground and support those people in their tragic situation. Seeing that fellow yesterday complaining about his skills not being used made me feel ill.

My beef is not with him and not with the other person who complained and suggested alleged rorts; my complaint is with Channel 9 and the
Sunday
program. I suppose it is more with the
Sunday
program than Channel 9 because it is all embracing and each program has its own responsibility. I question the morality of the people who put that program to air without giving the opportunity to CARE Australia to respond. I have checked with CARE Australia as to the requests that were made. CARE Australia quite understandably asked to appear live.

Mr President, you and I, as well as every senator in this chamber and those who are watching, would be aware of the editing that occurs in relation to programs. Certainly, when I was active in the organisation of my party I made it a rule to go live on every occasion. Television programs respected that, and they got a better program out of it. On this occasion, when a request was made not only was it not acceded to but, when CARE Australia and the President of CARE Australia asked that appointments be made so that he could explain the difficulties that were occurring, the
Sunday
program did not appear for appointments that were made. It just did not turn up.

The program did submit 35 questions, which were responded to by CARE Australia, but it still went ahead with the superficial program that covered only some of the points. For example, CARE Australia was said to have double billed for a pond that was built in a country. It turns out that two separate ponds had been built. One was billed to the United Nations and one was paid for by CARE Australia. Without checking that fact and without going on the ground and seeing the situation, Channel 9 came out with an irresponsible program which will damage not only CARE Australia but also other non-government organisations which seek the charitable dollar.

One of the things that I have done since I came back from Rwanda is go to many public meetings. As late as Friday night I was at a public meeting raising funds for CARE Australia, which I willingly did, through the Baptist Church in Queensland. I unequivocally have done that because of my knowledge of what I have seen. I have been to the organisation on Northbourne Avenue. I have looked at the structures. I have even seen what has happened on the ground.

One of the complaints was that CARE Australia did not buy trucks in Bosnia. It did not buy trucks in Rwanda or Zaire because it was safer to lease the trucks or use the trucks that were available there because they got hijacked. The same was happening in Bosnia. You do not buy trucks. It is all very well for somebody on the
Sunday
program to talk about buying a truck and transporting it to a foreign country. In Zaire, the regime is totally corrupt. A CARE Australia truck which had its material on it and which was ostensibly owned by CARE Australia—fortunately it was not; it was leased from a Zairean—was hijacked by the Zairean military. The Zairean military had run out of petrol so it held us up, took our truck from us, headed off and we never saw it again. We decided to let it go because, firstly, we did not own it and, secondly, we would have placed our lives in jeopardy if we tried to retrieve it.

To have that reporter carrying on as if this were a great misdemeanour just staggered me. He had no concept of what goes on in these situations. CARE Australia was asked to respond to a disaster situation at a moment's notice. That is what these organisations do. They go into a situation where there are no lines of communication, no radio, no tents, no covering and no food. To then be very objective about it back here in the comfort of an air-conditioned studio and pontificate about the lack of structure is just beyond comprehension. Surely the reporter could have given CARE Australia the opportunity to appear on the program and be questioned.

Instead, what has happened is that that slur has been cast, and it reflects on every other aid organisation as well. As you and I know, Mr President, when you are dealing with the public there is always that section of the community that says, `They're all rorting it for themselves. Why should we give money to the starving and people in disaster situations? They brought it upon themselves. We have all these terrible problems in Australia; surely the money should stay in Australia.'

This type of situation adds fuel to that sort of argument. I am devastated to see an attack on an organisation which I can assure you, Mr President, and the Australian public runs on a shoestring. Go over to Northbourne Avenue and have a look at what is going on there. CARE Australia is leasing a couple of floors in a building on Northbourne Avenue. It is really pretty rough, certainly by this palace's standards, and it is very rough by ordinary business standards.

CARE Australia cannot screen the people who apply to go into these situations. They are all volunteers. I can understand some of them being aggrieved, because certainly the security is impossible. That was another complaint—that CARE Australia did not provide security. Mr President, tell me how you can provide security when you are surrounded by 200,000 people, with a lot of them being armed. How do you provide security? This person complained that that area I was in got shot up a couple of weeks after I was there. I mentioned it in the Senate a couple of weeks ago. Of course it got shot up.

I am reminded of one day I was there when 25 Toronto police turned up. They came from Goma airport up to Kitale. I asked why they were there, and they said that they were there to provide security for the food distribution. I said, `Have a look out there. There are 200,000 people. How are you going to provide security?' They said, `We're Toronto police. We have been trained in security.' I asked them whether they were armed, and they said, `Oh, no. We are not armed.' I told them that they would not be able to provide security, and they scoffed at me. A quarter of an hour later I heard that they had gone five minutes up the road and been held up by the Zairean military, who relieved them of their watches, wallets, passports and the works. That was the good-intentioned but ill-prepared attempt at security.

I say to the person who talked yesterday about the lack of security that of course there is a lack of security. You go into those situations knowing full well that you will not have security. My security and the security of those who worked with me was the T-shirts that we wore all the time—I am sorry I do not have it on tonight—which had on it `CARE Australia'.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I pay tribute to a close friend and, as of today, a former colleague, Dr John Hewson, who has announced his retirement from the seat of Wentworth. John Hewson will probably be remembered as the man who sought to introduce from opposition the most dramatic reforms to the Australian economy in various areas of social policy that had ever been pressed in our history and who failed not because of a failure of those policies but because of a failure to convince the Australian public of the merit of those policies in the face of the most dishonest campaign of scaremongering that has ever been known.

para.tab: John Hewson's approach to life was probably encapsulated in Fightback. It was aimed at providing everyone with a fair go, with opportunity, with equality of access to everything in Australia. He was not in favour, as he said so eloquently today in his farewell speech in the House of Representatives, of governments telling people what they could and could not do. He was in favour of people being entitled to do what they wanted to do, with of course the limits being only to the extent to which their freedom to do those things interfered with the freedom of others. His creed, which he underlined today, was supremacy of the individual. That, of course, is the underlying creed behind the coalition parties, in particular the Liberal Party.

I commend John Hewson on his farewell speech today. There are a couple of matters I do not agree with him about. For example, I did not agree with him about the way his outstanding policy was presented at the last election. I have to admit, I did not agree with the way that outstanding recipe for rescue of Australia was abandoned so hurriedly after the last election, because of the way in which the government had so dishonestly destroyed the policy's chances of being accepted by the Australian public. I believed then and I believe now that abandoning Fightback in that way at that time was not appropriate; it was most unfortunate.

I believe that had John Hewson been able to retain the essence of Fightback he would have gained, if you like, a greater status and the status he deserved in political life. But, unfortunately, that abandoning of Fightback meant that he was subjected once again to a series of unfair and often dishonest attacks as no longer standing for anything. The fact is that John Hewson has always stood for the supremacy of the individual. As I said, while Fightback was a manifestation of that principle, there are other ways of supporting that view. John Hewson was always in his leadership promoting policies that maintained that supremacy of the individual.

He said in his speech today that he was, if you like, left of centre on social matters and to the right of centre on economic matters. To an extent, I disagree with his own analysis of himself. He was and is a genuine believer in individual freedom. Believers in individual freedom would naturally believe in freedom in social matters. If that puts you to the left of the spectrum, too bad; it seems to me to be an absurd definition of `left'. If the same belief in the same principle puts you to the right on economic matters, that is equally absurd. John Hewson is a genuine Liberal; he believes in the rights of the individual. There are many of us on this side who support John Hewson's approach to politics—that is, a belief in individual freedom. If that means being classified on the left on social matters and on the right on economic matters, so be it.

I totally agree with John Hewson's view that he needed a mandate on Fightback, that he had to get public support as evidenced at the ballot box before he could introduce such an essential, albeit radical, set of changes. He could not have in any honesty gone to the electorate denying what he was going to do and then seek to do it, apart from the fact that this chamber would not have allowed it to happen because we would have had here a group of people with, for whatever reason, the capacity to block federal legislation. They would not have had that capacity had we received a mandate to introduce the Fightback reforms which, among other things, included a massive reduction in the cost of living in rural areas in particular; massive benefits to those industries which are major employers in Australia and which depend on overseas markets; and massive improvement for our capacity to compete in the world.

It is a tragedy that John Hewson's master plan for Australia's recovery, for Australia's role in the year 2000 and the 21st Century, was rejected. Instead of his decency in that election campaign, we got deception from the other side. Instead of truth, we got trumped up lies. Instead of facts, we got falsity and fear. Instead of honesty, we got dishonesty. They were the essential differences between the campaign that John Hewson ran at the last election and the campaign of deception and dishonesty. In his speech today, the Prime Minister could not prevent himself from taking a cheap shot at the opposition—at a time, surely, when it was appropriate to comment properly and decently on the very significant role that John Hewson has played in politics, economics and economic politics in Australia in recent years.

One of my disagreements, however, with John Hewson is his continual stressing that he was more interested in policy than politics. I agree. He went into the last election with an outstanding policy and all that countered him was dishonest politics. But politics is not necessarily dishonest—it is only the way the government plays it. In fact, politics is the art of the achievable. To that extent, when John Hewson says, `I wasn't a very good politician, but I was good at creating policy,' he is probably right. But I do not think he should downgrade the role of politics. It is my earnest wish that John Hewson had been a better politician—in other words, someone better able to make his outstanding objectives more achievable.

In conclusion, John Hewson has left a remarkable mark on Australian politics—a far more lasting, effective and positive mark than the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) could ever hope to leave. I send my very kindest regards to Carolyn, Tim, Micah and Rachel. I have known John Hewson for almost 20 years. He was a constituent of mine when I was the member for Macarthur. I have nothing but the highest regard for him, for his ability and for his credibility. I wish him all the very best in his future endeavours and I am certain he will be successful.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, upon notice, on 5 July 1994:

para.tab: (1) What action is being taken by the Australian Government to increase the energy efficiency of Australian industry.

(2) (a) How much money has been expended or will be committed to programs to achieve this end in the 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years; and (b) how many staff-years are or have been dedicated to this purpose in the 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.
(3) (a) How much impact has this had on energy efficiency in industry overall; and (b) how much impact has this had on emissions as a percentage of total emissions from industry.
(4) In the context of our commitment to at least stabilise emissions at 1990 levels, is the level of activity by the department sufficient.

(5) In the light of the Minister's response to Senator Coulter on 30 August 1993 in which the Minister claimed that he would oppose under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade any foreign domestic legislation, such as the United States' British thermal unit tax, which attempts to apply energy standards to all products including imports, what is the department doing to ensure that Australian products will be competitive with European products.

(6) What is the funding and staff commitment to improving energy efficiency in Australian products for the 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years in dollars and staff-years, and as a percentage of total industry support and technology development programs.

(7) What percentage of total energy-related research and development goes respectively to coal technology, nuclear technology, wind technology, solar technology, insulation technology, energy efficiency technology (improved motors, pumps, etcetera), and to technology based on conserving energy (improved heating elements, heat pumps, co-generation, etcetera).
(8) What `no-regrets' improvements in efficiency or conservation have been identified, and what percentage of total energy use do these represent.

(9) What additional improvements in efficiency or conservation have been identified as `no-regrets' improvements when externality costs have been added to the market costs, and what percentage of total energy use do these represent.

(10) Has the Government calculated the impact on exports of the development of a domestic market for clean technology, energy efficiency and conservation; if so, what is this impact and what parameters for creation of such a market have been used in the calculation.
(11) What would the impact on the domestic economy be for the development of markets referred to in (10) in terms of addition to GDP and jobs created.
(12) The Minister has stated that fossil fuel dependence is not a problem for Australia, what alternatives to petroleum products do we have available.
(13) How elastic is the demand for petroleum, particularly what percentage of petroleum product use could be replaced economically within the next 10 years.

(14) (a) What is the rate of development of major existing global oil fields in terms of new technological inputs, upgrading old equipment and putting in new extractive technologies; and (b) at the current price of oil, what is the prospect of major oilfield structural upgrading occurring.

(15) (a) What is the rate of pubic debt in Saudi Arabia and other Gulf States, and how is it changing; (b) how long is this rate of debt likely to be sustainable; and (c) what measure of debt is going to fund oilfield upgrading.
(16) What is the status of the North Sea oilfield, and its likely lifespan at current oil prices.
(17) What is the status of the Indonesian oilfields, and their likely lifespan at current prices.
(18) What is the status of the Bass Strait oilfields, and their likely lifespan at current prices.
(19) What is the impact of the Commonwealth of Independent States oilfield sales, and how long are they sustainable at existing oil prices.
(20) How long are current oil prices likely to be sustainable, and approximately what price level will allow the development of new oilfields or the redevelopment of existing fields.
(21) Once the Bass Strait oilfields tail off, what alternative oilfields does Australia have.
(22) Should world oil prices rise, why would Australian oil prices not rise to a similar degree.
(23) What would be the economic impact on Australia, in terms of jobs, exports and GDP, of: (a) a doubling of oil prices; and (b) a tripling of oil prices.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: (1) The major Government program to improve energy efficiency in the industrial sector is the National Energy Management Program (NEMP), which is operated by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Principal activities of this program involve facilitation of energy audits, conduct of industry studies, and dissemination of advisory booklets, educational videos and information on internationally available energy technologies. In addition, the Commonwealth participates in joint projects with the States through NEMP. The main projects for industry currently involve investigation of the prospects for energy equipment and a review of energy auditing and energy management training programs for industry.

The Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency (CEPA) operates a cleaner production program consisting of workshops, a research initiative and a demonstration program. Between 1994 and 1996, ten firms will participate in a demonstration program of before and after energy audits, based on the introduction of an energy management plan by a consultant. The research component will be based on a whole-life-cycle approach to the manufacture of several products, including energy consumption.

The Government has recently put in place taxation arrangements that encourage industry to invest in new plant and equipment, and in one instance, environmental measures. These arrangements will improve energy efficiency through the uptake of new technology.
(2) The majority of Government funding for improving the energy efficiency of industry is through the NEMP:
(a) funds expended/committed on industry
1994-95—estimated approaching $2 million

(b) staff years (for each of the 3 years, equivalent of
approximately 3 staff years)

(3) No broad impact data is available for the industrial sector. However, the estimated median annual savings per enterprise from adoption of energy audit recommendations made in 1992-93 with less than two-year payback periods were about 680 Giga Joules, valued at about $24,000 and representing about 170 tonnes of carbon dioxide saved.

(4) Australia has no binding commitment to stabilise emissions at 1990 levels. The commitment presumably referred to in this question is only an implicit target in the Framework Convention on Climate Change that requires developed countries to make efforts to return greenhouse gas emissions to earlier levels by the end of the decade.

Australia's response to climate change is coordinated and implemented through the National Greenhouse Response Strategy (NGRS). The NGRS was always intended to be a phased approach to limiting Australia's greenhouse gas emissions. The first phase, which we are currently in, focuses on no-regrets activities and improving our knowledge base. No-regrets is defined as measures that have other net benefits, or at least no net costs, besides limiting greenhouse gas emissions. Future phases will include a range of measures that take into account improvements in knowledge, the outcomes of the first phase, and key economic and international developments.

The Government recognises that further action must and will be taken to implement no-regrets measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Departments are currently engaged in consultations with industry aimed at identifying cost-effective and practical opportunities for energy efficiency improvements.

(5) The Government opposes the use of environmental standards by other countries as non-tariff barriers to trade. The best way to address global environmental problems is through multi-lateral negotiations, such as the Framework Convention on Climate Change, not through the use of unilateral trade restrictions which may have unforeseen and deleterious environmental and trade consequences.

The Government recognises the need for Australian industry and products to be competitive in global markets, including Europe. Over the last decade, policies have focused on diversifying our export base into the higher value and faster growing areas of world trade in manufactures and services. The policy agenda was reshaped immensely during the 1980s to enhance this transformation of our industrial structure. Attention shifted from a defensive approach based on border protection, to an outward looking program aimed at encouraging competitiveness, the achievement of best practice and sustained growth in exports.
(6) In relation to the NEMP:
(a) funds expended/committed
(b) staff years
1992-93—17 (approximately)
1993-94—18 (approximately)
1994-95—18 (estimated)
(The difference between the figures in this part and those of part 2 arises because these figures apply to all NEMP activities, not just those relating to industry)

This expenditure equates to 0.21%. 0.20% and 0.18% of total industry assistance and development across all sectors for 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 respectively, as outlined in Budget Paper No.1 (1994-95).

The Energy Research and Development Corporation provides funds for non-coal energy related research, including energy efficiency projects. The Corporation's budgets for 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 are 11.6, 11.0 and 11.0 million dollars respectively. These equate to 1.19%, 1.07%, and 1.04% of total Government spending, in the same years, on research and development, as outlined in Budget Paper No. 1 (1994-95).

(7) ABS data does not provide a breakdown on the basis requested for the business enterprise sector. The following breakdown is possible for expenditure by the "government and higher education" sector in
1990-91 on energy research and development expenditure, totalling $103 million:
coal technology (19.8%);
nuclear technology (11.9%);
wind technology (0.1%);
solar technology (2.9%);
energy conservation and efficiency technology (3.9%);
electric power conservation (1.4%);
electricity transmission and distribution (1.3%); and
energy storage (3.1%).
(8) The NGRS has identified a number of no-regrets strategies for improving the energy efficiency of the industrial and commercial sector, including:
the introduction of standards and codes for new commercial buildings;
the introduction of standards and codes for new industrial machinery;
using information services and industry assistance programs to encourage energy efficient practices and equipment; and
targeting action on end-use areas with significant energy consumption and those industries with the greatest potential for improvements.
As noted in the answer to part 4, Departments are currently engaged in consultations with industry to identify further no-regrets measures.

There is no definitive economic data available on the percentage reductions of total energy use that no-regrets opportunities might generate. Industry estimates and anecdotal evidence suggest that savings in the order of 5-10% may be possible in the industrial sector.

(9) While no definitive economic data is available, studies suggest that the maximum opportunities currently available from activities, including no regrets, across all economic sectors could generate energy efficiency savings in the order of 20% of total energy end-use. However, the full technical and economic potential could never be achieved, or even closely approached, because of imperfect knowledge, behavioural inertia and inherent lags in the system. This figure, therefore, provides a ceiling on what is technically possible.
(10) The Government has made no such calculations.
My Department is, however, currently working closely with environment industry groups to identify industry development opportunities.
(11) The Government has made no assessment of this matter.

(12) Australia has large resources of black and brown coal, natural gas and uranium together with more limited resources, but still significant, of liquid petroleum. As a result Australia is able to produce heat and electricity at costs that are relatively low by world standards and has become one of the world's largest energy exporters.

Australia is a large scale exporter of energy commodities (especially coal, natural gas and uranium) and energy intensive products (such as aluminium). The total value of energy supplied to end users in Australia is some $35 billion annually, while exports amount to a further $11 billion annually.

There are a wide range of substances that could potentially be used as alternatives to liquid forms of crude oil. These include, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), natural gas, ethanol, methanol, synthetic liquid fuels derived from coal or natural gas, electricity in electric vehicles or even hydrogen.

(13) Recent estimates of the long term price elasticity of demand for petrol in Australia vary from—0.22 to—0.66. Studies of other developed countries have indicated that the long term price elasticity for automotive gasoline is between—0.25 and—0.7. This means that a 10% increase in real price will result in a decrease in consumption of between 2.5% and 7%.

The Commonwealth Government, while setting no targets for levels of alternative fuels to be substituted for petroleum products, supports the development of a commercial alternative fuels industry, based on Australian resources. The Government's strategy is to provide a suitable economic environment so that the private sector can introduce alternative and synthetic fuels on a commercial basis when the cost of producing alternative fuels and prices of existing fuels makes the substitution economically viable.

(14) Research and development by all major oil producing countries is a significant aspect of their long term planning. It is not possible to give a figure for the global level of redevelopment of oil fields and the application of new technological inputs, but this is an ongoing and continual process which all oil producing companies use as part of their production strategy.

Major structural upgrading of oil fields is being undertaken at the current price of oil where this upgrading is considered profitable in terms of the recoverable reserves it could generate. Any sustained increase in world oil prices would see redevelopment, structural upgrading and greater levels of recoverability as more oil fields become economically viable.

(15) The International Energy Agency (Committee on non-member countries, Report on Saudi Arabia, April 1993) estimates external debt service in 1990 for Saudi Arabia was about US$ 1.8 billion or 4.5% of oil export earnings.

In 1993 outstanding `development bonds' for Saudi Arabia totalled about US$ 9.4 billion; outstanding Treasury bills were estimated at US$ 18.7 billion; and recent borrowing on the international capital markets total about US$ 7.4 billion. Total debt, including earlier borrowing is estimated at about US$50 billion or 45% of GDP. Saudi foreign reserves minus gold have declined since 1982 with the current level at about US$ 6 billion.

Between 1985 and 1990 Saudi external debt service payments were less than US$ 3 billion per annum. Recent borrowing implies that debt servicing will become a significant feature of Saudi financial policy in the mid 1990s. Although Saudi Arabia's medium term debt has doubled in the last few years and its total debt has quadrupled (including treasury instruments), Saudi Arabia's debt ratios will probably remain conservative for some time compared to other oil exporting developing countries.
No information is available on the measure of debt that is funding oilfield upgrading.

(16) North Sea oil fields, while currently in a state of steady slow decline, are expected to continue production well into the next century. It has been estimated that at current prices approximately 20 new fields will begin development between 1994 and 1998 and approximately 8 fields between 1999 and 2003.
(17) Based on 1993 production forecasts and estimated recoverable reserves Indonesian oil fields have an approximate 13 year lifespan.
(18) The life of Bass Strait "commercial" recoverable reserves is currently estimated at seven years for oil and condensate and 23 years for natural gas.
(19) The Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) (or the former Soviet Union) is reliant on revenue from oil field sales for a considerable percentage of its foreign currency earnings.

The Oil and Gas Journal reports that for the whole of 1988, the Soviet Union produced 12.5 million barrels per day (mbd). Since 1988 production has declined and output for the CIS is about 6.7 mbd. The CIS is expected to fall to third place, behind Saudi Arabia (8.0 mbd) and the US (about 6.6 mbd), in global oil production.

Despite the fall in CIS oil production, exports have remained at high levels. Russia alone exported over 6.4 mbd of oil and refined products during 1993. This has been possible because domestic consumption has declined faster than the fall in production.
The International Energy Agency estimates that oil production within the CIS will fall almost 1 mbd for all of 1994 and demand will drop about 0.7 mbd. Russia will remain a large exporter of oil.

(20) Most analysts consider the medium to long term outlook for the world oil price is a slow but gradual increase for the next 5 years. It is impossible to predict the exact world oil price which allows the development of new oil fields or redevelopment of existing oil fields. This is because these decisions are reliant on a number of other variables, such as the development of technology, which reduces the cost of exploration and development.

A rough correlation can be drawn between oil prices and the level of exploration and development of oil fields. Increasing oil prices will generally have a positive net effect on the level of exploration and development being undertaken.

(21) Australia has significant alternative reserves in Western Australia (Carnarvon oilfield basin), inland South Australia and Queensland (Cooper/Eromanga basins) and the possibility of significant commercial reserves in the Timor Sea and the North West Shelf.

(22) Australian oil prices do rise and fall in line with price changes in the international oil market. This is because oil is an internationally traded commodity and any attempt at price setting or fixing by the Australian Government would merely lead to inefficiencies and distortions within the domestic petroleum industry.

The Government's petroleum policy is to promote an efficient and competitive petroleum exploration and production industry. In January 1988, the Government deregulated the crude oil market and removed export restrictions on oil. Access to international markets gave local refiners more flexibility to lower costs, select feedstocks, increase efficiency and strengthen their competitive position. Producers are now able to operate with greater certainty with the freedom to supply oil at international prices.

(23) A doubling or tripling of the world oil price is most unlikely in the short term. Short term increases in the world oil price, as illustrated in the dramatic price rises during the Gulf conflict, have a very marginal effect on any medium to long term economic indicators such as GDP, exports and inflation.

For oil price rises to have a sustained effect on these indicators they would have to be long term trends and not simply market fluctuations. While such sustained price rises would have a considerable effect on the national economy they are not forecast to occur within the foreseeable future nor at a rate which would preclude the development of suitable policy responses. By being competitive, outward focused and innovative Australia can raise its potential rate of economic growth. Sustained high economic growth will generate the employment opportunities to get more Australians back to work. The Government has adopted several strategies to achieve this:
a gradual program to reduce tariffs and other forms of barrier protection which has put pressure on Australian industry to become more internationally competitive;
microeconomic reform to improve the environment in which Australian industry operates; and
a range of generic policies designed to actively encourage Australian manufacturing and service industries to take up the challenges brought about by opening up the economy.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, upon notice, on 18 October 1994:

para.tab: (1) How does the department define the parameters of the "environment industry".

(2) What Government policies and programs exist which provide assistance specifically to the environment industry or to parts of the environment industry (that is, excluding "general" industry support schemes available to many or all industries).
(3) What is the budgetary cost of each of the programs identified in (2), both direct and indirect (for example, through tax concessions).

(4) What information is available about similar policies and programs at State Government level which provide assistance specifically to the environment industry or to parts of the environment industry.
(5) Can the Minister provide a directory of businesses which are active in the environment industry; if so, how comprehensive is that directory.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: (1) The Australian Bureau of Statistics has developed a draft of the possible classification for environmental goods and services as follows:

Environmental goods include: air pollution control; water pollution control; waste management equipment; noise control equipment; chemicals for pollution control; instruments for monitoring pollution; scientific research and laboratory; and natural resource conservation/protection.

Environmental services include: waste handling and facility operations; natural resource monitoring, conservation and protection; consulting services; environmental research and development; environmental training and education; legal services; and other services.
My Department's activities in support of the environment industries have primarily involved:

support to develop the environment management industry (eg. firms involved in water supply and waste water treatment, waste management and recycling, site remediation industry associated with mining operations, pollution control, cleaner production and energy efficiency); and
promotion of a more environmentally sound approach by all firms.
assistance through generic programs such as AusIndustry for firms in environment industries.

(2) The Department of Industry, Science and Technology directly supports the environment management industry through the Project Development and Technology Diffusion Network, which aims to make Australian firms internationally competitive through technology diffusion, the development of networks of suppliers, a referral service for firms, and demonstration sites.

Prior to 1994-95, DIST administered a separate Environmental Technology Grants Scheme, which provided funding for approved Research and Development through the IR&D Board. The scheme has now been incorporated into a wider generic program known as the Competitive Grants Scheme for R&D.

The Department of Industry, Science and Technology also supports the promotion of a more environmentally sound approach by all firms through the Better Business by Environmental Management program, (which stemmed from the Best Practice Environmental Management Demonstration Program), administered through the National Industry Extension Service (NIES).
The Environment Management Industry Association of Australia (EMIAA) has also received Commonwealth support over time for a number of initiatives.
Development of other environment industry sectors is directly supported by programs in other portfolios. Some of the major programs are listed below under part 3.

Support for the environment industry is also provided through generic government programs such as the Tax Concession for Research and Development, and the Pooled Development Funds programs. Similarly AusIndustry programs are available for firms in environment industries who meet eligibility requirements. The majority of Commonwealth Government funds to assist these industries is provided through these generic programs.

(3) An amount of $4.5 million over the next four years has been committed by the Department of Industry, Science and Technology for the Project Development and Technology Diffusion Network. The Environmental Technology Grants Scheme made payments to the value of $2,358,774 in 1993/94 and committed a further $924,890 during that period.
Information on funds provided to the environment industry through the generic programs noted in part 2 above is not available.
Other agencies which have programs directly supporting environment industries include:
AUSTRADE has an Environment Business Unit which jointly operates AUSTEMEX (the Australian Environment Management Export Corporation) with EMIAA;

AIDAB will provide over $120 million in 1994-95 for projects in developing countries that are specifically targeted at environment activities aimed at the promotion of sustainable development and at the same time advance Australia's commercial interests in this sector; in addition, AIDAB is providing $464,000 to the Environment Protection Agency (EPA) under the Environmental Co-operation with Asia Program for projects for 1994-95 to 1995-96;

the Environment Protection Agency (EPA) provides assistance through the Environmental Co-operation with Asia Program at a cost of $0.604 million per annum to 1996-97, and administers the National Environment Industries Database at a cost of $1.6 million funding over a four year period from 1992-93;

the Department of Primary Industries and Energy administers several programs which assist environment industries including the Renewable Energy Promotion Program ($3 million over three years), the Solar Water Heater Program (or Energy Card—$6 million over three years), the Energy Research and Development Corporation ($11 million per annum), the Perth International Centre for the Application of Solar Energy ($1.5 million over three years), and the Energy Management Program ($5.5 million per annum).
(4) Joint Commonwealth/State AusIndustry programs (eg the National Industry Extension Service) operate to assist enterprises to identify cost saving measures and develop waste management plans.
The Senator should approach State Governments to ascertain full details of their programs, but I am advised that the following programs operate:

In Victoria, the Environment Protection Agency provides interest-free loans up to $100,000 for Cleaner Production for SMEs (Small to Medium Size Enterprises) which introduce new waste recycling technology for the first time. Programs aimed at the development of efficient energy solutions formerly run by the State Electricity Commission continue to operate. Two Councils (the Waste Management Council and the Recycling and Resource Recovery Council) established by the Victorian Environment Protection Act also provide funding for innovative projects and infrastructure development for waste management. Both Councils are funded from levies on waste going to landfills.

The South Australia Government has established a Recycling Development Fund to promote recycling through a 19 cents levy for every tonne of waste going to landfill. The Office of the Environment Protection Authority has also initiated a Cleaner Production Program aimed at assisting firms to implement low or no waste technologies.

The Queensland Government support for the environment industry has been focused on assisting it to form networks. Financial support for the establishment of the EMIAA (Environment Management Industry Association of Australia) was also given in 1993/94.

(5) There are several commercial directories of businesses involved in the environment management industry and a Department of Industry, Science and Technology sponsored promotion booklet. Copies of these directories will be provided to the Senator. The commercial directories provide a very good coverage of the industry and include over 1000 companies.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: It should be noted that the majority of transplants for non-New Zealand foreign patients take place in Queensland. Accordingly, the answers have been structured around the Queensland experience.

(1) While the Commonwealth Government does not have direct responsibility for medical services which may be offered by Australian hospitals, Government policy is firmly against any commercial trade in organs per se. The Government does support, however, the export of medical services which may involve transplanted organs consistent with the policy of the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council (AHMAC). That is, that where there is no available Australian or New Zealand recipient for an organ, that organ may be offered to all non-New Zealand foreign patients. However, this is only undertaken following a comprehensive search of all Australian registries for a matching recipient. It is understood that only Queensland and NSW undertake transplants involving foreign recipients.

(2) The Commonwealth provides funding to the Australian Co-ordinating Committee on Organ Registries and Donation (ACCORD), which was established by the AHMAC, and to State Transplant Co-ordination Centres through the Nationally Funded Centres program.

(3) The annual trade returns supplied by the Department of Trade, include a `sink' or `other category' that allows for the notification of organ transplantation, and other `catch all' items such as heparin, bone marrow, snake and bee venom as well as animal tissue for permanent grafting or implantation. However, individual tissue and organ items such as hearts and kidneys are not required to be identified.
(4) Trade in this `other' category was recorded as $516,000 in 1993.

(5) In Queensland and New South Wales, foreign nationals have not received kidney, heart or lung transplants from cadaver donors. However, because of the relative excess of cadaver livers offered for transplant, a proportion of these have been implanted into overseas patients. Most overseas referrals are babies and young children.

No fee is paid for the organ other than the costs of retrieval to the Unit which receives the organ. These costs (for perfusion fluids, transport, etc) usually amount to a little under $5,000. In Queensland the current fee for a liver transplant on a non-New Zealand foreign patient is $150,000. These fees are for the medical services involved.
(6) Fifteen non-New Zealand foreign patients were transplanted in the last twelve months. The expected figure is similar for next year.
(7) There is no NSW Ethics Committee. However, many hospital and academic institutions have developed Ethics Committees for areas of speciality or expertise within their experience.

(8) Donor organs are offered in the first instance to the State where the donor was deceased. In the event that this State is unable to utilise these organs the rotation program is then set in motion. Under these arrangements the States are placed on a list which ensures that each State will, over time, have the opportunity to benefit from another States inability to utilise a donor organ.
Non-New Zealand foreign patients are only transplanted after the rotation list has been exhausted.

In Queensland, the notification of acceptance of each foreign patient onto a transplant program, other than those from New Zealand is given at the time of acceptance to the Chief Medical Officer, Department of Health, Queensland and the Immigration Department. At the time of transplant each foreign patient is identified to the interstate representative of the Australian Transplant Co-ordinators Association (ACTA).

In addition, notice of the transplant of all patients is recorded in the National Organ Donor Registry of Australia under the auspices of ACTA and the Australian and New Zealand Dialysis and Transplant Registry (ANZDATA) set up by AHMAC. Further details of foreign patients transplanted are recorded in the National Liver Transplant Registry.
(9) Australian and New Zealand patients have an absolute priority over foreign patients. Priority in admission to the waiting list is decided by:

(i) The Liver Transplant Assessment Panel which is made up of surgeons, physicians and paediatricians from all Brisbane Teaching Hospitals. Similar panels are in existence in all programs in Australia.

(ii) Priority (as in all States) is then assessed by organ matching by weight and blood group with absolute priority given to Australian and New Zealand patients initially on the local waiting list and then on interstate waiting lists according to strict rotation.

(iii) Prioritisation of urgent cases is by rules agreed mutually by the Heads of all Australian Liver Transplant Units such that a patient who is intensive care dependent takes priority for the next organ offered anywhere within Australia and New Zealand.
No foreign national can therefore be listed as `urgent'.

(10) All patients are accepted onto a transplant program in the hope and expectation that they will receive a transplant. For ease of access they are resident in the city in which it is expected that the transplant will take place or its local environs. Generally the total ischaemia time (time that the liver is stored) would not exceed twelve hours. No organs are exported overseas.

It should be noted that many Australian patients have been transplanted overseas with foreign patients organs before the establishment of heart, heart/lung, liver and other solid organ programs in this country.

(11) Reliably this is less than sixteen hours (livers), twelve hours optimum. However, in other organ transplant programs longer periods are accepted (up to twenty-four hours). Many of these organs stored for such longer periods fail to function.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: (1) Australia has noted the recommendations of the International Commission of Jurists.

(2) Although the Japanese Government has not accepted the International Commission for Jurists' recommendation that the Japanese Government had a legal and moral responsibility to provide compensation to "Comfort Women", the Japanese authorities have been considering the question of what sort of gesture might be made by Japan to demonstrate its feelings of apologies and remorse. talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, on 16 December 1994:

para.tab: (1) Given the concerns over the environmental and social impact of the proposed World Bank funded Arun III Dam Project in Nepal, will the Minister ask the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau to refer the project to the Environment Protection Agency for assessment under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act; if not, why not.

(2) What action will the Minister take to ensure that any environmental and social impacts of the dam are investigated before Australia's executive director serving on the World Bank votes for the project.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) The Treasury referred the World Bank's Environmental Assessment (EA) of the proposed Arun III Dam Project in Nepal to the Environment Protection Agency (EPA) in May 1993 in accordance with established procedures designed to enable the EPA to provide advice to the Treasury on environmental aspects of projects supported by the World Bank. This did not constitute a formal referral and assessment under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. The EPA recommended closer consideration of several issues, including: the ecological and cultural value of features of the Arun Valley; the availability of resources for regional conservation; the project's implications for endangered and other species; waste disposal issues; and the barrier effect of the dam on fish. Australia's Executive Director at the World Bank passed these comments to Bank management. The task manager for the project subsequently indicated that the matters raised by the EPA had been addressed extensively in a number of documents, including EAs for each component of the project and a regional EA.

(2) The Government is monitoring developments with respect to Arun III. The situation is currently fluid. The newly elected Government of Nepal has advised the World Bank that it wishes to review the project in more depth before proceeding. That review is now under way. Until it is completed, the Bank's Executive Board will not consider the project. Meanwhile, the Bank's Inspection Panel has registered a request for an inspection of the project from citizens of Nepal who claim that their rights and interests have been or are likely to be materially and adversely affected by the acts or omissions of the Bank during the design and appraisal of Arun III. (The Panel is an independent body established in September 1993 to receive and investigate complaints from affected groups that the Bank has not acted in accordance with its own policies and procedures in a project that it supports.)

The Inspection Panel's initial comments and findings on the above request include a recommendation that some aspects of the request, including environmental and social impacts of the dam, warrant further investigation. The Bank's Executive Board is empowered to decide whether a recommendation by the Panel for inspection of a request should be accepted, and will reach a decision after further consultations with the Panel. The Board's decision and the Panel's recommendation will be made public.

The Government will be advised by the Executive Director representing the World Bank constituency of which Australia is a member on the question of the Board's response to the Panel's initial recommendation. The Executive Director has been informed that Australia would not wish to see Arun III considered by the Board until a decision has been reached on this matter.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 January 1995:

para.tab: I refer to the search and rescue operation conducted for French yachtswoman Isabelle Autissier:
(1) (a) For how many hours were the C130 Hercules and the P3C Orions on standby.
(b) For how many hours were the Hercules and the Orions in the air; and
(c) What are the direct and full operational costings per hour of these aircraft.
(2) (a) For how many hours was HMAS Darwin operated (including departure and return to port).
(b) What is the per hour direct and full operational costing for HMAS Darwin.
(3) (a) For how many hours was the Seahawk helicopter in the air; and
(b) What are the direct and full operational costings per hour of this helicopter.
(4) How many navy, airforce and defence civilians had leave cancelled to be on standby for the rescue operation.
(5) Who took the decisions to use the defence assets that were used and when and on what advice were these decisions made.

(6) Was Ms Autissier given any choice as to whether she was rescued, and was she offered either the resupply of emergency equipment and/or the help of experienced Southern Ocean yachtsmen to enable her to reach Hobart if she so wished.
(7) (a) Did Ms Autissier carry insurance; if so by whom;
(b) Did her insurance include the Institute of London Underwriters standard yacht clauses; and
(c) Did her cover provide for life salvage; if so, will the Federal Government be seeking reimbursement from her insurance company for her rescue; if not, why not.

(8) Given that BOC is a large French conglomerate worth billions of dollars, which has invested between $10 million and $20 million in the Round the World race and that the BOC committee authorised Ms Autissier to sail from Capetown into the dangerous Southern Indian Ocean with a jury rig and canvas covering the hole of her previous dismasting, will the Federal Government be seeking assistance from BOC to meet the rescue costs; if not, why not.

(9) In the light of the cost to the Australian taxpayer of this rescue will the Federal Government introduce legislation to provide for the recovery of search and rescue costs where recklessness may be deemed to be a factor; if not, why not.
(10) Will the Federal Government set up an inquiry into all the facts surrounding Ms Autissier's rescue; if not, why not.
(11) Is it not true that the international convention on Safety of Life at Sea in fact does not refer to the reimbursement of costs and therefore does

question.para: not prevent a signatory to the convention from seeking reimbursement costs where possible.

para.tab: (12) What was the full cost of each search and rescue operation performed by the Australian Defence Force during the 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years.

answer.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: (1)-(3) Elements of 86 Wing (C130) and 92 Wing (P3C) were on standby to provide assistance for this operation for approximately 81 hours.
The total hours and costs associated with the Defence assets used in the search and rescue are as follows:

answer.para: ADF Asset Hours Additional Cost Direct Cost Full Cost

para.tab: Note: The category `Other' includes administrative costs associated with the commencement and implementation of the operation.

Additional Costs are those expenses which were incurred as a consequence of the rescue, including expenditure on such items as fuel, spares, maintenance and rations. Direct Costs include all Additional Costs plus those costs which, while they can be attributed to the operation (eg. salaries and superannuation), would have been borne by Defence regardless of the rescue. Full Costs include Direct Costs plus departmental overheads and capital depreciation.

(4) 31 personnel were recalled from recreational leave. Wherever possible those personnel were dispatched on leave again on completion of their task. Where this was not possible, leave arrangements were rescheduled to fit in with the wishes of affected individuals and/or the ship's program. No personnel lost their leave entitlements.

(5) Following a request from the Maritime Rescue and Control Centre and in accordance with the procedures laid down in the national search and rescue plan, the Chief of the Defence Force approved the use of ADF assets in the rescue operation. This decision was made at about 6.30 pm on Wednesday 28 December 1994 following consultation with his specialist staff.
The Minister for Transport has provided the answers to questions (6) to (11).

(6) To the first part of the question, no, as Ms Autissier activated two Emergency Position Indicating Radio Beacons (EPIRBs). EPIRBs are only activated when a seafarer is in distress. Search and rescue procedures commenced when the signal was received.
To the second part of the question, no, as there were no vessels proximate to Ms Autissier's craft and given the state of the seas it was not possible to effect repairs to the craft.
(7) I have no knowledge of the insurance arrangements of Ms Autissier or any other participant in the race.

(8) The Government will not be seeking assistance from BOC to meet the rescue costs. Australia is a contracting party to the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) under which contracting parties are obliged to provide search and rescue response (SAR) services for seafarers in distress.

While there are no specific provisions in SOLAS relating to responsibility for meeting costs of rescues, Australia, like all other contracting parties, does not recover the costs of search and rescue incidents. Because of the importance the Government places on safety of life at sea, Australia provides the service without the cost being recovered on the basis that the same service is reciprocated by other countries for Australian seafarers.

(9) No. For the reasons outlined in the response to part (8), legislation will not be introduced to recover search and rescue costs. In addition, the consequences from a deeming of recklessness could involve a denial of natural justice and/or lengthy and expensive litigation.
(10) No. The rescue was successful and the facts are not in dispute.
(11) Yes. It is true but international practice is as noted in the response to part (8).

(12) To fully cost ADF participation in all the search and rescue operations which occurred in 1992/93 and 1993/94 would involve considerable research and I am not prepared to authorise the time and effort entailed.
